In the book she's a childish, self-obsessed, neurotic but chillingly recognisable narcissist, whereas here she's some sort of avenging ghostbuster. If you take it as a movie in its own right however, it's a lot of fun; best of all is Eugenio Zanetti's amazing production design - the house is an incredible ramble of Gothic madness, peppered with hellish gargoyles, marble columns, gargantuan spaces and bizarre decor. The cast are all good actors stuck with a slightly lame script, although Taylor really gives it her all, but it's a movie where the characters are pretty much a distraction from the marvellous sets and nifty special effects (by Phil Tippett and Craig Hayes). With exteriors shot at Harlaxton Manor in Lincolnshire, and a grandiose score by horror expert Jerry Goldsmith (The Omen, Alien, Poltergeist), this is fine horror fare, confidently lensed by Dutch former cameraman DeBont. It's scary stuff, but it's not a patch on the book, which is one of the best horror novels ever written and will leave you shivering for a week.

Review title: I admit my remarks may not be ENTIRELY to the point...
Review_body: I promised myself that the next time I wrote about a Dreamworks film I'd mention how much I loathe their logo.  I now have the perfect opportunity. We all know, in this case, that the film following the logo is bad: you don't need me to tell you THAT.Jesus! how could they come up with something so awful?  Universal's globe (it looked great in the 1960s), MGM's lion, Columbia's torch-bearing lady (especially the older version, with the prism effect), J. Arthur Rank's gong, the Archers' target (my personal favourite), the Twentieth Century Fox monolith, Disney's castle, RKO's radio tower, even, perhaps, Paramount's unremarkable mountain ... all of these had class, some of them had poetry, some a decent fanfare.  Dreamworks gives us an ill-composed image of a small child (aw, how cute) fishing (aw, how cute) from a crescent moon (aw, how cute), surrounded by smudges of blue fairy-floss (aw, how cute - gag, choke), complete with tinkly music.The very name - "Dreamworks" - annoys me.  Schoolteachers, after telling small children the difference between "its", the possessive, and "it's", the contraction, should caution them to NEVER use the word "dream" to refer to anything other than those odd things we experience when we're asleep.  It's an insult to works of fiction to call them, or compare them to, dreams. (People also use the word "dream" as if it were synonymous with "desire", as if the word "desire" were too crude.  I disapprove of this, too.)  But I if Geffen, Katzenberg and Spielberg want to suggest that they're in the business of producing dull, slap-dash, rambling works of fiction - or perhaps by "dreams" they mean naked wish-fulfilment -, that's their affair.Anyway, about the film.  To be honest, I don't care of a film, any film, if it scares me or not.  ("Creepshow 2", of all things, frightened me, while "The Shining" didn't; I certainly shouldn't conclude that the former is a better film than the latter.)  The problem with the cartoony, computer-generated ghosts is not that they're not frightening, nor even that they don't look real (what would real ghosts look like?); rather, they make one think, "If there WERE ghosts, and they DID look like that, what would be so great about them?"  The story flops hither and yon in a confused daze, the group dynamics ditto (every so often you can hear Jan de Bont saying, "Ah, to hell with all this character stuff"), and Owen Wilson plays the kind of person who would try to repair a broken television set by pulling it and sticking his head in, while the power's on.  Very bad, but at least it's not boring.

Lili Taylor, Liam Neeson, Catherine Zeta-Jones, Owen Wilson, and Bruce Dern all co-star in this weird horror-thriller that pits all of them trying to survive spending the night in a haunted mansion. Zeta Jones fails horribly to capture the audience's attention as the sexy lesbian her character is supposed to be and Neeson just looks quite bored with the role of overseer of the project they all embark on. Taylor, whose character has a weird attachment and attraction to the supernatural occurrences in the house is probably the only person whom the director required to show some acting skills. As people begin to disappear into the night, the truth about the secrets that exist behind the ancient walls of this spooky mansion begin to make their way into the light of day.

I don't know if it's due to seeing "Scary Movie 2" before this, but I don't think this film scary in any aspect. It's a good idea, an experimentation that goes out of control, but the plot and the directing are too weak to do it well. Also, I found some things from the plot very implausible. First, they find the message written on the wall saying "Welcome Nell" or something like that. Then, all of a sudden, Theo asks if it's one of Luke's sick jokes, considering that they've known each other for 30 minutes and Luke hasn't made even one single joke before that. Second, people start thinking that Nell is having a mind disturb due to the fear and the scariness; then, instead of doing everything to not scare her anymore, Theo leaves her in that creepy big room by herself - turning the lights off and closing the door before leaving, oh yea of course. Gimme a break!

"The Haunting" is a far better film than what most would believe.**SPOILERS**After her mother's death, Eleanor (Lili Taylor) is desperate to get over her feelings of despair. Research Scientist Dr. Marrow (Liam Neeson) is searching for subjects to participate in a study on sleep disorder, and Eleanor is a perfect candidate. Accepted, she travels to Hill House, the site of an infamous massacre years ago, and meets up with the other subjects of the experiment Theo (Catherine Zeta-Jones) and Luke (Owen Wilson). After the usual introductions are done, Dr. Marrow briefs everyone about what they are doing and the purpose of the experiment. After an accident nearly ruins the experiment, Dr. Marrow decides to carry on. That night, strange banging noises haunt Eleanor and Theo as they try to sleep. The next day, she begins to see and experience strange events in the house. Trying to convince Theo and Luke that Dr. Marrow isn't interested in sleep deprivation doesn't work, but it brings Eleanor close to a secret that even Dr. Marrow didn't know about and that could bring the house down around them.The Good News: OHMYGOD! This has one of the creepiest houses ever in a horror film I've ever seen. It has the perfect blend of Gothic atmosphere and modern touches. It has an overall feeling of dread and suspense. With it's long, winding corridors, creature-busts for decorations, and artwork that is just as creepy as spending an eternity in hell itself, this house is just as creepy as the original. It is big and cavernous, and yet confining. These two ingredients are essential in creating the perfect haunted house movie, and the third ingredient is one of my favorite rules for haunted house is the "things that shouldn't be doing that/that shouldn't be there" philosophy. I love when haunted house films do that. If it's done right, it is an effective scene that really brings out the suspense of a movie. This movie does it right by keeping the first part of the film as a mystery as to why it's haunted, and the second half as a series of clues to lead us to a terrifying secret about the house. For the first half, though, we don't know the secret, and therefore we are left with a very spooky haunted house film. By making it just a spooky film, the paintings looking at us, the walls moving, it adds to create an atmosphere that very few haunted house films have created. There is one standout scene that really goes to prove this: as Eleanor is lying bed, she sees a black shadow enter the room on the ceiling and go over to her doorway. As the shadow gets to the doorway, it causes the archways in the door to raise, and it lights up these two red crystals. When it finishes, it appears that the door is looking at Eleanor with this demonic impression, and it is a very creepy scene. The ghosts are sometimes pretty creepy, and the way they interact with the cast is some great shocks. The one death in the film is one of the highlights. After attacking a picture of the owner of the house, the ghosts strike the person in the back and knock them onto a carpet. The carpet is dragged over to the fireplace, where it has a lion's head for a swing. The lion then opens its mouth and decapitates them, right in front of the rest of the group. There are many more different scenes that give some good chills, but would take up too much space to describe in detail. I even enjoyed the two different tones to the film. The mysterious first half is very well done, but the puzzle painted in the second half is very well thought out and is a bit out into left field, but it does make the movie seem a lot smarter than it probably is to some people.The Bad News: Despite one of the classic scenes from the original being cleverly homage in a scene that really sticks out since it doesn't follow the tone of the rest of the movie, this has one very classic mistake: the ghosts are shown. There are several scenes where we see the ghosts up close, and that really irritates me. This is the only real complaint: the ghosts are far too visible far too often.The Final Verdict: This is a better film than most admit to, but it really isn't all that bad. It has loads of suspense, a chilling house, and standout performances, all combining into a film that is a bit underrated. Watch this late at night with the lights out, and this might give you a few chills.Rated PG-13: Mild Violence, some language, and themes involving abused children

A remake of the classic 1963 movie "The Haunting" about a team of paranormal experts who look into strange occurrences in an ill-fated house. Through the course of the night some will unravel, some will question, and all will fight for their lives as the house fights back.Some people might not be afraid of random noises or echoes by no one or blood foot prints on the floor or even just how a place looks. Well, others, on the other hand, are afraid of those things, and that includes me. This movie basically scares people by using some creepy noises, chilling moans, and some great special effects to achieve the scares.And it works. I love these kinds of films! I love haunted house movies! Unfortunately, I saw "Scary movie 2" first, which spoofs most of this movie. Still, I was frightened. I will also praise this movie for the great special effects and the extensive and elaborate set designs, which I found really amazing.The performances are great, by the way, although sometimes awkward by Lili Taylor. Apart from that, I liked the other's performances. This movie might not be scary for some but others, it will scare you.

Review title: "The Haunting" (1999)- The subtle development and mature storytelling of the original are traded for loud special effects and lazy filmmaking in this trashy remake.
Review_body: In 1963, director Robert Wise unleashed onto the world a pure vision of terror with his film "The Haunting", based on Shirley Jackson's earlier novel "The Haunting of Hill House." An incredibly nuanced and subtle exercise in fear and psychological drama, Wise's film is a incredible achievement by any stretch of the imagination, and to this very day it remains an important and beloved masterwork of horror. Some (myself included) would go so far as to call it one of the greatest horror films ever made....so why not put the remake in the hands of a director known for effects-driven action schlock? What's the worst that could happen? Oh, yeah... the worst that could happen is exactly what DID happen- it's a complete mess!Jan de Bont's 1999 release "The Haunting" (which is most certainly not based on the 1959 William Castle film "House on Haunted Hill", despite several other reviews incorrectly stating this) is one of the more notorious remakes of the past twenty years, in no small part thanks to its complete and utter misunderstanding and misrepresentation of the works that inspired it. Released in the late-90's heyday of then- modern digital effects and in-your-face thrills, the film is a complete and utter betrayal of the original. It takes the careful, methodical and subdued storytelling of the original and replaces it with on- the- nose set and production design and a plethora of "Boo!" scares. It takes the thoughtful and mature character development from that amazing film and replaces it with the broadest and most hackneyed of clichés and stereotypes. And it takes the subtlety of the Robert Wise classic and destroys it by smacking you in the head with its blatancy in every single scene. It's complete trash to the original's treasure.We follow a group of insomniacs who agree to be a part of a study on their condition, set to be held in Hill House- a mansion built in the 19th century by eccentric textile tycoon Hugh Crain. However, things are not what they seem, and the director of the experiment, Dr. Marrow (Liam Neeson) has actually lured the group there under false pretenses. He instead is seeking to study the effects of fear. Soon enough, it becomes all too clear that something is amiss in Hill House, and that the spirits of the past wander the hallways at night. And for some reason, group member Eleanor "Nell" Vance (Lili Taylor) in particular seems to attract the attention of the ghosts around her...To give the film what little credit is due, there are some positive aspects of the production that I could certainly see working with a better script and in the hands of a more confident and clever filmmaker. Lili Taylor makes for a magnificent protagonist and is splendid in a slightly modernized update of the character portrayed by Julie Harris in the 1963 classic. She's the only aspect of the film that felt like it could have fit in perfectly with the original. (Thankfully, she fulfilled this promise recently when she co-starred in the wonderful haunted-house thriller "The Conjuring", which finally made good use of her talents.) I also found the cinematography to be stunning, and the film does look oft-gorgeous. Director de Bont got his start as a cinematographer, so he knows hot to compose a shot, and he works well with DP Karl Walter Lindenlaub.Unfortunately, pretty pictures and a good lead performance do little to combat the negative effects of a contrived script and numerous sequences that are tonally confused at best... and brainlessly nonsensical at worst. The film can never seem to settle on what it wants to be... it tries its hardest to strike fear with Gothic set designs and digitally-assisted jump-scares a-plenty... yet it also wants to be a whimsical and uplifting story about how the "power of love" (ugh) can save the spirits of the damned. So you get a series of jarring and awkward sequences that radically shoot back and forth between two opposing tones in a very inorganic way.The "horror" of the film is poorly handled, and generally revolves around cartoonish "ghosts" that waft through the air with all the grace of a crumpled paper airplane and hilariously tacky digital renderings of the house suddenly "morphing" into devious shapes while horns shriek in the background. I'm not one to bad-mouth digital trickery and computer-generated effects... but they need to be used in moderation in key places to be effective in the confines of a horror film. Here, de Bont seems content with throwing as much at the screen as possible, giving it a kitschy "made for TV" kids-movie vibe. It's like one of the bad episode of "Are You Afraid of the Dark?" with a budget. It's lazy, trite and completely without atmosphere.And to top it off, the story and the characters are all lazily handled and mind-numbing thanks to a script that can only be described by the word "hack." Co-star Catherine Zeta-Jones stars as a character named "Theo", whose only development involves showing off her barely- covered breasts and piling on references to her bisexuality. The story-line is incredibly dumbed-down and every major development smacks you in the face like a brick due to over- explanation. And without spoiling anything... the climax is completely out of left field, preposterous and anything but climactic.Jan de Bont is clearly trying to make the crazed 90's roller-coaster version of Robert Wise's film. And he's relishing in adding in as many loops, twirls, cork-screws and drops to its tracks as possible. But he's made one fatal flaw... he's wasted so much time on aesthetics, he's forgotten to add in the cars for people to enjoy his roller-coaster. And thus, we're left with something that looks exciting on the outside... but it completely empty and without any real fun or purpose."The Haunting" is a 3 out of 10.

After I watched it the second time I have to analyze that this haunting story didn´t scare me. There is no substance and no logic. The dialogue was very poor. The soundtrack therefore was surprisingly well adapted and the special effects well done. The cast is set wrong. Why Liam Neeson or Catherine Zeta-Jones took this part in this senseless movie? Don`t waste your precious time. The average vote on IMBb reflects exactly what I think: 4/10.

Directed by Jan de Bont. Starring Lili Taylor, Liam Neeson, Catherine Zeta-Jones, Owen Wilson, Marian Seldes, Bruce Dern, Alix Koromzay. (PG-13)Insulting remake of the classic Robert Wise chiller only resembles the inspiration in shallow ways. Doctor Neeson lures three strangers (Taylor, Zeta-Jones, Wilson) suffering from insomnia to the secluded Hill House under the pretense of a sleep study, but he really wants to study the psychological response to fear as he artificially ratchets up the "bumps in the night." Q: What are the odds that the house is actually haunted? A: Astronomically higher than the odds that the viewer will find any of it legitimately frightening. Clumsy attempts at jump scares aplenty, hamstrung further by overabundant (and below-average) CGI and the mistaken belief that "more" is "scarier," this ludicrous haunted house picture gets worse as it goes along, and is convoluted-but-dumb enough to be mistaken for a parody (the setup would vaguely serve as the basis for an actual spoof movie, the second "Scary Movie"). Taylor's meek and introspective performance (before the special effects take over and coarse melodrama sets in) is the only thing saving this stinker from the slimiest of depths; but then again, regardless of the quality of the movie she's in, when does she ever disappoint?22/100

Alot of people hate on this movie. But since it has come out on my birthday in the summer of 1999 I've loved it. I know it's goofy. But it's one of the only big budget Hollywood scare fests. And although it's not very scary or even very suspenseful it lacks something genre films desperately need, it's absolute fun. A genuine rush of pure entertainment. Starring Liam Neeson, Lili Taylor, Owen Wilson and scene stealer Catherine Zeta Jones. The film centers on a group of characters who are unwittingly participating on a study on fear in a giant grotesquely beautiful mansion with a sketchy past. The film is not subtle at all and when the floodgates of paranormal activity begin. It's a barrage of CGI that has everything from furniture to stone sculptures springing to life and attacking. Like I said before the movie it's a ton of fun and a truly rare example of an imaginative Hollywood reimagining with a budget so that the director of Speed and Twister can do everything his little heart desires. One of my faves.Budget: $80M
Box Office: $180M9/10

Let's get this out of the way first. I like this remake of The Haunting better than I like Robert Wise's 1963 version of the film. However, the discrepancy between the two in my eyes on this viewing is nowhere near my last viewing in 1999, when I felt the remake was a 10 and the original a 6. My opinion of the original has gone up slightly, to a 7, and my opinion of this film has gone down two points, to an 8.Still, I can't see how someone can like the original film a lot and dislike this remake. There are more things about them that are similar than most folks admit. A lot of the negative views on the remake seem centered on CGI and other special effects. I think that puts a disproportionate emphasis on one element of the film, and it's not as if the Wise film was really devoid of effects, although I agree it had far less.Most folks think the original is scary and this one isn't. Maybe that's part of the problem. I don't think any films are scary and I never have. Fear is just not an emotion I can get from films.Like the 1963 film, the focus here is on Eleanor (Lili Taylor). The premise is basically the same, if some of the details have been changed. An academic researcher, Dr. David Morrow (Liam Neeson), wants to study the fear response, especially as it relates to group interaction. Morrow poses a ruse to get research subjects. He says he's going to be doing an insomnia study. He draws a few participants, including Eleanor, Theo (Catherine Zeta-Jones) and Luke (Owen Wilson), to a huge old mansion--more like a palace--called "Hill House". He invents a story based on the true one (per the film's world) about the history of Hill House and plants the juiciest details with Luke, along with an instruction to keep quiet about it lest he scare Theo and Eleanor. Of course, Luke blabs, and soon afterward, spooky things begin happening. But is Dr. Morrow behind the strange occurrences or is there really something supernatural going on at Hill House? What will happen if the participants discover the truth behind Dr. Morrow's experiment? And why does Dr. Morrow, or whoever is behind the "haunting", appear to be picking on Eleanor? Director Jan de Bont gives strong nods to the original film in the remake's script, and he even goes so far as to recreate performances, specific shots and sequences. The strongest recreation of a performance is a minor one--Marian Seldes' Mrs. Dudley, who delivers the infamous speech about the "rules" of the house and her and her husband's caretaking habits with almost identical dialogue and intonation as Rosalie Crutchley's Mrs. Dudley in Wise's film. But all of the principal cast members are directed to give performances close in tone and disposition to those in the original. Sequences such as Eleanor and Theo running to each other as they experience strange sounds and something trying to enter their rooms are almost identical to the original, with de Bont taking great care to block infamous shots so that they're the same as the beloved Wise film. Other sequences, such as the sudden presence of cold, are changed in structure a bit, but retain the spirit of Wise. This is all evidence that despite the reputation of the de Bont film, it is much closer in tone--even with its strong emphasis on things only heard or glimpsed out of the corner of one's eye--to the Wise film than almost anyone admits.Of course, this version of The Haunting does have differences. De Bont was not shooting for a Gus Van Sant-styled recreation, ala Psycho (1998), after all. De Bont dispenses with Eleanor's narration (which I've always found annoying in the original), shoots in color, and goes bonkers on production design, cinematography and yes, special effects and CGI. Personally, I prefer going bonkers on production design and cinematography. On both of those ends, The Haunting easily deserves a 10. The sets are breathtaking, beautiful, bizarre and stunningly shot--the exterior of the house, too. I also like the special effects and CGI, but it may be important to remember that I'm not someone looking primarily for realism in films. To me, it's absurd to watch a film about the supernatural expecting realism, anyway. But that's because in real life, I'm a skeptic on all of this stuff. To me, this is a fantasy, as is the Wise film, and I welcome fantastical, surreal (read "non-realistic") imagery.However, unlike the first time watching the remake, I felt that The Haunting had flaws this time around. Maybe I didn't notice them in the theater because I was so floored by the beautiful visuals projected larger than life. The problem is that the story and the dialogue become gobbledy-gooky. There are a lot of non-sequiturs in the plot. Characters disappear for arbitrary lengths of time. Eleanor figures out mysteries that should require complicated sleuth-work without much information to the viewer about how she did it. Characters say things to each other that seem like necessary foundational exposition was edited out. On the other hand, the Wise film wasn't exactly free of these problems, either.And the focus here isn't primarily on a tightly woven story in the vein of a mystery flick, anyway. The focus is on atmosphere--a rich tapestry of visuals and sound, where the actors are just one element, all meant to evoke moods. The film tends to be more poetic in this regard. Viewed that way, it succeeds.

Review title: This is not a horror movie, but it's very entertaining.
Review_body: That said, I loved it.  Had me glued to the screen the entire time.  I'd barely looked at the watch.  Horror fans, this isn't gonna scare you.  Don't look at it as a horror movie per se.  The problem we see here is whether it's a horror movie or just a movie that is creepy.  It's just your classic haunted house movie.  Original no.  But I personally loved it.  If you've ever played the Sierra video game Phantasmagoria (7 cd roms long) as it is an interactive movie, you'll simply love this movie.  I also appreciated the fact that whomever designed the pan/scan version took it upon themselves and preserved some integrity of the film by putting 1 particularly widescreen moment in the film along with a smaller, but equally just widescreen towards the end of the film.  Aspect wise, I think people are still confused with widescreen.  They would call us purists I suppose, but movies are meant to be shown in widescreen.  Widescreen is not like those rip off panaramic shots used by Camera's.  (those who have used it know what I mean)  I think it was wise that they used that widescreen shot in the movie to show what difference it could make.  Pan/scan versions are cropped and destroy the movies integrity.  Some movies are shot in good and poor widescreen, but one this is for sure.  Get ready for HDTV..... :)

Warning: may contain some spoilers.But this film has been spoiled.  This film was terrible.  I was so looking forward to The Haunting.  But once again film makers forget what is so obvious to the rest of us, that it is disgusting and repulsive, and that is the fact that very few people know how to make a terrifying film.  Very few people understand the craft and skill behind it.  Because I can honestly count on two hands the films that scared me, or at least left me filled with tension.  So in the history of film there has been about 1000 horror movies made and I have probably seen about 3/4 of them, how come only ten or so can truly scare?  The reason is because most film makers know that a scary film has to have atmoshphere, tension, a good script, perhaps music, lighting or lack thereof ( Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Blair Witch Project ) and a director who knows how to use the camera so that it uses us.  The Haunting has none of that.  The Haunting is filled with lots of loud noises, a non scary entity that shows itself at the end of the film, possessed statues, sheets that move by themselves and every other trick that should make a film like this good.  But what it needs it better camera work, even a little bit of tension and hey, how about a scare or two.  The Haunting contains none of that.  This is one of the biggest disappointments of the summer.  So here is my advice to Jan DeBont.  Whoever directed the trailer, get some pointers from them.  And get Linda Hunt to do some voice over work for the film as well, she had me glued to my seat with anticipation in the trailer ( these are its eyes ).  It's funny too, because Jan De Bont was a DP before he hit it big with Speed.  And one of the films that he was DP for was Cujo.  Now Cujo was a good horror film, not the best, but pretty good.  It's too bad that he couldn't learn from someone even like Lewis Teague, because any effort besides this one would have been better.  This is a disgrace to horror films and even as a film itself it is terrible.  You want to be scared this summer?  Go see Blair Witch and Sixth Sense.  You want to waste two hours?  Go see The Haunting!

The first half or so of the movie is not bad at all. Interesting characters, intriguing premise, engaging storytelling. Even the thing about the kids make you want to know what's behind it all.The latter half of the movie is as disappointing as it could possibly be. The characterization (incl. some promising innuendo) is utterly abandoned, the story doesn't really go anywhere, it's boring, and nothing of what we want to know is actually revealed. The movie begins fine, and then ends as a mess so bad it isn't even ridiculous. It's tragic. (This is, by the way, the exact same problem Thir13en Ghosts had: a set-up, but an incoherent ending that fizzled out into nothingness.)The actors suffer under that same malady. It's not their fault that they don't get to develop their characters in the second half of the movie. Zeta-Jones is drop-dead gorgeous as always, and Lili Taylor is also interesting and appealing. Liam Neeson's heart is never in it (and who can blame him?), and Owen Wilson, well, he's never an asset to any movie, in my opinion.I give The Haunting 5 out of 10. And that's generous.

Review title: Worth looking at. Must dispose the script.
Review_body: My Take: A triumph of style over substance. Many critics hate this remake of Robert Wise's classic haunted house movie because, they say, that it has little resemblance to Shirley Jackson's classic story, which it was based on. Well, the film does overemphasize the special-effects to produce thrills rather than story or the use of imagination. The film stops being Shirley Jackson's subtle haunted house story when the film itself becomes a haunted house. Well, the story does tell about a group of paranormal investigators daring themselves to live inside the old Hill House and find its mysterious remnants. But they, instead, discover a mysterious legacy of evil. The film was directed by "Twister"'s Jan De Bont, so expect it to have a lot of special-effects and a famous lead cast, save the subtlety and psychological punch of the story. What story? Screenwriter David Self leaves it to De Bont and the parade of special effects to tell the story, as if the thing never needed the screenplay. Still, THE HAUNTING is more of a second round on Disneyland's The Haunted Mansion rather than a redo of the Shirley Jackson story. The lack of imagination to tell the story is made up by the imagination used to put it on screen. The special effects leave very little to our imagination, but it's as if a large amount of imagination used to create them. Eugenio Zanetti is the real star of the show, making Hill House a triumph of style and the stuff of nightmares. All this and more, save the messed-up screenplay and uneven use of its popular cast (Owen Wilson as a paranormal investigator?), make THE HAUNTING a worthwhile, but not necessary, diversion. Rating: *** out 5.

I liked this movie. It seemed to be a throw back to the Hitchcockian type of horror/suspense movies where the writers and acting left a lot of the scary stuff to the viewers imagination. Until the last 30-40 minutes when they got way to weird with the special effects and the CGI's. I did figure out that the carved kids faces represented the dead children but I did not know he was the killer until it was explained. Liam Neeson's doctor character seems to be rather unethical in doing a study without the patients knowledge or permission. Owen Wilson was not that impressive in this movie. Zet-Jones acted a bit strange in her role almost like she was not fully committed to it. While Lili Taylor only got fourth billing her character is really the main one that everything ends up revolving around. The special effects with the children's faces were a little wooden (pun intended) but also kind of interesting. Will I own this movie? No. Will I watch it on TV again? More than likely.

Review title: Has anyone who voted seen the same movie I have????
Review_body:
Come on people, the average vote here and the word of mouth on the internet make you think this one sucks. So do all the Razzie nominations. I thought it would suck too, BUT, I rented it anyways, and I was NOT disappointed. Didn't regret a minute.
This is really a good flick. It has a good story, a good cast ,in which Lili Taylor and Catherine Zeta Jones (damn she's hot, wish I was Michael Douglas) stand out, the rest of the cast is OK. Taylor as the 'psycho' and Jones as a BISEXUAL (I believed it, then again I'm a guy). The effects and the music are great, the combination of the two really excited me and had me sitting on the edge of my couch (seat). Good direction too, no doubt as the effects and music made it an entertaining and exciting movie. It was not that creepy though, but still good entertainment. Now for the downsides of this flick, well there are actually no more than two or three: 1: Where does Taylor get the stuff she's saying from about family and so on. 2: I do not understand THE CALL (you'll know what I meant with these first two, after you saw this movie) 3: Ending is a bit vague.Take my advice, ignore everyone elses opinion and see this one, or look at how much money it made (pretty much I daresay), that says something too, you know
8 out of 10

The setup was creepy, cast members reliable, production values remarkable. Too bad director Jan De Bont is to horror what garlic is to vampires.An adaptation in name and general premise only, the Haunting has doctor Marrow (Liam Neeson) invite patients Nell (Lily Taylor), Theo (Catherine Zeta-Jones) and Luke (Owen Wilson) - plus other two who leave after a minute - to Hill House, an isolated mansion, for a psychological study about fear. It soon becomes clear the house is haunted and the group in danger."Some house are born bad", recites the ominous tagline; to this I may add "and so are some movies". De Bont, who did a competent job with a fast-paced action movie like Speed, is unable to craft a sinister atmosphere, relying instead on the patented "whispering children" shtick and on cheesy CGI ghosts; the psychological terror of Shirley Jackson's novel becomes subpar horror schlock. Too bad, because production design at least did a commendable job: the set for Hill House looks effective, a humongous, tasteless, unsettling Gothic manor. Even a magnetic actor like Neeson seems bored. Taylor starts well enough as the vulnerable Nell but then lapses into histrionics. Others aren't given much to do, with Wilson as the comic relief and Zeta-Jones as the eye candy (sadly, no Entrapment-like tight jumpsuits here).The Haunting has plot holes so big you could drive a truck through them, a sign of blatant disrespect towards the audience. My favorite is how the survivors at the end don't bother to mention to the returning caretakers that THERE IS A BEHEADED CORPSE IN THE CHIMNEY. I guess they are in for a rather unpleasant surprise - just like viewers.5/10

Review title: A Step-up And A Step-down Remake
Review_body: I have yet to read the novel by Shirley Jackson, but I have to assume that this remake covers all the material left out of the original that would have gone so far to explain the house's history and idiosyncrasies. The effects are very good, but they aren't very scary or likely in the boundaries of true haunted houses.Lili Taylor's performance takes back stage to Catherine Zeta-Jones which is quite the opposite of the original and does obviously impair the movie's likeability. Liam Neeson is rather distant to the character and events, and Owen Wilson is quite annoying as he tries to copy the original role set forward by Russ Tamblyn. The house, however, takes centerstage as the special effects take over the storyline midway through the movie. Complaints aside, this is a very good if not excellant movie. It ends rather on a confused edge, but thankfully, it does not try to copy the original.

The saying "less is more" worked very well for the 1963 original film. If you want to see a good, genuinely scary ghost story, see the original. If you want to see how much FX stuff tinseltown can throw into a ghost movie, see this.  Like STAR WARS I: THE PHANTOM MENACE, this film has lots of razzle-dazzle, but little story. The remake relies on every ghost story cliché (groaning doors, cold winds, phantom noises, visions) done with the all the latest FX.  But the original bw film created mood, atmosphere, and suspense much more effectively with fewer, not greater, FX and with characters who actually developed a plot.  Since TITANIC, the rule seems to be FX. Too bad that plot and character get buried. "Some houses are born bad" says the film's ad. I didn't know houses were born. But movies are -- and the ad could just as well say, "Some films are born bad." This one is an example. To pick up on a few lines in the film, I'd conclude that the movie can be described this way -- Charles Foster Kane meets Charles Addams in the FX department late at night.

Review title: Boring film that doesn't even try to be scary
Review_body:
The Haunting is a remake of an already subpar horror film and you might have some expectations for this film to be better than the original. In reality it is even worse than the original.A psychiatrist invites three subjects for an insomnia study at an old mansion called Hill House . Unbeknownst to them he actually is conducting an experiment on fear and plans on making them believe that the house is haunted. The only catch is, that Hill House really is haunted.
Liam Neeson,Catherine Zeta Jones and Owen Wilson are all very watchable however the lead,Lili Taylor, is terrible and one of the major flaws of the movie.The majority of the movie includes very few scares and saves everything till the climactic third act so to speak. However, there is nothing in the picture that can be remotely frightening. The faces on the wall and such is a novel concept but it fails to be even mildly creepy. The giant ghoul at the end is comical and is 'defeated' in a deus ex machina style. And can someone please enlighten me how Nell died(with a classic head tilt)? The shots of the 'children's' sacred expressions are downright cartoonish and deplete any little drama there is.The production design for this film are definetly some of its redeaming qualities such as the hall of mirrors which along with a line about Charles Foster Kane, certainly feels like a nod to Orson Welles.The Haunting is an incredibly boring,ridiculous film that doesn't even try to be frightening.

Critics' pans aside I love this remake. It has its own flavor of this story. This is a much more visual version than the original. The cherubs on the wall are so emotive, they actually scared me for a sec. This is the second version of Shirley Jackson's fab story about an anthropologist trying to prove the afterlife in a notorious old mansion. In order to do so he invites certain types to spend the night. High-jinks ensue.

Review title: May the ghost of Shirley Jackson haunt those who perpetrated this CGI crap-fest.
Review_body: The Haunting Of Hill House is one of the finest ghost stories ever written. Subtle and brilliantly crafted by someone who understood the psychological underpinnings of horror, Robert Wise's original 1963 film is a largely faithful, extremely well-made and atmospheric version of the novel.And then there's this.Everything that made the novel claustrophobic, compelling, frightening, and darkly elegiac has gone, replaced by relentless Caspar The Friendly Ghost-style CGI, bad acting and an appalling screenplay which bears no resemblance to the book whatsoever, apart from using the names of the characters and the same basic situation.This awful melange of steaming horse dung is a wonderful example of the direness of a lot of modern film-making. Bereft of skillful story construction and suspense-building - in fact bereft of story construction and suspense of any kind - this is what you get when the audience gets lazy and will watch any pile of old tripe.I really can't relate how bad this film is - like Van Helsing it occupies a place all its own. The actors should be ashamed to have taken money to appear in it.Do yourself a favour, read Mrs. Jackson's book or see Robert Wise's film instead.

The Haunting is an extremely creative and interesting film that could well have been amazing if pulled off correctly.The film boasts a good cast with: Catherine Zeta-Jones, Lili Taylor, Owen Wilson and Liam Neeson. They all do quite a convincing and good job in their role and help give the scenes some life they overwise might not have had with different actors. Each character is very unique and has good personality traits.The plot is quite average but where the film really stands out is the fantastic art direction and ridiculously gothic mansion. The mansion is one of the greatest fictional architectural moments I've ever seen in film and is extremely rich with detail and dark. The soundtrack is also a point for praise, it has some really good tracks which are used well to set the scene. The house is really its own character. Furthermore, there are some very interesting story elements regarding the history of the house, such as the owner (the ghostly Hugh Crain) taking children from his textile mills and murdering them, stuffing their bones under the fireplace so as to have a family for all eternity. Spooky7/10: A good gothic horror, overlook its flaws and you're in for a treat

Review title: Tell better stories! Why is that hard to figure out?
Review_body: This movie upon first impression leaves this reviewer asking, " Did I do something to mess this up? Was it me?" Only after a second viewing does it becomes apparent that it's the movie's fault. This is a remake of a 1963 movie that was itself a poor poor adaptation of the Shirley Jackson masterpiece The Haunting Of Hill House- if you haven't read it, the book is like a modern day epic poem as a tale of horror. Certainly the 1963 film adaptation fell short, and this version manages to fall short of the '63, that's a big empty space of a difference between The Haunting (1999) and the book. The book is classic, the movie is lowest common denominator over-the-top Hollywood psychopathy on display. You would have made more money if you just did a film version of the book- good stories are eternal, special effects are forgotten.

Review title: Some scary material and an involving plot makes this one work only by a bare minimum. *** out of ****
Review_body: THE HAUNTING (1999) ***After viewing much of Jan de Bont 's screen credits I begin to notice a typical technique in his direction. His film's usually begin with a solid plot development and end with a spectacular denouement. Through the middle of his movies is where more of the problems come to mind. Most of the time, the characters just complicate the plot issues more, and mostly don't further the plot any. Remember "Twister" and "Speed 2?" All this holds true for most of Jan de Bont, including the new version of the Shirley Jackson horror novel, The Haunting of Hill House, called "The Haunting.""The Haunting" does work, and compared to most of the other summer horror flops out there today ("Lake Placid," "Deep Blue Sea," "The Mummy" etc.) it is a true, horror provoking gem. But the film only succeeds by a bare minimum. It is like someone passing high school with a 74% when a 74% is allowed. I liked the movie's overall production, and much of its scary material. I found myself studding the characters, trying to understand the message, struggling to figure out the plot before it is revealed to us--in other words I was very involved in Bont's storytelling, but only enough to marginally recommend.The film opens with an experimental study of sleep deprivation by the mysterious Dr. Marrow, who takes his four patients, including Theo, a bisexual, Eleanor, a woman going into debut and Luke, a comical jokester, to a massive, antique mansion in the middle of nowhere to observe. Secretly he is conduction a study of fear in which he will tell the patients scary stories only for them to fill in the rest. During one of the screenplay's bad moments, the fourth volunteer in injured by a piano string and his carried off to somewhere else, That woman as no idea how lucky she was.At night time, the patients hear things that are frightening. The gather up, and investigate, only to find nothing. The house, called Hill House, is enough to give the boldest of beings a chill, but what the characters see and hear will make you shiver.As it turns out, Hill House has a past to die for and is haunted by spirits of children who are pleading to escape from a demon who has wickedly fathered them for many, many years, and plans on doing it forever. Eleanor turns out to have more to do with this story, and discovers secrets that turn her to believe that she is a great relative of the late children's mother, who killed herself when her husband drove her crazy.Structurally, "The Haunting" is passable, but characteristically, it is greatly flawed. Movies like this the audience needs some action, beyond psychological terror, too keep them interested. The way to do this is to have a cast member be killed in the process. We like to know what were upagainst, here, and the way to do that is to see how and what is killing the it's victims. But "The Haunting" doesn't have enough characters to pick off one by one. For instance, the piano string incidence, the character hurt and taken away, before the story ever develops, going from six characters to four. And they all have big names and play important roles in the film. So, who is the house going to kill? See what we're up against, here. There aren't enough central characters for the film to have fun with, therefore all we receive is instance after instance of noises, threats and scary music.However, the film does take itself seriously and has a lot of thrills in its plot, after the first hour of plot development is over. One more thing, however. The film has earned a PG-13 rating, and while I have always made it a point never to judge a movie on it's content or rating, I have to complain about this one. I am reminded of the 1996 horror comedy called "The Frighteners" which earned an R rating for terror/violence, the same reason "The Haunting" got a PG-13. But this film is much more adult in its subject matter. Much more tense in its storytelling. And much more seriously violent than the other movie, which scored a higher rating. My point: the MPAA has goofed up again. Little kids do not need to be seeing movie about evil spirits and hell. So do not be fooled by the rating, this is not a film for the very young of age.

Review title: I'm Haunted by how bad it was
Review_body: A re-telling of the classic haunted house flic from 1963 (based on Shirley Jackson's famous novel), this was criticized for being nothing but non-stop special FX. In this day and age, that's no surprise. The makers here obviously attempted the ultimate haunted house epic. We are privy to view some of the most opulent sets ever conceived; some of the rooms are larger by themselves than what an average house is sized at (some of this impressive set design may lose its impact on the small screen). Neeson is the researcher investigating causes of fear who invites a trio of insomniacs to this gigantic house under false pretenses. The house has a sad, evil history, the focus of which is lost under the weight of innumerable FX shots in the 2nd half. The house-spirits focus on the character played by Taylor, a social outcast who spent many years caring for an ailing mother. Plot revelations concerning her relationship to the house seem contrived & unnecessary, adding to a messy ending (also, a character's death is just ridiculous: how about just ...stepping out of the way?). Zeta-Jones is suitably great to look at. I get the impression of filmmakers given unlimited funds to realize a glorious vision and completely forgetting the main purpose of the whole project: making it scary. Yeah, yeah, OK, it's an impressive looking house - now what about the fear? As Jeff Goldblum might say - 'Now, we are going to see some scary things in this haunted house, right? Hm..? Hello? Hello?'

Review title: This film will haunt me for the rest of my life
Review_body: I'm genuinely in disgust at how bad that was. I normally like to write a lot about the film and talk about the actors and the scenes I liked. But firstly there was no good scenes, each scene was worse then the last. Secondly all the actors were crap and painful to watch. Writing a big review is a waste of my time just like the film.

I don't know how many movies i've seen that start out well but end like a train-wreck. Quite a lot of movies, i can tell you that. And still this is one of the worst i've seen.Dr. Marrow (Liam Neeson) have a newspaper ad out looking for people to participate in a study about sleeping disorders. But in secret he is really doing an experiment about fear and how it affects people. Soon though it becomes apparent that the house he has chosen for his study has more than planned to offer in the ways of fear.The cast of "The Haunting" is maybe not excellent, but it does contain a lot of famous names. The budget and premise also seems perky. And yet this turns into a crap-fest before long. How did this happen? In my opinion it's mostly due to the fact that the director and script-writers know nothing about the elements of good horror film.They seem to be completely ignorant when it comes to the concept "subtle horror" and "chilling moments". Instead we are treated to a special effects-extravaganza. It starts out rather well with a house that looks simply amazing. The art direction is excellent to say the least. But soon the movie derails completely and the special effects take over. I even get the feeling of a Disney-musical sometimes when the furniture and the whole house seems to start moving. Just add the carnival music and you would have a decent live-action "Beauty and the beast". Seriously this is just too much. Instead of creeping horror they opt for shock-effects, which is almost always the wrong way to go. And it shows here.This is just another movie that shows that special effects can never replace a decent script. I rate it 4/10.

Review title: Silly me, I thought this was supposed to be a scary movie.
Review_body:
Eh. That's basically what I felt like when I left The Haunting. I was glad that they decided to play it as a straight thriller with little comedy, but it just wasn't all that scary.Liam Neeson wants to do a study on fear. So he gets a group of people together under the guise of an insomnia study, in order to scare them and see how they react. The group starts off as 6, but within a few seconds, two of them leave and are never heard from again. Did anyone else find that odd? Introduce two characters, send them off, and then never speak of them again? How long does it take to get some stitches? Unless they were the ones that were supposed to do the scaring, but I don't remember that being mentioned either. Anyway... After a while one of the house guests (Lili Taylor) discovers a hidden secret within the walls and rooms of Hill House. And that secret isn't very happy about being found out. So the house attacks the guests and all hell breaks loose. Literally at one point.
The movie moves along very slowly. It kind of reminded me of what I've seen of The Shining in that way. Of course this movie wasn't nearly as good. It just moved along slowly, trying to build the suspense. But to be honest, I didn't really care what happened to these people. I was actually hoping one would die to make things interesting. One did die, but it took way too long for it to happen (although the death was quite exciting). The story about why the house is upset was a little convoluted. A second wife? I must have missed something. I did love the sets though. The house itself was quite amazing. Just looking at it and trying to imagine myself living there was frightening. But there were way too many hallways. I never got a real feel about where the rooms were in relation to each other. The acting was ok. Taylor takes a leap from her indie roots to try and make it in the mainstream, and does a credible job. She was just held down by a few awful pieces of dialogue. Owen Wilson seemed out of place around these actors. He never really got into the feel of the film. Zeta-Jones played her role well, but if there was supposed to be a small lesbian sub-plot, it was very very small, too bad. And Liam Neeson has never been one of my favorites for some reason. And he lived up to those expectations.So overall, there were a few chills and thrills, but too few to make it very exciting. The special effects were somewhat different and done very well, but in this age, I need a little more than cool special effects. How about a coherent story and some real frights? If you're looking for a good scare, I'd put my money on the Blair Witch.

This movie may have the highest contrast ever between cast members I would normally expect to excel in just about any context, and results that reduce even them to complete mediocrity that any collection of second-rate TV actors could have managed. I mean really, what a waste. It's not even a fun piece of junk, it's a shrill, overblown, irritating one that completely blows the psychological nuance and atmospherics of the original, and does not replace it with effective more-explicit scares. Like everybody else, I loved De Bont's directorial debut "Speed," but it's pretty amazing how quickly he lost the knack. This stale popcorn flick is one good proof that sometimes the more money you throw at a project, the more likely it is choke on that cash. It's too overbearing even to be a guilty pleasure.

The Haunting is a film that boasts a really creepy house, good effects work and sound work, a cast that seems to believe that everything around them is real and that house.  There are scenes that make you jump, and the sinister aspects of what went on at Hill House in the past, I found interesting. There are genuinely creepy moments in the film and I liked the way the ghosts manifested themselves in sheets, curtains and the house itself. Jerry Goldsmith's score gave it the right atmosphere and the sound design had voices popping up around you.  What I wish could've happened is for something a little more intense.  Jan De Bont had a PG-13 rating to contend with and I think that he held back a little too much.  Poltergeist scared me silly when I saw it many years ago, and it still holds up.  The Haunting could've used a few more scenes of pure terror.   The ending was for me, a little anticlimactic.  Overall, I enjoyed it.  The acting is good and there are moments that make you jump.  I just wish it scared me more.

While being a Horror freak, I'm still only 27 years of age, so I guess I wasn't here for many of what others might call "classics". I wasn't even aware this movie was a remake before checking IMDb. Now that I've finished watching it, I remember that I saw it around 13 years ago with some friends in Junior High. I also recall not losing sleep over it even at 14.From an older and more experienced point of you - this movie isn't scarier than the witched in Disney's older animated pictures. The story might have been original before too many films used the same idea of a bunch of strangers arriving on an old haunted manor for this reason or another.Lili Taylor (main protagonist Nell) might be many things, but she's no actress. Her acting was so amateur and childish, it was like seeing a 5 year old playing pretend... the rest of the all-star set was luckily better. Catherine Zeta-Jones was exciting and sexy as city-girl Theo, Owen Wilson was as funny and charismatic as always, and Liam Neeson was a perfect choice for the role of Dr. Marrow.The children's "ghosts' were a nice touch, but the main ghost was quite a let-down. Nothing scary in this one... I'd say this film would be good for children who're about to become teenagers and would like to ease their way into the horror genre. However, for us adult audience - this film was nothing more than a waste of time.

It's rare you find a remake better than the original & this is that rare case!! I am not a fan of remakes but something about this movie made me change my mind & glad I did. The acting is very good, location & effects are as well!! Those that have giving this movie bad reviews are the ones that don't understand it!! I'm not going to give spoilers or anything because you need to see this for yourself!! Don't let others scare you off!!

The ghosts look like casper. Even the deadliest ghost at the end does not manage to scare. Even actors like Liam Neeson and Owen Wilson look out of place. The dialogue is totally cringe-worthy. It is an opportunity lost . I usually never criticize a movie and I am the one always appreciates the good parts in a movie. The only good factor in this movie was Catherine Zeta Jones . She looks hot. She has the oomph factor and I could just keep looking at her in all her scenes. Lily Taylor gives out an honest performance in her meatiest role but the cringe worthy special effects ruin the movie's experience. The actors act well in a few scenes and their expressions may scare us but as soon as the loud music and the cringe worthy special effects take over, you are left laughing unintentionally.

I must be special. After reading comments on this film, I realize I must be somewhat retarded when it comes to horror flicks, because I actually thought this film was fairly good. Not astounding, but certainly chilling. I loved the way the ghosts were merely suggested or roughly visible. I liked the house and I liked the idea. I just wanted to say this.What was lacking was a clearer story. The Eleanor character is way to loosely defined to make a lasting impression, and when the explanation comes it is surprisingly naive and feels like a cheap way to bring closure to the mystery.

Review title: Not as good as the original
Review_body: Some films just simply should not be remade. This is one of them. In and of itself it is not a bad film. But it fails to capture the flavor and the terror of the 1963 film of the same title. Liam Neeson was excellent as he always is, and most of the cast holds up, with the exception of Owen Wilson, who just did not bring the right feel to the character of Luke. But the major fault with this version is that it strayed too far from the Shirley Jackson story in it's attempts to be grandiose and lost some of the thrill of the earlier film in a trade off for snazzier special effects. Again I will say that in and of itself it is not a bad film. But you will enjoy the friction of terror in the older version much more.

Review title: Not the best, but I thought it was decent
Review_body: Like House on Haunted Hill that came out the same year as this, I'd never seen the original. It got me curious about a mansion with a shadowy past and a group of people working in an experiment conducted by a somewhat mad doctor. The special effects were a bit overdone and weren't that impressive but the visuals of the whole house were interesting. If I had to pick the best part of this whole movie, it would be the soundtrack. Chilling yet beautiful. I wish I could say the same thing about the movie itself.

This film is really, really bad.  It's god-awful horrible.  Do not, under any circumstances, see this film.  Given the choice between having my toenails pulled out with pliers, and watching "The Haunting," I'd have to flip a coin.  It is badly written, badly acted, and horribly directed by a man who should really go back to dropping cars from the sky (Speed, Twister).This is a B-Movie not at all disguised as a high-budget piece of trash. I'm sure I've seen the exact same script, with a budget of fifty bucks, starring 2 ugly guys and 2 Playboy Playmates who walk around topless the entire movie.  The premise makes no sense, the motivations of the characters make LESS sense, every character is present or absent from scenes at random, based on who showed up to work that day.  The ending makes no sense either-- the characters who die, die for no reason at all, other than it makes for another stupid, extremely expensive special effect.This movie works on NO level and I fail to see how any sane human being could find a single enjoyable thing about it.  "House on Haunted Hill" was scary.  This is a skinflick with all the skin edited out, it's about as scary as a walk to your mailbox.  1/10, *ONLY* because this website won't let me vote any lower.

Belated Day 16 Of My 31 Days Of Horror.This film is about a group of people played by Owen Wilson Catherine Zeta Jones and Liam Neeson spending the night in a house that contains sprirts.That is the story and this is a poor film. Jan De Bont slipped through the cracks after Speed. This film has poor special effects lousy acting and a terrible interpretation of the original classic. I don't even want to spend a lot of time on a film that does not deserve my own time.Rated PG-13 For Intense Horror Sequences.1hr 53min/113mins.BOMB/****

Review title: The spooky house concept is used to moderate effect.
Review_body:
While it is far from being a bad movie, `The Haunting' is still unsatisfying in a few aspects. While the cast works well and the storyline is amusing, it doesn't let out its intended effect. The spookiness and disturbance seems very artificial and doesn't seem to flow naturally in the film. While the storyline itself is plain freaky, what the film delivers is something on a much lower note unfortunately. `The Haunting' takes on many of the usual horror clichés but, in this films case, it is used to its advantage.
Luckily, its small but likeable cast makes up for most of the flaws. Lili Taylor takes on the lead role and is adequate for the part. She is ably supported by the more experienced Liam Neeson. He is a welcome addition to the film and makes it all the more watchable. Owen Wilson is equally impressive and likeable as a super cynic and cocky show-off. The most colourful and developed of the cast, though, is Catherine Zeta-Jones as a flamboyant over-the-top bisexual. The fact that her character is bisexual is a blatant draw for the male audience but she does a good job in her role, even though. The only other problem with the film is the resorting to shoddy computer images at the end of the movie (the same problem was in the similarly themed `House on Haunted Hill'). As if the scares weren't disappointing enough as they were, the CGI didn't help matters one bit. Nonetheless, some genuine scares come out of the film among the rest of the dross.
The performances and likeabilty of the film fortunately overshadow the evident flaws, making `The Haunting' a general success. The formula and moderate blandness prevent it from being anything above good but you have a satisfying movie despite this. 6.2/10.

Review title: .If you are into suspense and a good scare this is a good one.
Review_body: The movie is about a study in fear. I was reading  Leonard Maltin's review, and he seems to state there were "virtually no scares" in the movie.  I was really scared. Perhaps people are getting desensitized because the movies are getting more and more graphic, more special effects, more deaths, more explosions. I think that what made Hitchcock's movies scary was what your mind put into the movie; suggestive, not graphic. I will not watch movies that will bring fear to my mind. My husband picked this one and we watched it together. I though it was just as scary as  "The Shining."  As far as scary goes it gets a ten on my fear scale. If you are into suspense and a good scare this is a good one.

Dr Marrow enlists Theo, Luke and Nell for a study of sleep disorders at the Hill House. As soon as the terrifying truth about the mansion is revealed, everyone is found fighting for their lives.I had watched "The Haunting" years ago and I'd almost completely forgotten the movie entirely. I revisited the film recently and I thought it was a brilliantly entertaining and well-made picture. The location of Hill House is a fantastic setting for the story and they use the location stunningly well, from the first sweeping shots of the four leads arriving there to the dramatic conclusion. Based on its locations, its sets, its art direction, its sound design, and the overall splendour of its visuals, the film is some of the best I think I've ever seen in the genre. Creating a haunted house with real personality and terror.The cast of the film is also fantastic. Lili Taylor without a doubt pulls out a riveting performance as Elanor. Catherine Zeta-Jones brings the sex appeal. Owen Wilson keeps the film light and humorous whilst Liam Neeson plays the medium between the group, the character-based moments at the start of the film are even interesting and the dialogue is smart and snappy.The story is an interesting spin on the original, with the message that love is the only true antidote to fear. I know lots and lots of people hate this film but I just found so much to love about it I couldn't help but disagree.

Review title: Don't believe anybody in this movie I saw the original...
Review_body: --SPOILER ALERT--THE HAUNTING from 1963 holds my title for most frightening film ever made, and I figured to make a good remake the director should minimize the special effects to zero, and go for great suspense, mind-scares and some frightening production design.It makes no sense, the first hour tries to be a remake of the original, the second hour explodes to some kind of fun-house. The reason I hate this movie so much is a lot because I love the '63-version. Everything in it was right. I was scared to death, and it didn't have any effects, gore or action. From the start to finish it was a scare. I was afraid that this would be a step-by-step-remake like the Gus Van Sant-PSYCHO, but now I wish it at least was. Every reason why the original was scary has been wiped out and replaced by an anti-scare. The movie starts with Nell getting a phone call with a "tip" to look in the phone book to find an ad for insomnia-problem. Who this is, buy the way, never gets revealed, even though Dr.Marrow claims it wasn't him. In the first THE HAUNTING we quickly catch up sympathy with Nell, sharing her thoughts and memories from the past, and we are filled with horror when she aproach Hill House, the house stares at her and it feels as if she has been eaten by a monster when she is in it. In the remake it is the total opposite. We don't feel anything for her and since the house doesn't look scary at all she loves it, why? Because it is beautiful!!! Did the filmmakers notice that the house is supposed to be scary?Also Mrs.Dudley is a complete disaster. OK, so I might be a little too demanding but I think that she was the thing that told us in the first movie that "there is something wrong about this place". Her presense was cold and stiff and the way she says "in the dark... in the night" and suddenly smiles, when she's been totally numb in her face all along made me shiver. Here the way SHE says "in the dark... in the night" sounds like she's been studying the script a million times and is death tired of the line, not aware of that it is one of the most important lines in the movie.Casting Jones to play Theo was a pretty good choice, but the character is too annoying, jumping around like a schoolgirl, when she is supposed to be cool and ms.ESP as Luke so elegantly puts it in the original movie. The good thing about Luke in that classic is that he don't believe in the supernatural. Here we don't really know if he does, since Dr.Marrow don't care. He's not out to investigate the supernatural, he's out to investigate fear. Too dull to be true. Therefore the entire "Hugh Crain-story" is changed to a much more flat and un-interesting one.  And as you might know the main rule about THE HAUNTING is broken. The movie is filled with over-the-top special effects, when the original's essence was that it didn't have any. Well, I guess it's the American Way.I guess they can't make a movie about a haunted house that won't contain greased effects and blood and gore, they simply just have to kill someone. I thought it was a good idea to set in two extra passangers to Hill House... until a harp-string flies off and wip her across the eye and she and the other guy drive back to the city. And Luke actually gets his head chopped off! Since when did ghosts start to kill people?Everything good about the '63 version is missing in this version.  3/10

Review title: Both deep and scary as Hell - but suffers from the comparison
Review_body: The big disadvantage with a remake, is the fact that one always compares it with the original. For this reason, I think the movie-makers should stop making remakes, and try to find some fresh new stories instead. All the fantastic special effects in this film, for instance, should have made a perfect horror movie somewhere else. But now, I could just think that they are trying to compensate for the perfect psychology and understated creeping horror in the original, by throwing in a lot of expensive technology instead.They also missed one important thing in this film: Eleanor should have been attracted to one of the men, and the other woman, who was beautiful and self-assured, should have stolen him in front of her eyes. For this was an important psychological turn-point in the original: Eleanor realized once and for all, that she had no hope of love, family or belonging in the world outside... And why should the other woman be bisexual, suddenly? - that did not add anything meaningful to the story.However, in both movies I find the basic story very sad, convincing and realistic. I think many lonely women - "old maids" - can relate to it. In reality, they often turn to religion to find communion with both the parish and the supernatural beings (God, Jesus, angels...) - that do not demand beauty, style, charm or social skills, but are there for everyone.In this story, it is only more extreme. Eleanor is so lonely and unhappy, that she is not even afraid of ghosts manifesting themselves anymore. Because she sees them as as a possibility of company, family at last! And she sacrifices her mortal life entirely, to become one of the ghosts in the haunted mansion (in the original), which is the only place where she ever feels that she has _belonged_, or sets them free and follows them to heaven (in this remake).

I watched this on Amazon video near Halloween. It started off interesting but owen Wilson has to be the most annoying person ever and totally ruined the spook factor for me. The actress playing nell was also annoying but did the character justice I think. The ending was ok but over the top. And everyone saying this is a remake of a 63' film is wrong! This is an adaptation of Shirley Jackson book. So maybe get your facts straight before saying its completely wrong and bad lol.

A group of insomniacs do their best to put viewers to sleep in 'The Haunting', a truly disappointing attempt at a horror film. Eleanor (or Nell) lives a boring life and has for years, taking care of her ill mother. Now that the mother has passed away, she's having trouble sleeping so when she see's an ad for a sleep study on insomniacs, she jumps at the opportunity. She and two others (along with the head of the study) have to spend a few days inside a creepy old mansion in which it's deceased owner (Hugh Crane) was a sadistic creepy guy who loved children. Each night some strange stuff happens; loud noises, ghosts climbing into bed with Nell, that sort of stuff. The group discovers the secret behind Crane and the children who died there, leading to an odd ending in which Nell feels compelled to stay in the haunted house forever.'The Haunting' has got to be the most non scary horror film out there, when it really shouldn't be. It had a huge budget, a large creepy old house, a decent story had it been told better... but at the end of the day is just not scary or even remotely terrifying at all. The "scares" are few and far between, and when a ghost does appear they aren't eerie to watch. Most of the ghosts are the dead children from years ago, but they are nice ghosts and try to help Nell. The main villain Hugh Crane is not scary or intimidating at all, even when he finally appears it falls so flat. And one of the most disappointing things about this remake is that it does not use the huge mansion to it's advantage. The noises that we hear late at night are not well done at all, and the actors do not react in an appropriate way to the "scares".I thought Lili Taylor put in a very weak performance as the lead Eleanor. Some of the acting choices she made during the "scary" moments feel flat and felt forced from on her part. Liam Neeson hammed it up for the cameras and seemed out of place in this. Catherine Zeta-Jones and Luke Wilson however did good jobs in the supporting roles. Overall 'The Haunting' remake is a failure. Stick to the original 1962 film, it was much better.4/10

Review title: A dull film to say the least
Review_body: Dear me, a rather underwhelming display of noise, inane visuals and non-drama that expects one to empathise with its endlessly open-mouthed stock "heroine". Liam Neeson, so impressive in, say, "Husbands and Wives" or "Schindler's List", is scarcely a presence here. His character may have had potential, that I expect was tapped more in the original film. A problem is that once the special effects start to dominate, about 1/2 of the way through, there is literally *no* characterization. The characterization there is is all too scant, and no proper context is given to the film's events. It is all set up very suddenly, and the motivations of the characters are barely touched upon. Lili Taylor is rather annoying in a thankless role, meant to be the film's center. The delectable Catherine Zeta Jones, irritates rather less, as she does indeed appeal to the eye, and importantly as her character is barely involved in anything at all. The makers' intent - Ms Jones to act as eye candy to drag in a certain audience - is all too clear, hardly a new gambit in such movies. Each character is plainly a stereotype - Neeson as the sombre scientist, Wilson as the supposed "everyman", Taylor as the sensitive "everywoman" and CZ Jones as the sexy society girl. Wilson, bizarrely co-writer of the excellent "Rushmore", is the worst of a cast that is emphatically keen to go through the motions. His character is appallingly written and played with no stature whatsoever by Wilson. The script is utterly nondescript, and is not helped by dull, telegraphed music and bland direction. For a supposed Horror film, this has to rank especially low. There is a tangible lack of atmosphere, even of an archetypal horror sort, and this begs the question - what were this film's makers thinking? Surely at least one would attempt a more low-key use of special effects, and music of a less bland kind so typical of modern Hollywood. The use of lighting is mediocre, and although I wouldn't go as far as to say monochrome is truly essential to horror films, it is usually a very safe bet for effective atmosphere. I save seen some of the original film, from 1963, and it didn't appear to be particularly great to me, but it certainly got the horror basics right, and seemed effectively suggestive and low-key. This remake is pretty awful in every regard; the special effects even being far from eyecatching, and the admittedly reasonable sets ill used. A very inconsequential, pointless film; as far from unsettling me as a particularly aimiable episode of "Bagpuss".Rating:- * 1/2/*****

The tension in the room was so great that small startlements caused the whole theatre to scream.  The special effects were great, really blending in the haunting with the characters.
