Review title: Great special effects...but not at all scary
Review_body: I hadn't heard anything particularly good about this film, but I thought I would see it for myself.  I was disappointed to a certain extent- because it just was not at all scary.  it looked like it might be, and the haunting of Hill House certainly is a very creepy novel- but this film is just special effects wizardry and thats about all.  It has a great cast, particularly Taylor, Neeson and Zeta-Jones, but they really do play second fiddle to the special effects.  The set design really is magnificent, but the story is fairly average and the characters are unfortunately a little underdeveloped. By the end I was  bit bored with the 'creepy house', because it just was not 'creepy' enough.  Some of the lines were so laughable it could have been mistaken for a comedy.  Visually stunning for a while, but when you run out of things to look at- there is nothing else of interest.

Review title: Expected the worst, but was pleasantly surprised
Review_body: I can't understand what it is that fans of the genre didn't like about this film.  It was truly a lot of fun.  The special effects were wonderful. I generally agree with reviews and with IMDB voters, but not this time.  I waited until it came to home video which I felt was another reason that I wouldn't enjoy the film. I believe special effects films need to be seen on the big screen, but again this was not the case.   To me the film begs comparison to two films that were released around the same time.  Blair Witch and The Mummy. Both films that I thought were terrible.  Blair was probably the most overrated horror film of all time. The Mummy made gobs of money and it was pure dreck.  People liked it for it's special effects.  Films like the Mummy and The Haunting are not rich in character development, they are more like funhouse rides.  Well with that analogy the Mummy was a B ticket to the Haunting's E-ticket.

Review title: Overblown remake of a 60's horror movie.
Review_body: I have no idea why producer/director Jan de Bont decided to remake this classic haunted house movie from the Sixties.  The film seems to be designed to promote ILM's digital special effects wizards - the actors and the story are superfluous.  And whereas Director Robert Wise made a good film with considerably fewer resources in the original, Jan de Bont wastes a lot of talent here to produce a film that borders on camp.The weakest link in this film is the lead actor, Lili Taylor.  Her attempts at expressing horror and wonderment are just plain laughable.  When you see such actors as Liam Neeson, Catherine Zeta-Jones, and Bruce Dern reduced to playing secondary roles, the blandness of Ms. Taylor's performance is only accented.The plot is similar to the original except the doctor in charge is conducting an experiment in people's reaction to fear, not an exploration of psychic phenomena.  Anyone could have played the part as it was written, so why bring in Liam Neeson for a second-rate part?  Catherine Zeta-Jones plays the worldly traveler to Lili Taylor's spinster, and again, while she's drop dead gorgeous and I love to see her in anything, she's wasted in this part.As noted, the special effects are the star of the film, and ILM does a masterful job.  Nothing you haven't seen in other films, but the effects are pretty amazing nonetheless.  That having been said, the plot is pretty weak - malevolent ghost and former master of the house tries to capture Eleanor (Taylor) and keep her there. It's not a scary movie because you can see everything coming before it happens.  Other than drooling over Zeta-Jones, I didn't find much of interest here.

This film is a travesty of the scary original. Here, the original story of Hill House is elaborated on, but not in a believable way. They thought they were improving on it? This film not so much remakes the original plot as rips it off. The big draw, they thought, were the special effects. At times, the special effects are so cartoon-like, I scoffed at them and was never scared by them. The haunted house in this question resembles a cathedral more than anything else, and the original owner is turned into an industrial magnate. There's added plots of his marriages and a bunch of trapped children, which is suppose to tug at our heart strings. Yeah, right. It's a surprise that some good actors were lured into starring in this, which did nothing to help their careers. Catherine Zeta-Jones is very well-cast, but was defeated by the lousy script and ridiculous visuals. I hope she and her co-stars were paid well for this waste of their time, not to mention the audiences. Hollywood needs to learn to leave well enough alone.

The only good thing about this movie are the sets and the location. Harlaxton Manor in England posed for the exterior's; they couldn't have picked a creepier looking house.  The inside is also miraculous.  I would love to have a house with everything just like that inside it.  The huge fireplace, the wonderful hallway with a stream in it and books serving as stepping stones, etc. But they have strayed too far from Shirley Jackson's acclaimed story; the worst faux pas was making Evelyn anything other than a victim.  That is the essence of the original story: she is swallowed up by Hill House and hasn't the strength to fight it.  What's worse is that the story they do come up with is not fleshed out at all.  They just put these 4 poor actors in this gorgeous set, and have them all speaking lines that mean nothing and go no where.  If you must see this film, see it for it's visual splendor.  If you want to see the best and only adaptation to capture Shirley Jackson's story, see the 1963 version by Robert Wise, also called "The Haunting".  There is no comparison between the two.  Then read the book.  You'll be surprised at how closely the 1963 film follows the storyline, and at how far off this new movie is.

The Haunting (1999) D: Jan de Bont. Lili Taylor, Liam Neeson, Catherine Zeta-Jones, Owen Wilson, Bruce Dern, Todd Field, Virginia Madsen. At about the half hour mark I was thinking to myself "Ok, flimsy premise, but cool house and looks like Lili Taylor is going to anchor things with a touching, three dimensional characterization, and there are some interesting possibilities with the rest of the cast." I really was willing to give it a chance at that point. At about the 45 minute mark, I was getting a little restless, fidgeting in my seat thinking "Oookaaay, ready for some scares!" 15 minutes later, I was still waiting. 15 minutes after that, same story. 15 minutes after that I was too busy gagging at the increasingly banal dialogue and moronic situations to think much of anything. (Owen Wilson getting "trapped" in that economy car has to be one of the most hilariously suspense-LESS scenes ever filmed! Hey Owen, to get out you might want to try um, rolling the windows down?) Not too long after that, the closing credits started rolling and I vaguely recalled having sat through what must have been a motion picture of some sort. Only recently, with the aid of hypnosis have I been able to come to terms with the fact that I had just viewed something called "The Haunting", possibly the worst movie ever made - dollar for dollar.All that money, all that talent and this is the best they could come up with? A movie totally devoid of scares, chills or suspense of any kind? How ironic that much the way Liam Neeson's laughably conceived scientist character lures a group of people to a spooky mansion under the pretense of it being a study about insomnia; the folks who made this movie lured a group of people to see what was presumably supposed to be a horror movie when it was actually a cure for insomnia! Way to go Jan De Bont! He is like a failing student bluffing his way through an oral exam about a subject he knows nothing about! Because it is clear that this man has absolutely no feel for this genre, the mechanics of horror or the most basic fundamentals of story telling in general.His cast is marooned, stranded on a tiny raft swirling around in an ocean of incompetence and it's interesting, in a ghoulish sort of way, to see how each one of them deals. Lili Taylor DOES create a character and give her a soul - she's a wonderful actress and she has no choice, she can't help it, it's like a mothering instinct. But she finally goes under in the film's "climatic" moments - her stubborn professionalism capsized by a monsoon of stupidity. (Plus, her screams need a lot of work - she's like a patient opening her mouth and saying "AHHH" a little too loud.) Liam Neeson is in pain throughout - he's a good actor who's just very embarrassed. Owen Wilson is too much of a newcomer to truly understand how wretched the thing is. An offbeat presence, I think he had an inkling and spends most of his time on screen looking around for guidance that is not forthcoming. Given a paper thin character with absolutely nothing challenging to do and what could have been an interesting relationship with Taylor left totally unexplored, Catherine Zeta Jones just looks incredibly bored - like a high fashion model forced to babysit.The best word to describe this movie? HOLLOW. There's almost nothing to it. If you really want to be scared, check out the original. Now THAT was a creepy movie. There's simply no comparison.

Jan de Bont's puerile marijuana trip between reality and fantasy lies in a net where you can invent nonsense of "scientific experiments" and "tyrant landlords" just as an excuse to make a house come to life by moving statues in an idiotic routine. This movie also teaches a lot: 1) If you are trapped in a house where voices of children are heard, when paintings in blood are written, when doors are strangely closed: just stay a little bit more, some days more. If you die, you die. What's the problem? 2) You are doing a movie of "suspense" or "horror", just finish it by showing the credits with a merry go-round music! Anyway, children will like it. 3) If an iron statued-eagle goes crazy and decides to jump over you, fight it over with a stick. 4) When they take you a picture in the Medieval times, like the one showing Carolyne, take her kind of ten with her pointing to the fire place, even if she looks idiotic. It's a probable clue for your great grand daughter to free dead children: well that's a premise!! 5) Hugh Crain has the best haircut I've ever seen on a ghost.6) Jan de Bont has 12 years old and the writer is Rain Man. 7) Purgatory and Heaven are as easy to enter as in California. 8) If you have a companion that thinks her family is a group of dead children, take a step back.You may know; movies are not made for reality. But what is imaginary is Jan de Bont's intellectuality. The leading actress is so obnoxious in his Eleanor role that I would vote "yes" if someone proposes to exile her to Vanuatu. Catherine Zeta Jones? Owen Wilson? Acting touches rock bottom with their empty gestures. The movie gives a lot more importance to the visual stuff (like lion statues dancing) than to the importance of the script. It's an empty, very empty package. Recommendation: stay away from this movie.

This movie was one of the worst movies ever made.  It ranks right with "Twister," and "Friday the 13th Part VIII," which this movie resembles. This movie was one of the clumsiest, most obvious, and down-right funny horror movies that I have ever seen.  The person I saw this with told be to hush because my laughter was disturbing the rest of the people.  But, the movie is not all bad.Plot: Great plot.  I am sorry but the plot is one of the creepier plots ever made.  They mangled it though.  The idea that a house where a man hunted children, and a distant relative saves their spirits is pretty good.  This was done from a book, and is a remade movie.  I have not seen the original, but since it had a different director, and special effects that couldn't try to steal the show, it must be better.Acting: I loved Lily Taylor.  As Eleanor, she was wonderful.  However, the rest of the cast needed a little help.  Owen Wilson was decent, but Zeta-Jones, although very nice to look at, was too outlandish in this movie. Liam was way to obvious for me.  Lily Taylor was good as a person suffering from true delusions, and almost breaking-down.  She should act her way into a better movie.Special Effects: Nice to look at but too much.  I mean, they were the most obvious effects imaginable.  The roof beating, the spirits in the drapes, and the pointy things on the bed were too obvious.  However, it also suffered from the "Gee, how could I have missed that" syndrome.  The room that resembled her mother's room was a direct result of that.  The eyes in her room were also direct results of that.  The only thing that worked in my opinion was Mr. Frosty.  You'll know what I mean, as the guy in the window.Dialogue: Horrible.  Not much else to say.Direction:  Blunt, obvious, and horrid.  He set everything up early.  The revealing of the fear experiment would have been a nice discovery/twist late in the movie.  The guy in the pond was too obvious.  Nothing shocked me, or made me scream.  I laughed at some of the things, like the fireplace.Sound:  Louder than a rock concert.  I can hear the movie in the next theater.  Really, I saw "Eyes Wide Shut" and I heard the rumbling from the theater.  Prepare for loud decibels.  Also unnecessary low rumbling is constant through the movie.  It got annoying.  One cool effect is you hear the house quietly settling, and it goes from the back of the theater to the front. That was cool.The house rocked, and I want to live there.  But, I laughed through the movie.  It is blunt, obvious, and you will laugh at the bland attempts to scare you.  It is like going to a haunted house in October, everything jumps at you, and it does not work. However, I laugh at those houses, as I laughed at the movie.  For making me laugh--------3

Review title: Definitely the best movie ever done.
Review_body: To all horror movie lovers, to see a couple of times, attentionaly and bearing in mind that some bad reviews must not influence the final appreciation of a fantastic movie.The Best: The actors, the special effects, sound, art direction, sceneries, photography, directing, the majority of the script, after all : THE MOVIEThe Worst: Saying nothing would be stretching things too much, but my only complaint goes to the non inclusion of images of the house's past: construction, deaths and probably if there were more characters trapped in the house would be interesting.As almost everyone should know this movie was based upon the novel by Shirley Jackson The Haunting Of Hill House', and the following 1963 Robert Wise's movie with the same title. The first movie was very faithful to the book and this one was just based on it. So, for those who compared both movies really don't have a point for it, as the only thing in common are some common places, character names and plot scenes. Back in 1963, Robert Wise, director of West Side Story propose us a visit to hill house resulting in one of the scariest horror movies driven and acted well by someone who knows what is doing. Three and a half decades later, Jan De Bont, director of the fantastic box office hits, Twister and Speed offer us another visit to Shirley Jackson frightening manor, this time with frankly terrific results. Both movies are good and scary, but Jan De Bont's is incomparably better.For more than one century that the frightful and sinister Hill House stands alone and abandoned or so it seems. Intrigued by the house's storied past, Dr. David Marrow (Liam Neeson) draws some people to the house Theo (Catherine Zeta-Jones), Nell (Lili Taylor), Luke (Owen Wilson), for an apparently innocent experience. But since the moment of her arrival, Nell seems frightenly mutual. As soon as it begins to get dark, the study about fear is horrifically abandoned as the people discover the haunting secrets that fill hill house. This secrets are allusive to the house's owner Hugh Crain and the house's construction. At first they believe that the story is some kind of a fairy tale but as soon as this secrets are revealed by apparitions to Nell, she realizes that it is not that fairy tale but a haunted story of terror, slavery and death until the very revelation in the end.The movie is mainly focused on Lili Taylor's character Nell which drives her character's acting remarkably well, although the other main character's acting are very good indeed but it is clear for everyone that the acting' that steals the show is hill house itself. Set designer Eugenio Zanetti did a very good job designing the interiors of a huge manor that is creepy, beautiful, charming and mysterious altogether. It is very rewarding to see that this is one of those movies that are rewarding in every aspect you can examine. But this movie works fantastic as a whole not only in some aspects. Music composer Jerry Goldsmith gave us pleasant movie scores like Poltergeist', The Mummy', Hollow Man', Star Trek' among other instant classics and once more he did a fabulous job composing this score that perhaps is his best one in his career, creepy, beautiful and suggestive. Some time ago before 2000 Oscar ceremony I read a comment that if this movie was not nominated at least for special effects, sound, photography, set design and sound design I will be haunted', I just have to say that I totally agree. Director Jan De Bont proved that he knows how to direct not only action adventure movies but also horror/ thriller/ suspense and still keep the audience on their nerves. David Self's screenplay is not what people make of it, it contains very well written descriptions, memorable sequences, not included on the original nor on the book, remarkable dialogues and quotes.After reading hundreds of comments here on IMDB and other sites about this movie I just find curious that in all of them they only refer as negative the slowest parts of the movie never the best and memorable, why is that, were they to embaraced of stating they were truly scared or touched by those scenes. Are they true critics or selective critics. A movie comment is written selectively or as a whole? I have to confess that I laughed  my stomach out  reading those comments.Anyway, for those who are reading THIS comment and haven't seen the movie, don't let yourself be influenced by those critics, you better don't, and for those who have seen the movie and feel somehow divided, I advise you to see it again and again to let yourself be swept away by the hugeness and strength of the movie. If you allow it, Jan De Bont and David Self's THE HAUNTING will do it for you. I've seen hundreds of movies so far and none of them could touch me so positively as this one.The Haunting will also make you wonder: Who called Eleanor to respond to Dr. Marrow's ad?See it, enjoy it!   Oh, and Sleep Tight!

Review title: What would you expect from a PG-13 horror movie?
Review_body: It's not scary. It has scary moments, but it's not a scary movie. The story-line tries to be clever and I guess it is, in a way, but the only thing that saves the movie from being boring are the special effects. There's nothing new there, we've seen it all before, but there are a lot of special effects in this movie... It's an ok movie, but that's it.

Review title: Not Alot of Plot, Nice Sets
Review_body: Well, I just watched this movie on PPV.  Was it worth it?  Yes and no. Personally, I loved the house.  The set design is a masterpiece.  I would love to live in a house like that!  I loved all the antiques and creepy statues.  But that's really all I loved about the movie.  I did like the main character, Elenor, at first.  But as the movie draaaaggggsss on, I found Elenor intolerable as well as all the other characters.  In fact, I kept wishing the house would kill them all off.  This movie could have been done so much scarier and better.  It needed a better cast and alot more horror.  It also needed a bigger cast.  There weren't enough people in that house to kill off.  The whole movie is really a big shame.  All that money to build those impressive sets and all we get is a bad Poltergeist rip-off. If you like scary old houses with creepy antiques, watch the movie just for that, but don't expect much in the way of a good story.

Review title: A silly film with poor acting.
Review_body: Compare this film to The House on Haunted Hill and you will see how these people simply can't act. Vincent Price could convey more with just a glance than any of these over-blown (and over paid,) super stars.We have here a similar premise to the Vincent Price film but the similarity just shows up how inferior this is. After 15 mins you could be forgiven for fast forwarding to check if anything worthwhile happens.To summarise – there is lots of running around, screaming and sexual innuendos (yawn,) all held together with CGI effects, then it ends.A waste of money.

This movie relied to much on special effects rather than concentrating on creating a real spooky environment. The atmosphere was very creepy but the total effect wasn't great. Catherine Zeta Jones in this movie just flashes herself around the whole movie not really giving any type of performance. Only one death throughout the whole movie, a bit confusing at times in the story. the special effects were the star in this this movie, the actors and director could have done much more with the creepy story of the man and the house with all the children. A pretty lame remake.

Some paranormal investigators spend a few nights in a supposedly haunted house and learn that the house is really haunted .The story is the same as the original film, but after the first 30 minutes, it becomes obvious that they're going in a very different direction. The subtlety and nuance of the original film is replaced with blaring music, loud sound effects, wind machines, and some really bad computer effects. This Haunting is more like an amusement park ride at Universal Studios than an effective horror film.

Review title: About all that can be said is great photography and special effects.
Review_body: What makes the film barely worthwhile seeing is the mansion, the photography, and the special effects. If one expects a thrill, forget it. The plot is very predictable and there is no suspense. Part of the problem is Lili Taylor who plays the main character. Her performance at times makes one wonder whether they are watching a comedy or a thriller. The film opens with a scene between Taylor and Virginia Madsen in a battle over the estate of their mother but the story never resolves that issue and leaves it dangling. The ending leaves one unsatisfied in that it leaves too many ends untitled. One gets the feeling that they are not watching a thriller but only the hallucinations induced by the fear that the Doctor has generated. Catherine Zeta-Jones provided nothing in her supporting role. One good thing for the movie was that there was no gratuitous sex and no profanity or vulgarity.

Review title: Little in the way of frights or empathy
Review_body: This is a movie that does not start well and gets worse the longer it goes on (and it does go on). The basic premise of Liam Neeson's character Doctor Marrow conducting a study into fear by inviting people to a so called "haunted house" under the misinformation of it being a study into people who suffer from insomnia is interesting enough. This could of lead to some good psychological scares. However when the house itself does turn out to be haunted we really do gets by numbers horror where I found it incredibly difficult to find any empathy for any of the characters and also struggled to maintain interest in the film. Even the normally likable Owen Wilson was poor here. Certainly one to avoid abd not one for re-watching.

Review title: Not bad...if u don't compare it to the original!
Review_body: If you don't compare it to the original classic, the remake is pretty good. One of the more interesting things was that they created a different "history" of the house, which is revealed, slowly, as the movie progresses.  It adds a "diffent dimension" (and, an interesting one, at that) to the film.But, the character's acting is EXTRMELY wooden, and Hill House is impossibly over-ornate (they would've needed over 100 servants to clean it all!  They went "overboard" on this!). And, of course, the special effects are top-notch!!!!!Again, if you forget about the '60's classic, and judge this film by it's OWN merits, it's pretty good!  (Look at the remake of "Psycho" -- they copied every frame, and everyone said,"Why bother remaking it?").  But, 1999's "Haunting" is NOT a remake -- they take the original story line and, in myopinion, make it BETTER!Norm

The scariest thing about "The Haunting" is that somebody spent that much money on such a bad movie.The sets, costumes, and special effects were worthy of the best Spielberg or Lucas could offer, but they're wasted on a Mystery Science Theater 3000 script. Who wrote the screenplay, R.L. Stein?The characters are utterly alien. They rush into situations where they should be terrified. They brush off serious questions, leave Nell alone when they think she's in danger, fail to even check on her claim that she found skulls under the fireplace (okay, the headshrinker makes a dulsatory attempt, but doesn't follow through), send the biggest and heaviest member of the group up a fragile set of stairs instead of having the slender woman come back down them, et cetera ad nauseum.If the dialogue got any cornier, the FDA would classify it as a vegetable and add it to the Food Pyramid.Visually, it's beautiful. If you want to feast your eyes, watch it without the sound, maybe listening to some classical music. Then it's salvageable. Otherwise, it's a waste of time.

Review title: Not the worst movie ever made, but horrible none the less
Review_body:
Some of the other reviews call this the worst movie ever made, well, it's not.I'm first going to say the good points about it.  First off, the special effects will make you drool.  They are so good, and so original that no one, NO ONE can say this movie is 100% bad.  Oh, and Catherine Zeta Jones is in it.  That's about it though.Movies like this are like M&Ms (this is a long analogy, so go with it).  The movie's soul (the characters, the acting, the plot, the theme, etc...) are like the chocolate.  The extra stuff (the special effects, the sound, etc...) is like the candy coating.  As you know, about 90% of an M&M is chocolate, because that's what tastes best.  Same goes with movies. 
Now, M&Ms need the coating too.  Other wise, it would just be chocolate, boring chocolate.  In movies, special effects are nice editions, but they need a chocolate center to cover.Now, if the IMDb editors haven't cut out my analogy, if the Haunting was an M&M, it would be all coating.  No chocolate, at all.  And that is pretty sad seeing how this movie is a REMAKE, of a movie BASED on a book.  You would think at some point along this movie's script they could have added interesting stuff.  But, noooooo.  It's almost like they subtracted stuff and replaced it with uninteresting dribble.The thing I hate most about this movie is Lillie Taylor and her character Eleanor.  First off, this woman can't act, period.  I break out laughing whenever she speaks.  Her character is also way too complex.  When someone makes a stupid movie, just leave it stupid.  There was no way of making this movie smart, and the good people at Dreamworks know that.  So why, WHY did they try to put a complex character in a movie where all the other characters are 2-dimensional recycled trash?I really don't consider this a movie.  It's a demo tape for the Dreamworks visual effects team.  It was made so they could say, "Hey, I did the CGI effects on the Haunting", and people will be impressed.  But, if some one, say the actors or the director says," Hey, I was in/directed the Haunting", people will run in terror.  This is a scary movie.  It's scary that someone had the idea to make it. AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH! (Note; buy this movie if you want to impress some friends with you new home entertainment system, other wise, avoid at all costs)

I LOVED the house. It was the best house I have ever seen!! The house gets 10/10 for shear over-the-top grandness! All those carvings, and secret rooms, the cherubs, the beautiful ornate furniture! There are so many neat things about this house that it should get House of the Year in Movies. One question: Where were the elevators??Aside from that, the rest just sucked. I sat there and waited for something scary to happen... and nothing happened! I waited some more... and still nothing!  Of course, special FX are pretty well special in the FX dept, but this is marred by the weak plot and lame acting. If only they had put more real scares into this, it would've made a much better movie, after all, it is a remake of a 60s flick!However the house is, of course, the best (and definatly the most memorable) actor in the movie.CONCLUSION: See this House first!

I know it is fashionable now to hate this movie.  I have seen hundreds of spook films including he original 1963 Haunting as well as most of the Hammer films.  This film is not restrained and does not hold back at all which is probably why so many modern viewers seemed not to like it. Yet many viewers can accept out of control films like Scream because slashers are more easy to believe than demons or ghosts.  Actually this film had many great scenes and the acting and special effects were great.  I have seen it 15 times now and it gets better every time. The director of this film has made a number of interesting and stylish films and was not trying for the type of realism of the 6th sense.  The Haunting lets go and is certainly not boring.  Perhaps this film might appeal more to John Carpenter fans but more of an tradtional plot structure. The old Haunting was also a fine film from 1963.  It was even more scary. See both and also The Innocents and The Legend of Hell House with Pamela franklin.

I know it is fashionable now to hate this movie.  I have seen hundreds of spook films including he original 1963 Haunting as well as most of the Hammer films.  This film is not restrained and does not hold back at all which is probably why so many modern viewers seemed not to like it. Yet many viewers can accept out of control films like Scream because knife killers are more easy to believe for most people than demons or ghosts.  Actually this film had many great scenes and the acting and special effects were great.  I have seen it 15 times now and it gets better every time. Perhaps this film might appeal more to John Carpenter fans but more of an traditional plot structure.  The old Haunting was also a fine film from 1963.  It was even more scary.  See both and also The Innocents and The Legend of Hell House with Pamela Franklin.

Wanna make a horror-film? Here is a virtual guidebook on how NOT to do it. When is anyone in Hollywood ever going to realize that lavish sets, digital animation and loud sound effects does not necessarily a horror movie make? Especially not when the director fails to grasp even the most basic rules. This looks like a show-reel for some digital FX-company. Yes, I knew going in it was going to suck, Jan de Bont and a re-make of Wises excellent The Haunting? One of the best haunted house movies ever? No-no-no-no...and it did suck, beyond my wildest dreams, in fact. The plot holes and other crappy things in this movie are too numerous to mention. The only horrific things about it is the level of sucking it reaches, and the wasted time and effort of the set decorators and carpenters. I feel sorry for the great Jerry Goldsmith who had to score this utter piece of garbage. Everyone else involved in this movie should be ashamed. I´m glad I didn´t have to pay to see it. It´s so bad it isnt even funny, its condescending and insulting.

Review title: Shouldn't be compared to the 1963 film, but still a (very) atmospheric chiller
Review_body: I saw The Haunting (1999) when I was 4 years old and I loved it as a kid. Although I don't consider it such a great film nowadays, specially when compared to much superior 1963 original, I consider it a fun movie that works better as a stand-alone film. As a matter of fact, I think it would've had much more praise had it been a stand-alone film. It's also better than most of the stupid, PG-13 remakes out there, like the godawful Prom Night remake. The film has something else that lacks in every PG-13 horror remake nowadays: the atmosphere. The Haunting is filled with atmosphere. The set desing is jaw-dropping, for the likes of Suspiria and The Shining. The dark imposing mansion, it's very creepy and the house setting in this film is better than the house from the original. The soundtrack by Jerry Goldsmith is haunting and beautiful, showing us he hasn't lost his touch, and it's up there with the scores he composed for The Omen and Poltergeist. The acting is, well, not so good, and you can expect that from Owen Wilson (WFT IS HE DOING IN A HORROR MOVIE ANYWAY?!). Lily Taylor does the best she can as the outcast protagonist and I sympathize with her character more than I did with Julie Harris in the 1963 film. However, the 1963 film is better in almost every way and it's of course a classic, one of the best of the genre. Liam Neeson also does a good job. Catherine Zeta Jones steals the scene as the wild Theo, and is probably the best actress in the film. Even the direction is good, which surprises me considering it came from the director of Speed. DeBont proves to me he's a big fan of Kubrick's The Shining, considering how the film appears in a terrifc scene in Twister and here it's obvious he's influencd by that film. In any case, watch The Haunting. It's worth it, it's not as bad as people claim it to be and try to watch it with an open mind, I really hope you enjoy it.

Review title: Planning to watch it now? Don't.
Review_body: There is not a single positive point to watch it now, not even Liam Neeson. Just walk away.

The Haunting is yet another bad horror remake with phony overdone special effects and a big cast of on screen favorites and has no redeeming qualities whatsoever except maybe for the cinematography.Yes remakes aren't all bad but remakes directed by Jion Da Bont definitely are.I suppose that the A-List actors (Liam Neeson,Catherine Zeta Jones,Owen Wilson)are there to distract us from the boring plot,ridiculous special effects, and terrible attempts at scaring it's audience however this is a movie not a tabloid magazine we don't care whose in it we care about the characters and story two things this film missed.The storyline is like taking the classic novel The Haunting Of Hill House and ripping out four chapters and then using whatever's left for the film it is so boring and a lot of it is unexplained.The characters are pretty thin and while the acting is good you don't really care about any of the characters at all.Lily Taylor gives a horrendous performance and sounds like she's 8 years old when delivering her lines not to mention what a horrible screamer she is.Lily Taylor isn't made for the horror genre at all.The ghosts are stupid and cheesy, they look like a bunch of Casper The Friendly Ghost's and the ghost of Hugh Cain looks like a fat guy dressed as the grim reaper for Halloween with a smoke machine.There is this creature on the roof of one of the rooms that is a giant purple mouth and it's not even funny unintentionally just plain sad.The house is pretty and well designed that is probably the only positive thing about this movie it looks nice but that doesn't save it from it's brutal everything else.I can honestly say i felt like i was wasting my time watching The Haunting on TV for no price so I would've been even more pi$$ed if I had paid to see it but luckily it was on Scream Channel.Overall The Haunting is a boring remake that tries to overwhelm you with bad special effects, a poor attempt at horror.

I hate brussels sprouts, I don't trust used car dealers, can't stand banks and this movie was lousy. That pretty much summarizes it. To pad the review let me add Owen Wilson should be forced to eat brussels sprouts while buying a used car with a loan from a bank. Lili Taylor should stay away from the front of the camera and maybe work as a grip or in the deli section. Zeta-Jones should have taken all of her clothes off. At least it would have been a distraction. Liam Neeson should simply go find the original negative and burn it. Jan de Bont should pal around with Owen Wilson and eat lots of brussels sprouts. Finally, if you're gonna make a movie and spend a ton of money on it, why not hire a scriptwriter instead of just asking the pizza delivery guy to come up with some 'hot' ideas.And the ending sucked.

Review title: The Worst Reviewed Movie of the Year...
Review_body: Even though 80 percent of the reviews of this movie were bad, I decided to go see for myself, because usually critics stink anyway.  They were sort of right.  I was mad in two ways: there was no good, memorable, scary scenes like the original.  There was no hand-holding scene (although you could hear Lili Taylor's character say, "It was holding my hand" for about a split second, but it was drowned out by the very loud music.)  I was also mad that the TV previews say only Liam Neeson and Catherine Zeta-Jones's names when Lili Taylor's character was the lead!  Yeah, sure, she's an independent film queen, but at least give her some "big-studio" credit!Well, anyway, the movie was good in some ways, and it was bad in some ways. It was bad that the special effects weren't very scary, but in the original, it was scary with no SFX whatsoever. Also, the best moment that was in the original was NOT INCLUDED (the hand-holding scene)!  It was good because it did not have a single F-word in it and there was minimal gore.  Also, it was a little scary with the startle sounds and the sound effects (scary sounds were the best part of the movie.)  It was still kind of scary, but I still think that the original is best.  Also, don't go to the movie expecting Liam Neeson and CZJ to be leads, expect Lili Taylor.  She was great.

The only plus for this film are the visuals, and while by today's LOTR-bar-setting standards they're nothing incredible they are still impressive and nice to watch. Also some great imagery, the mansion has a wonderful, Gothic atmosphere about it so kudos to the visuals department.That aside, this movie stinks! Terrible, laughable dialog, especially the climax of the film, very cringe-inducing. The story has some interest but falls flat on the ground with the tacky writing and lame acting efforts of Neeson, Wilson and Zeta-Jones.Avoid. 'Nuff said.

Review title: Really neat effects- and it actually has a story!
Review_body: I guess people have canned this one because it doesn't have a lot of gore and blood.. but it's called "The Haunting," which does suggest that it will be more about ghosts than murder, right?  (I mean, you wouldn't expect "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" to be about bumps in the night, would you?)    I saw this in the theater and was scared out of my wits, but of course it's much less scary on TV.  I still like it a lot because instead of showing mindless dismemberment and disemboweling, they spend the time providing some personality to the main characters and letting you come along while one of them learns the secret of the house and eventually goes nuts.  (Ehh, and of course Liam Neeson is there looking very sexy and captivating, as always. That doesn't hurt at all.) It also has really neat special effects that aren't just ghosts walking around (ala House on Haunted Hill), but the house *itself* actually comes alive and you can feel the evil presence in it. Only at the very end do they show a definite "ghost," and they build up to it - which is rare in modern movies.  I am surprised so many people disliked "The Haunting," but I suspect it's because they were looking for a splashy-blood movie with main characters that are just dopes who wander around alone in basements, all but begging to be chopped up... not a "real" movie that details its characters and offers a genuine story.   The only fault in "The Haunting" is the ending, which is hokey because Nell ends up blabbering some really cheesy lines.  Otherwise I think this a really good one - (I've rented it several times.) because it isn't a brainless gorefest. If you want a movie like that, rent any of the Friday the 13th or Nightmare on Elm Street installments.   "The Haunting" is a serious, chilly movie, not a cheaply made horror flick.

Review title: "It should be burned to the ground, and the ground sown with salt"
Review_body: This movie is the most accurate measurement of how low the art of cinematography has fallen. $80 million it cost, and it was finished just in time to qualify as "turkey of the century". The reason it is so glaringly awful is that it has to bear comparison with the 1963 original...a real classic. The main effect of this [1999] movie will be to provoke more people to become acquainted with The Haunting[1963], and to discover its austere beauty. And that of many other forgotten old films.

If there is anything that I have to say about this movie, it's a pure dissappointment.  Although the castle is beautiful, this movie just doesn't cut it.  Its about 4 people who stay in a "Haunted" house.  Its effects are all 3-d, (which look real cheap at that).  And is not scary at all.  Only consider watching this movie if you are suicidal. Contains- Violence

I can't believe DreamWorks poured $80 million into this sorely overhyped horror movie with all the best parts spoiled in the previews. This movie is so bad that the moments in the movie intended to be scary are laughable. It's hard to believe that such a talented cast would do such a terrible film. Jan DeBont, a very good director at action adventure movies (Twister, Speed) but a terrible director at horror movies such as this. If you want scary, I suggest the original which is disgraced with this version.

Review title: Typical movie where best parts are in the preview
Review_body: A truly awful film. I must say I almost threw up once I left the theater after seeing this sure to be a golden raspberry nominee. The direction is more stale than a box of old donuts and the writing is even worse. I wouldn't even call this a remake of a classic. I'd call it a disgrace to a classic. A lame subplot overshadows a film that had such potential. DreamWorks should employ a new marketing department because they showed the best parts in the preview with this seriously awful movie.

Review title: Starring Lili Taylor and Hill House
Review_body: The Haunting takes place in an awesome mansion (Hill House), a very rich set for a scary haunted house tale.  Unfortunately, despite some pretty elaborate special effects, the movie is simply not very scary.  It could ... and should ... have been much better, especially since the budget appeared to offer considerable resources to the film's creators.Although this flick is billed as starring Liam Neeson and Catherine Zeta-Jones, it's Lili Taylor's character ("Eleanor") who, along with the House, are really the stars.  Rent it to see Lili and the House.  But don't expect to be scared.

Being a fan of pretty much all four of the main actors in this movie (some more than others) I was looking forward to seeing THE HAUNTING. After seeing the very cool-looking graphics that were on the commercials, I was even more excited. Unfortunately, I found that I had already seen most of the best-looking graphics on the commercials. I didn't find the movie too scary, but it was spooky at some parts.Dr. David Marrow (Liam Neeson) wants to perform experiments using human guinea pigs to learn about human fear. He takes three subjects, Theo (Catherine Zeta-Jones), Luke Sannerson (Owen Wilson), and Nelle Vance (Lili Taylor), who believe that the tests are about insomnia, to a giant mansion. The mansion has a scary history and some very creepy rooms, decorations and gargoyles. The subjects come to learn that the mansion truly is haunted, though Dr. Marrow thinks it is just part of his experiment. Soon, the four have to struggle to survive the night and get out of the mansion alive.The story line is fairly interesting, but this movie is overlong and tends to get boring at parts. The computer effects are fantastic, but they aren't shown enough until the end and most of those effects you probably saw on previews and commercials.Catherine Zeta-Jones stole the show, playing an extremely sexy bisexual. Liam Neeson did a fair job, but he does tend to go into spurts of over-acting. Owen Wilson does well as the comic relief and Lili Taylor did an OK job as the first woman to notice the mystery of the mansion. All characters are very different and it is fascinating to see how they all react to the haunted mansion.This movie is definitely worth a rent. You might be bored at some parts, but the action is good and the ending is fair. Go enjoy.

Review title: This movie is classified in the wrong genre
Review_body: The genre should have been comedy.  This movie was neither scary, mysterious, or thrilling.  It was a horrible movie.  Please tell me the book was better.  I found myself during all of the "scary" parts of the movie. The scariest part to me was probably when Liam Neeson got the class stuck in his hand and had to pull it out.  I found myself wondering why good actors such as this would actually agree to take part in this sorry excuse for a horror film.  Liam Neeson was in good, quality movies until he hit "Star Wars: The Phantom Menace" which is number 1 on my list of over rated movies.  It's like that was the movie that ruined his career.  Catherine Zeta-Jones (Traffic) is also a pretty decent actress.  I can't possibly come to understand what she was thinking when she said yes to this movie.  That blonde guy...I don't even know his name...will probably never get another role after this.  And then there's Lili Taylor.  What can I say about her? She was horrible.  Isn't she the girl from Ransom (which in my opinion was a good movie).  I can't remember her acting on this but I hope she hasn't gotten worse through the years.  I found myself wanting to jump into the movie and slap her.  Is this how she really talks?  Or is it her acting voice.  She had lines like "the children need me," and "even in death you wouldn't let them go."  Who the heck cares about some children that died like 200 years ago?  They're dead...get over it.  And she has to be the one to save them because she is their great great great (sure there are some more greats in here) aunt.  There was no plot to this movie, none of the stuff that happened was explained, and the stuff that was supposed to be scary wasn't.  OMG it's a statue...let me scream in fear and trip over myself while I'm trying to run away!  The ending will have you laughing and thanking God that this movie is over.  Rent the movie if you want a good laugh... 1 out of 10.

This is not only Lili Taylor's worst film but it is also one of the worst films ever made.What were these intelligent actors like Taylor and Owen Wilson and Catherine Zeta-Jones thinking when they accepted this crap? Were they really getting that much money to do this? How sad. It's not even good in a "so-bad-it's-funny" sorta way. When Taylor says towards the end, "it's all about the family" I thought I was going to vomit.This isn't worth commenting on any further -- if you still want to watch it after reading all the negative comments written, be my guest. Absolute garbage.

A truly terrible remake of the classic 1960's chiller of the same name. What was a genuinely chilling experience has become a prime example of crass, big-budget Hollywood overkill.  At times there is some enjoyment to be had by admiring just how foolish the whole enterprise truly is but it is hard to sustain any level of real interest as more special effects bludgeon any rational thought out of your head.  Do yourself a favour and check out the original-sure it is more slowly paced and there are hardly any special effects but once the atmosphere captures you you will be hooked.

Review title: Not great, but not all that bad...
Review_body:
I've been reading the reviews that make this sound like the worst movie ever.  I must admit that I found it scary and interesting.  No, it's not great.  The mansion and the effects are fabulous, but there's not a whole lot of story going on here.  They also missed many opportunities to make you wonder what is really going on. I think it would have been more interesting if they had:
1.  Not killed anyone.  The one killing was gratuitous and not necessary to the show at all.2.  Kept you wondering if this is real or a put-on.  It would have been far more interesting and much more of a challenge to the viewer.A bit more subtlety would have been really helpful, too.But, it's worth renting or watching on HBO.

Review title: If you haven't seen this yet I recommend you do
Review_body: The Haunting is one of the best horror films I have seen in quite a while. Its not so much a scary movie but a suspenseful supernatural drama horror movie. The Haunting is sadly underrated and with a score of 4.7/10 when I did this review its quite sad. The movie doesn't pile on the gore like in most other horror movies and instead there are more screams and a sense of a ghostly presence.The Haunting should have been nominated for at least one oscar but poor reviews from the critics and people made it poor for some people. It may have been a box office smash in both the uk and the usa but its not no Carrie or The Exorcist (which are both crap). 10/10 If you like The Haunting try: House on Haunted Hill, The Others, The Haunting (1967), Scary Movie 2

Review title: Great movie and f/x but the plot was really lacking.
Review_body: I thought this movie was pretty good. I was a little mad that the plot was hardly there. There was great sets and good performances. The one thing that really held this movie together was the amazing f/x. They were some of the best I had ever seen in a movie. The action sequences were really good too. It's just a fun summer movie. I will buy it when it comes out on DVD. It's worth it. It opened big but dropped at the box office. It deserved more. It's got some laughs but not many. It's not a comedy but I like a little laughs with my horror. Check it out if you don't mind a plot that isn't there. It just seemed to go on about nothing but it was still fun. At least it's better than Jan De Bont's last movie, Speed 2: Cruise Control. The Haunting: B-

Review title: Zeta would make a nice stewardess
Review_body: The script for this movie was probably found in a hair-ball recently coughed up by a really old dog. Mostly an amateur film with lame FX. For you Zeta-Jones fanatics: she has the credibility of one Mr. Binks.

Review title: Was this movie *supposed* to make any sense?
Review_body: Effect(s) without cause is generally not possible in the real world but in the world of Hollywood remakes, not only is it possible, it's required.  The Haunting has been given the computer treatment courtesy of a 1st-class cinematographer-turner-director who once showed promise (Jan de Bont- Speed) but has since produced a string of big budget garbage (Twister, Speed 2).Actor are superfluous in a movie of this type and they seem to realize it. Liam Neeson and Cathrine Zeta-Jones act like they wish they were anywhere but in this film.  Lili Taylor makes an attempt to add something to the proceedings but whatever that something might be is unknown since the script feels like half of it is missing.  Events just happen, good and bad ghosts show up with no rhyme or reason and then the story just ends with a most unsatisfying non-event meant to wrap up the previous 90 minutes of inanity.There really isn't even reason to see this for the effects since we all know that anything can be put on screen now.  Why not watch effects in the service of a good story instead of just for their own sake?

I wondered during watching this flick whether Jan De Bont (a fellow Dutchman) had seen the original Haunting. Because from this movie he could have learned that LESS is MORE. This is the ground rule in making a successful horror flick. Alien, Jaws, Poltergeist are all movies in which most of the time you don't see what the characters are up against. The same with the original Haunting from 1963 in which you don't get to see the enemy at all, you just hear it.This suggestion of 'something's in here with us' has been totally annihilated in this version. Added to that the horrible acting performances of the cast except maybe Lili Taylor who delivers a somewhat credible performance.The only positive credit goes out to the CGI and physical effects people for delivering astonishing effects, but regrettably this didn't help the movie much, it even diminished the scaryness factor. It's these effects people that prevent this movie from getting a 1 instead of a 3.Better luck next time, Jan.3/10

This movie was one of the greatest movies ever made,,,, it had everything to make a movie great. Incredible acting, awesome special effects...... oh wait I must be thinking of a good movie. Well this wasn't one of them, it just plain sucked. What I want to know is, what kind of bone head would think that this movie was a 10. When I casted my vote there were 206 out there, god knows what goes on in their head. Now as for any other vote, a 8 or 9 was even too high, but a 10??? Come on, what made this movie sooooo good to give it a 10? I know these are the same 206 that thought that Jean Claude Van Damme is a great dramatic actor.

There are movies you don't remember because you have seen them many years ago, but most of the times it means as you didn't enjoy them. It's surely what happened with me when i watched Hantise for the first time ten years ago, i wanted to watch it these days for remember it.I remember it was scary so i turn off the lights and started to watch it at 11p.m. The first hour was good, many scenes are stressing for example when an invisible force hit the room door during night or when the head of the statues suddenly look at the girl sleeping whereas they didn't do before.The second hour was pretty ridiculous especially the special effects like the spirit of the householder which attack the main protagonist, Lili Taylor. Also, i'm disappointed of the acting of Catherine Zeta-Jones who is an actress as i like, but she looks silly on this movie and she more appears like a secondary role.Don't watch this movie for be scared, you will be disappointed.

The '99 version of The Haunting is not nearly as good as the older version with Julie Harris and Claire Bloom.  That was true classic psychological horror. The new version, however, does have a great House.  Hill House itself is the star of this movie.  It may be that people truly knowledgeable in special effects might not think so, but to me, just watching the house was enough. I enjoy special effects that are not blood and guts.  I can't even begin to describe all the things the house does, and anyway, I would not like to spoil it for someone who has yet to see The Haunting.  If you like really wild special effects, watch The Haunting, and I hope you aren't disappointed.
The special effects seemed well done.  The story got a little weak in a few places -- even a little corny. It's mainly an effects movie, not a lot of plot or character development.

Review title: A HUGE INSULT to Shirley Jackson and Robert Wise!!!!
Review_body: It always amazes me why Hollywood thinks that it can make movies that are better than the original screen classics...(for example, Hitchcock's "Psycho")...this film went no where fast and its use of special effects...an awful insult to Shirley Jackson and Robert Wise and the rest of the crew of the original film!!!! My score: 2 (out of 10).  My advice: check out the "Blair Witch Project"...a much more scarier movie!!!

Just finished watching. Don't even know what this movie was about. Very very dumb movie that has nothing to say. Supposed to be a haunted house movie ... it is but it isn't. Yes it all takes place in a big house but there's little to no haunting.Because of this, the movie gives the viewer precious little to care about.Expect far, far more from an A list cast and director. Just treading water here, they're making a movie simply because it can be made, not because it should be made.Can't recall who wrote the screenplay but wow -- it is terrible! An embarrassing effort all around.

The pace of this film was slow, and it wasn't really scary. The overall effect was kind of stupid and boring. If you want a much better film to watch on Halloween, check out "The Changeling" staring George C. Scott. "The Changeling" was superbly done, and fulfills its promise as a suspenseful and scary movie.

Review title: Who WAS holding your hand, Nell?
Review_body: Nobody. And then, "I won't let you hurt the children!"These two lines are perfect examples of how the movie fell apart in the second half. Mainly because there was no prompt for this iconic dialogue from the first film in the second one. No one was shown to be holding Nell's hand, or that her hand was in any position in which it would be 'held'. And secondly, she didn't hear the terrifying noises of child abuse in the dark. Being a remake of the 1963 classic, I don't think anybody expected it to be as good as the first. But still it was off to a promising start, with lonely, unwanted Eleanor against the glamorous have-it- all Zeta as Theo. Even Owen Wilson being Owen Wilson in Hill House was entertaining. Unfortunately, the second half nose-dived. They didn't keep up the motif of the desperate Eleanor with no home being hounded by society - except in that one scene in which Owen Wilson trashes her only legal possession against the iron gate (he gets his poetic justice). Instead of the house PREYING on Eleanor's weakened mind, the idea that Eleanor DID somehow legally belong with the house was pushed a bit too far (the woman wearing the necklace in the painting and Eleanor spewing a lot of ancestral details which no one can possibly verify there). That and the abundant use of CG takes away from all horror and leaves us with an adventure film with one horrible accident.Watch the original 1963 film for your dose of chills and terrors.

Pretty bad movie offers nothing new. The usual creaks and moans attempt to make-up for a muddled, but thin story.  Acting is barely above pathetic. Why Liam Neeson signed on for this is anyone's guess. Owen Wilson truly turns in one of the worst performances in recent horror-movie history. Catherine Zeta Jones is fun to look at and not much else although Lili Tayor did an above-average job. The special effects were fairly memorable and the house itself was breathtaking and hauntingly gorgeous.  However they can't makeup for the poor acting and the storyline which appears to have been thrown together at the last minute. Don't bother.

I don't know why the critics trashed this movie. I hardly ever agree with them anyway.The movie could have been a little scarier - I don't usually go to Horror movies! I even had to psych myself up to see it in the daytime. I needn't have bothered! ;) (The Cinema was full of kids too, heh! ;) ... Liam was great as always. I also liked Catharine Zeta Jones (Theo) and Lili Taylor (Eleanor-Nell)The house was very Gothic and beautiful in a spooky way. The special and sound effects were awesome. I also loved the music score, particularly the gentle tunes for Eleanor and her journey to save the children, how she grew out of her stagnant routine and life and finally gain her power, peace and freedom.

Just plain horrible... and the big disappointment is.. it could have actually been good! The special effects are outstanding! and that is the only good thing about this film.The entire movie does not explain it's self and keeps you wondering through-out... and the end does not fit... (But I will know next time when I want to distroy a ghost all I have to do is yell at it and it will go away....) Maybe, just maybe... if directors/writers of these horror movies.. would spend just a little more time developing a point for their acual charecters as much as the heep load of special effects.. then they might gain some ground and not make you leave the theater thinking ... 'was that it?'Bottom line... just dreadful.

1963's "The Haunting" is still one of the scariest horror films ever made. No blood, no gore, no special effects (except one) and it scares the hell out of you.  Why try to remake it?  Well, they did and, predictably, did a lousy job.  First off, it looks great.  The sets are incredible and take your breath away.  Second everbody (except for Neeson) gives out good performances.  This is particularly impressive when you realize how howlingly bad their dialogue is.  The story was (unwisely) changed from the original (I'm still not quite sure who Neeson gets them all together--it sounds like to test fear????!!!!!).  There are two HUGE gaps in the script--two other people are introduced at the beginning, one gets hurt, the other drives her to the hospital--and they're never mentioned again.  The second one: when they try to leave the house when all hell breaks loose, the doctor says only the caretaker can let them out.  However, earlier we had seen him unlock the gates himself!  Those two lapses aside, the dialogue is incredible bad.  I can't believe they actually let this script by.  The audience was laughing at the lines!  (Also there's a plot twist at the end that was so ridiculous, I yelled out "Oh come on!" and audience members applauded me!)  Also it's not scary.  The special effects are impressive, but you're always aware that they are special effects.  I only jumped once (when a skeleton pops up).  Let's see, horrible script, lapses in logic, ridiculous plot twists, nonscary...a must miss basically.  If you want to be scared, rent the original.  You'll be much better off.

Being a fan of the haunted house genre, when I first saw the teaser trailer in the theater, I was extremely excited. That excitement didn't last long. This movie was a ridiculous remake of one of the classic haunted house films, and I'd never recommend this. Special effects are not scarry. What you don't see but know is there is what will make people remember the story and come back time and time again. Rent or buy the original instead, it's much creepier.

It's a depressing affair to watch particularly talented young actors trying their best to toothpick through The Haunting's unintentionally funny script and dog-paddling in a thick soup of special effects. Whilst the film boasts a handful of unsettling moments they bear no excuse for the rest of the film's fatal flaws. Lili Taylor's constant bawl scream is unnecessarily frequent and is quite annoying. The characters are over-baked stereotypes - see Catherina Zeta-Jones playing a bisexual "free-love" artist. I found most of the characters to be so unlikeable that I was waiting for each of them to be killed off as soon as possible.

I saw this when it came out, but can't remember if I liked it or not. So....it's the Halloween Season, it's on HBOmax, what the heck, I'll watch it!Well, it took me 20 minutes to delete this horrible movie. The acting is so bad that it's laughable. Don't waste your time.

The Haunting perfectly demonstrates EXACTLY what the problem is with Horror films today. I don't think The Haunting is an unforgivably bad movie, it just so happens to make all the mistakes that most horror movies do, and is more obvious in doing it. You have a menacing setting for a movie, throw in a cast of actors that deliver empty and meaningless performances, and completely misuse your elements of "terror". The problem with The Haunting is that it actually does an OK job of building suspense and making the audience feel a little awkward and tense, but ruins it by the end. There are some decent sequences that visually work and in the end, do make me jump. Like the scene with the fireplace. That was pretty good, because you didn't see what was coming. We've heard it a million times. It's always scarier NOT to see something. Now here's the problem. In the last 30 minutes of The Haunting, they have the idiotic idea of SHOWING us everything. All secrets and mysteries are revealed, which takes away all intrigue we had, because like in every horror movie out there now, the whole movie has to be explained so in depth. Remember when Horror movies were great because they didn't always answer all the questions. And then the second major problem. We get a huge visual effects sequence that's supposed to jump right out at the audience, stun us, shock us, and blow us away. But of course, how can this work when there's no mystery or suspense anymore. In the last act of this movie, there's nothing to be scared of because you've now seen everything, and know everything that's been going on. Plus, the audience can't be shocked or terrified by a huge visual effects monster when we've pretty much seen it all before. When effects have reached the point they have, nothing is stunning or frightening to look at. Also, if we know it's a visual effect, there's nothing scary about it. The Haunting does a good job of building suspense, but throws it all away on a cheap and goofy over-the-top ending. Strangely enough, this review I just wrote could be posted for House On Haunted Hill, 13 Ghosts, Ghost Ship, or any other of the countless movies like it. Bringing me back to what I said at the beginning, The Haunting demonstrates what is wrong with ALL horror movies.But I will give Liam Neeson some credit. He had a really interesting performance, that unlike everyone else in the movie, he plays well. But alas, no matter how good a performance is, it's not enough to make up for cheap material. But I did catch myself flipping to this movie a few times on TV recently to see him again. That must count for something.

You've got about 30 minutes of a decent movie here before it turns into a loud, annoying, computer generated cheese fest. All the elements are in place for a good, spooky time - the set is gorgeous and ornate with just the right hints of creepiness, the cast (maybe minus Owen Wilson) is excellent, and the sound design is near flawless. It stays understated for about the first half hour before everything falls apart, but that first portion of the movie is pretty good.

How on earth was this achieved? This movie had an incredibly lush set, and one of the greatest sets for scary spookiness I can imagine. A case in point: the indoors merry-go-round with mirrors is the perfect setting for oodles of spook. Just seeing it for the first time in the movie made my skin crawl with anticipation of the great chills to be offered. Hell, just the jingly clown music made my spine turn cold. We are introduced to characters with a slightly forced depth, especially Theo, but at least these are three-dimensional, interesting figures. The stage is set.And so, it begins. And this is where the true miracle of the screen comes. This movie is completely and utterly UNfrightening. In a set like that. I just don't get it. It's a miracle. Give a monkey a camcorder and stick it in that set, and it would shoot a more suspenseful movie than this. How is it possible to create such a bland, boring, unfrightening, laughable piece of trash with a set like that. It's a modern marvel. My hat is off.

Review title: Better than it's score would suggest although not without faults
Review_body: This remake of the sixties classic of the same name has unfortunately been somewhat slated by critics, although I feel it's better than most people seem to think it is.The location work is stunning and the set design has clearly had a lot of work put into it.Liam Neeson, Owen Wilson and Catherine Zeta Jones all perform their parts quite well, but Lili Taylor is not as good as she should be. On paper she should be perfect for the role of Nell and for much of the film she provokes the necessary sympathy. She seems unable, however, to scream properly, instead letting what sounds like an animal cry. Also, she seems to say "Oh No" in exactly the same tone of voice every time she sees something frightening, although to be fair this is as much the fault of the script as it is hers.Towards the end the atmosphere is slightly diluted by such things as having the beds and statues spring to life which makes these scenes much less frightening than they could be.In spite of all this, this movie has a certain something that regardless of it's faults, makes me want to watch it again and again, and ultimately you can't ask much more from a film than that.

The first reviewer said pretty much what I wanted to, except for a few things.  The house looks nearly identical to the one from "Casper 'Friendly Ghost'" & "The Canterville Ghost" - The acting was not bad but not good either with a few over "exaggerated" moments.  The bedroom in which the spikes came down is a cut + paste from "Murder by Death" - All the scary scenes & animation were well put together and very believable. The cast was picked well except for Owen Wilson who was better in "Meet the Parents" then this flick! Out of 5 stars, I give this movie 3 1/2.  If your TV is plugged through your receiver, turn on the bass for this one!!

Review title: Not a horror, but still interesting!
Review_body: If you wanted a horror story, they tricked you. Happy Halloween! But, it still has a good story line and it's visually interesting. Compare it to Thir13en Ghosts (2001).

Review title: Some houses are born bad. Films are just made that way.
Review_body: The first scene in this remake of The Haunting is remarkably faithful to Shirley Jackson's subtle psychological chiller, but beyond that, any resemblance is almost purely coincidental. Jan de Bont's film is a gratuitous CGI-fest, visually spectacular but utterly inane. It owes more to television's Munsters and The Addams Family (both of which are mentioned) than to Robert Wise's eerie film or Jackson's novel, but unfortunately it is no more funny than it is frightening: any episode of Buffy the Vampire Slayer would beat it on both counts. Lili Taylor performs well as Eleanor, and Bruce Dern has a nice cameo, but Neeson is wooden, Wilson is miscast, Zeta-Jones might as well be a shop mannequin, and the computer-generated ghosts overact atrociously. It's passable drive-in fare, and would make a cute ride at Disneyland, but it's a clear case of too many phantoms and not enough menace.

Review title: ... And what a house it was!
Review_body:
To use an old cliché, if nothing else, this movie is truly a "triumph of production design". The house really is quite spectacular, beautiful, mysterious, filled with wonderful artwork - and lots of SFX.
While the 1963 version was very powerful in creating a "haunted" atmosphere, mostly by using the power of suggestion (using mostly sounds, special camera angles and creepy music, and letting your own imagination do the rest) here the makers took the opposite approach and pulled out all the stops in order to create a supernatural feast, truly making the whole house come alive.
Also very nice is the music by veteran Jerry Goldsmith.
So... is it a good movie? Well, I liked it. Was it over the top? Of course it was. And why not? What's the point in doing a remake of a classic if you're not going to try a different approach? If you don't like it, there's always the original...Check it out, if only for the gorgeous set design. A feast for the senses.

I was unlucky enough to be curious enough to see this film. At first glance at the trailer, it appears to be a sort of supernatural horror thriller movie, only to be sorely disappointed.The general storyline. Woman gets a phone call suggesting she sign up for an experiment in an old house. She meets a couple of other people (who seem to randomly vanish from the plot later without word of explanation) to take part in the experiment. Shortly after, strange things happen in the house, and things go further downhill (for the unfortunate audience).I first started to get suspicious when I saw the figures appearing via bedsheets, and somehow the main character doesn't find this remotely odd or scary. Later on, the house ups the ante, and I can't be bothered to further illustrate other than that the so called 'scares' are brought about by special effects (and not remotely scary), acting from all the cast is poor beyond belief - especially Lilli whats-her-face shouting 'you shall not harm a child' for no understandable reason whatsoever, and the climax seems to occur via something that wouldn't look out of place on scooby doo. All in all, I found myself inexplicably wondering why I hadn't wasted by time with a far superiour pile of cr*p. Like Freddie Got Fingered.Go and see paranormal activity instead. It is far superior.

The story is wild (in a boring way), the effects are good but simply not creepy at all and the actors seem to be as bored as the audience.The only tension I felt throughout this whole movie was when Catherine Zeta-Jones approached Lili Taylor with her sexual hunger. I was hoping for a little lesbian scene.You don't feel the evil in the house (which is a very nice house, I give the movie that) and without that, a movie about a bad house can't work. What does one need to create some nice horror? A bit of gore, some suspense, believable work of the actors, characters to relate to and an uneasy style. This was just a children's birthday party. Boring!

The title says it all. One cannot really call this much more than an "attempt" at a remake, as it fell flat on its face before it even got started.Perhaps the only redeeming quality of this film was that it featured Liam Neeson. The effects were overused or underused (depending on what point in the movie we are discussing), the characters were static (and Owen Wilson was horrible), and the attempts at comic relief were also a failure.4/10, for at least an honest attempt at making a remake of an old film which should never have been touched.

Never saw a bad movie like THE HAUNTING this year. Excellent FX and scary sound effects indeed. That's about it. First :Who cares about the actors? No one : Liam Neeson, owen Wilson and Miss Zeta jones might die,disappear, desintegrate... the story's still here, it can go on without them. Only Lili Taylor is necessary : do you call that a screenplay? Let's be honest, it's a symptom of screenplay. So D'WORKS needed name to sell this piece of rubbish called movie : let's take these guys, they might sell this good! (did they?) Second :Who Cares about the story? Why, why this need to rationalize fear, this need to explain evertyhing what's happening in the house, why can't people learn from what's has been already done? and WAY much better! Look at Robert Wise' THE HAUNTING. He just had the power to terrorize an audience without showing any ghost, without explaining the strange power of Hill House. The characters in 1963 had real motivations : they were real characters. The ghosts here are no the ones you expect. Jan de Bont piece of rubbish is no more than a wannabe-funhouse, totally useless, not needed, badly scripted and always looking for some more FX to keep you awake. Even the John HOUGH version of 1972 is far more scarier.Avoid that 1999 version  at any cost!

After reading a lot of negative reviews about this film, I found the time ripe to see and comment it too. When I look at the other films I've seen that Jan de Bont has made, Speed and Twister, I think The Haunting is, when looking at the screenplay, better than both those other two movies. But overall I think this movie is the second best Jan de Bont has made. Twister had a meagre story but never seen before special effects, The Haunting told a more developed story and had great special effects. Speed is still the best movie that Jan de Bont has made. The Haunting had a few very scary moments but wasn't as near scary as a horrormovie like Halloween, but maybe that's because in The Haunting a house played the leading role. The sets used in the film were extraordinary, I'd never seen such a beautiful scary house in another movie than the one that was in this film. Still, the movie had it's flaws. Not all the characters were well developed, the ending was a bit anticlimactic and not everything was as scary as it probably was meant to be. But overall a pretty entertaining movie (a 7 out of a 10).

Unfortunately nothing much happens in it.  You could take all the embellishment, visual and sound effects, add them up and compare them to just one scene in the orginal "The Haunting", - the "bulging-door scene" - and they would generate only a tiny sliver of suspense and terror that it did.  This will give you some idea of just how superior the original is to the remake.

One of the best movies I've seen in a long time!!!!!  This movie was sooooo good.  I went with a group from work and we all loved it.  It was the late showing and the auditorium was packed.  The whole audience got into it and laughed a little in the couple of humorous spots and jumped and screamed in the rest.  The acting was superb and the fx were top notch. (Done by ILM so of course they were.) :)  The story was great.  I saw the original a few years ago and it was great for it's time but this new updated remake for the 90's does make it even better.  I know not everyone likes it and of course the critics have given it bad reviews overall but hey, they're critics.  They wouldn't know a good movie if it came up and bit them in the a**.  :)  Face it, a good rule of thumb is, if the critics don't like it, it will be excellent and probably a block buster; if the do like it, then it probably sucks.  And excellent example is the Blair Witch Project.  They've given that movie top ratings and it REALLY stinks as far as it can.  Take the Blair movie and think "Plan nine from outer space" and you just be touching the tip of how bad that movie is.  But I digress.  Sorry.  GO SEE THE HAUNTING!!!!!!!!! IT'S AN EXCELLENT FLICK!!! :)

Review title: I was surprised......it was really scary
Review_body: I went into this film very skeptical. I figured that it was going to be a cheap Hollywood horror film designed to deliver profits and not much else. I was wrong. Though it starts just a little bit slow, once the action gets going it doesn't let up. The special effects used in the curtains and the stone creatures is fantastic. As far as spirits and ghosts go, it's no Exorcist, but it is a decent horror film with scares guaranteed to make you jump in your seat.

This is one great film. I was sooo glad that it didn't turn out to be 'scream' or other campy horro flicks, instead "the Haunting" will scare you out of your wits. It is very very creepy as strange things happen to insomniacs during the night. A very good plot outline and the ending was good too. i don't know why critics are hating it, but this is one of those movies that the audience like better. This movie had great effects and by far Jan debonts best movie ever. I recommend to all horror fans. This is extremely creepy.

Review title: Not Quite As Haunting As You Might Expect
