The special effects were pretty, but nothing groundbreaking.  The one shining star in this film is the prone statue in the fountain... now he's creepy!

The only two decent things in this movie ate Lili Taylor, whose valiant talent is all but wasted, and the special effects, which together are sadly not enough to make this movie anything but a waste. Catherine Zeta-Jones gets vastly undeserved star billing for nothing more than looking good, and Liam Neeson and Owen Wilson are uncharacteristically, painfully bad, even given almost nothing to do.

Review title: Entertaining up to the end. Then things got a bit silly.
Review_body: With nothing to protect herself against her dead great-great-grandfather, Nell resorts to witty retorts such as "Go to Hell!" and "I'm home, Grandpa!" to lure the evil spirit toward the gates of Hell.In the time tested tradition of ending a smart and scary thriller with a climax of gore and cheap one-liners, "The Haunting" comes " ---  this close to being a really good film. But like it's predecessors, can't quite close the gap.The ending sucked.  Sure, lots of people say the ending sucked about lots of different movies, but I'm not actually talking about What Happened, I'm talking about how it was filmed.ALL directors and ALL Screenplay writers must follow the golden rule of scripting.  Does this dialogue advance the plot?  If the dialogue was left out, would the viewer understand the scene just as well?  In the case of "The Haunting", I doubt Nell verbally abusing a ghost during the climax would qualify as necessary or even good dialogue.Pretend Nell didn't say anything during this key moment, and you'll leave the film happy, satisfied, and thoroughly entertained.

Maybe it was my fault.  I watched the original just before seeing this movie.  It's nothing like the original.  The original is actually kinda scary.  This movie....isn't.  The closest it got was an occasional startling moment or two. Those were just annoying.  This movie is Hollywood crap, Good vs. Evil. The computer graphics look neat but give to much away.  My question is why did they even bother.  Stay home and watch the original. You'll thank me.

Review title: Oh dear, oh dear, oh dear.
Review_body: Well, this movie just really sucks. Why does it suck? The plot. I just can't think of a story-line more boring or stupid. The special effects are all right, but nothing spectacular. Please, do yourself a favor and don't go see it. If you feel that you absolutely have to, wait until it's out on video. Yuck.

The Haunting  (*1/2 out of ****) Well, that's strike two for Jan De Bont.  I swear if they ever give Kevin Costner or this guy another movie camera, I am gonna be sick.  Well, after "Speed 2: Cruise Control", De Bont could have really used a push, but, unfortunately, this film pulls him back even farther.  This awful remake of the  1963 Robert Wise classic stars Liam Neeson as a doctor who lures three "ordinary" people to an old, allegedly haunted  mansion  to use them as guinea pigs on a test to see how humans react to supernatural experiences. Well, it turns out the house is really haunted by the owner...blah blah blah...yada yada yada.  I think you can fill in the rest, because we've seen it all before (only done better).  Unlike the original, this one relies solely on special effects rather than its actors.  Just like an old comedian's sidekick that sets up the jokes for his partner, it seems like the characters are just there to set up the house's special effects. Anyway, to save you seven dollars, the movie is two hours of excruciatingly loud door-slamming.  There, now you don't have to go see it.  You're one of the lucky ones.-Bryan A. Hicks

Review title: A Creepy, but horrific remake of the Original Classic
Review_body: It's all fun in games, throughout the movie. The acting was totally awesome, but the effects were outstanding. Great Film! **** A

Review title: A disappointment to say the least
Review_body: The Haunting is a visual masterpiece.  The special effects are phenomenal, and the images are very demanding; almost too demanding. Yet the film runs into a problem that many recent films have also encountered(in contrast to the technological revolution). The film is about two girls and one guy, placed in a haunted(literally) house, for the experimentation of human fear. As time passes, and the characters discover the horrible truths of the house, and the previous inhabitants, one of the characters finds a hidden and lost connection with herself and the house.  Finally she is able to free the house from the haunting ghosts and demons that had roamed the house for years. The film depends on the special effects to carry on the movie, which is a mistake to begin with. The most important part of a film is the script, which can be simplified as the plot. Not only is the haunting too dependent on special effects, and visual scare, it lacks a decent plot to accompany it.  A film cannot be good without a good script, but a film can be good without great special effects. Aside from these factors, the acting wasn't too great either, and the film also fails to accomplish one of it's goals. It isn't frightening.  The plot is predictable, which results in a lack of fear in the audience.  The film could have been a lot better, had it simply spent more time and concentration on developing a more believable and more detailed plot.  *****(5 stars of 10)

Review title: A complete waste of special effects.
Review_body: An English Teacher once advised me that no play or film is so bad as to have no redeeming qualities (this was after I had written a particularly splenetic and peevish review of a theatre workshop production of 'Macbeth'). Since then I have always tried to find something worthwhile in a film, no matter how disappointing...and 'The Haunting' is an extremely disappointing film.Set design and special effects are both excellent (although borrowing heavily from H R Geiger's designs in 'Alien') and, once again, Jan De Bont demonstrates that he is an excellent cinematographer.  However, De Bont is not a Director and, in the light of 'Speed', 'Twister', 'Speed 2' and now 'The Haunting', it is time for him to realise his limitations.The 1963 'Haunting' was always going to be a difficult subject to emulate. Robert Wise's production relies predominantly on atmosphere and characterisation, so important in making it a genuinely frightening film. The 1999 'Haunting', however, opts for computer generated images rather than plot development and, as a result, betrays its weaknesses from the outset.Incredulity is stretched to breaking point (who would willingly spend the night in a house like this?).  The characters are so thinly drawn that they evince neither sympathy or antipathy (this is a film Liam Neeson will want to forget) and, despite some pleasantly diverting shocks which send a ripple of nervous laughter through the audience, much of the film is so outlandish as to descend into farce (please try not to giggle when you see the portrait of the villain).In the hands of a better Director and with a more intelligent screenplay this film had the potential to be one of the best films of the year. Instead it is cliché ridden, predictable and, at times, boring.It is a piece of work which my English Teacher would have returned unmarked with a polite note saying, 'I think you should do this again.'

When I first heard of it, I wasnt interested in it. But I saw it about 6 days ago and I loved it!!! The effects and the acting were great. Not many movies scare me but this one really got my heart pumping!!!!! The graphics made it even more effective and after seeing it, I wanted to see it again!!! Liam Neeson has outdone himself again with his acting and well, this is going to be in my top ten greatest movies!!!

Review title: Go find the original - this remake is a grand waste of time.
Review_body: I was appalled - simply appalled - by this remake of the classic 1960 movie "The Haunting". Let it suffice to say that this remake has no atmosphere, has stripped the original of all subtlety and has been fitted with a pathetic all-too-Christian Hollywood ending. Don't watch it - go get the original.

+1 for the scenery, Catherine Zeta Jones when she was 30 and the Volvo.
The rest of the movie is utterly crap and has nothing to do with Shirley Jacksons masterpiece, except for the names.The ghost of Hugh Crain is more laughable then scary.

They might as well have called this movie "The Crapping". That's pretty much what they did to Shirley Jackson's book. They took a great story, hacked it down to its bare bones, and rebuilt it Scotch tape and gum. It's just so flimsy. All the actors are capable of giving good performances, the problem is rotten material.The filmmakers clearly underestimated their audience. They took out the story and replaced it with meaningless special effects. I've never heard of a haunted house with moving woodwork. The only real similarities with the book are some character names, and the name of the house. They changed the reason these people are even at the house. They added extra characters (but took them out suddenly, then we never hear from them). They killed one character that shouldn't have died. But maybe that was a good thing. He was likable in the book, but not here. The list goes on and on. All of it pointless. Just watch the Robert Wise version. It's much better and it treats the book with respect.Bottom line: Hear that sound? It's the sound of Shirley Jackson turning in her grave.

Giving this 3 out of 10 is being generous. Let me say first that this is probably what happened after shooting was finished and all the King's Horses and all the King's Men were trying to figure out how to put this movie together. Producer 1: "Let me see...the underlying theme in this movie is..." Producer 2: "Family! It's about Eleanor being the bad guy's third wife...or fourth, and she's pregnant...but not really and wants to save the kids."Producer 1: "The kids that died about 150 years ago right? Producer 2: "Yeah, the ones he used in a sweat shop...or was obsessed about...or something like that."Producer 1: "So he trapped their souls...and his...in the house...because why?" Producer 2: "No no no, they're stuck in purgatory b/c he's bad and can't go to hell right away unless Eleanor sends him there by yelling at him a lot."Producer 1: "You really think people will watch this? I mean OWEN Wilson is in it for God's sake!" Producer 2: "What if we re-shoot Zeta-Jones in some sexy thigh high boots?"Producer 1: "Sure, that'll do it for me."

Review title: Ready to get haunted? Not quite...
Review_body: I gave this movie a 4 of 10. However, if you'd ask me to rate Hill House itself, I'd definitely go for 10 out of 10. The only thing I truly enjoyed about this (fancy?) remake was the house, in my humble opinion the true star of the film.The acting was so-so (though Lily Taylor did a nice job, same for Luke Wilson) and the effects were not as creepy as they should have been for a movie that's rated +16 (in Belgium this equals the 'R' rating in case you're confused)... not to mention they look 'old school'. This movie lacks soul, and the plot gives you a 'been-there-done-that' feeling. Yet I bought it on VHS, because I simply LOVE Hill House. The sets are magnificent and it's best to simply not pay attention to the action or dialogues and feast your eyes on the splendour of the rooms and hallways. The Great Hall is my favourite: with its huge empty space, creepy statues (the lions above the fireplace are much scarier than Hugh Craine's portrait...) and the large doors which, *possible SPOILER* according to Theo look like Rodin's Gates of Hell are splendid examples of Eugenio Zanetti's talent.Other than that it can and will be a boring, dull ride...
This is absolute dross. You know its bad when Scary Movie 2 is better. Just climb the fence ffs.

I have not seen the original, and I am not much of a horror film fan.  The Haunting (1999) does not work as a horror film.  Rather, it works well as a light comedy with a few cool action scenes.  I went in to the film expecting something empty and poorly done, and I came out of the film having been well entertained by something the played like the tales I read each month in Fantasy & Science Fiction magazine, and having been very well done.  The viewer is left uncertain whether the happenings at Hill House are real or imaginary until very late in the movie.. and I'm not going to spoil for you which the case is!

Review title: Starts with a bang, ends with a whimper
Review_body: Okay, first of all, this movie is not the total dud that many reviewers have condemned it to be. The acting is sufficient, the pacing is good, and the effects are impressive. Quite honestly, the movie scared the living heck out of me. The letdown, unfortunately, was in its touchy-feely end, and left me feeling unsatisfied...the movie would have been much better with a more impressive ending. Kudos to Lili Taylor, the art director, and the special effects crew; jeers to the writing for Liam Neeson's stereotypical "The experiment wasn't supposed to go like this" scientist character.

This may be the worst horror film of the decade.  The story was sketchy, the character development non-existent, and the house a cartoony joke.  The scariest part of the entire movie was when the house formed eyes and stared down at the bed-That's it.  Personally, I wouldn't want to watch an entire movie for only one scare.  The computer effects were not in the least scary and at most startling.  And, while the actors portrayed their weak written roles as best as possible, still the essence of the movie drains through the plot holes.  A movie as strongly advertised as this brings down the entire genre when it promises great fright but turns out deader than the ghosts haunting it.

Review title: A little slow paced but a pretty good movie
Review_body: The movie The Haunting was a pretty entertaining movie but not an all around excellent movie.  I loved the House.  Hillhouse gave a creepy sense that makes it the perfect place for a ghost story.  The acting was very well done.  The computer effects were absolutely stunning. (it is right up there with some of the best computer effects I have seen in movies.)  The story however is somewhat slow paced.  That however is understandable since it is based on an older novel.  The pace does speed up for an all out spectacular ending.  I give this movie 4 out of 10 stars because although many people will enjoy this movie, I believe it may be to slow paced for some people.

Review title: The Haunting is okay, but differs greatly from original
Review_body: I am a big fan of the original film "The Haunting."  I saw it for the first time as a child and have considered it the most frightening movie I have ever seen.That said, it was unlikely that the new version could live up to my expectations, but I still had high hopes for it.  I was thinking that perhaps they would develop the characters just a little more fully than the original film.This new film isn't necessarily bad, but I feel that its major flaws are that it is too overblown and that it runs too far afield of the original (book) story.  One fear I had was that there would be too many special effects.  There were.  This story is one that relies mainly on the things that you don't see happen.  The fright is built on the sounds, the tensions, and the feeling that things are not at all well in this house.  There are only a few physical manifestations in "The Haunting" and these few are enough to convince you that something is terribly wrong without going over the top as they have done in the new version.As to its adherence to the story line, this version is only very loosely based on the book.  If they had not used the same character names and lifted a few lines of original dialog, it would be nearly unrecognizable from the original story.  That's too bad because, being regarded as a classic horror story, it's hard to imagine how the filmmakers sought to "improve" (?) on the original by changing it so drastically.Finally, while the original has a brooding ending, this film has a basically triumphant Hollywood happy ending.  Although I like happy endings, it just doesn't work so well here.jt

The Haunting's premise sounded good, but the lack of frightening scenes in the film makes the film boring. After a drab opening 20 minutes, the film doesn't get much better. The scariest bit is when a lump of coal spits in the fire (not intentional) It gets a bit better in the middle but then descends into total c**p at the end.

Review title: Why the Haunting was a horrible film
Review_body: The Haunting is a horrible film because the script itself is one of the most poorest written scripts I have ever seen produced.  I actually can't even believe some of those lines made it into the film especially the last 20 minutes or so."Its about family grandpa". I literally laughed out loud at the film.On the other hand, the technical aspect of the film was great.  The sets were beyond belief and the special effects were good too but the fumble here is a bad story!

This movie is very cool and exiting! The special effects is brilliant and the editing (by Michael Kahn) is perfect! The acting isn´t the best you can get, but it´s not bad, so it´s OK! One thing that makes this movie so cool is the sound effects! They rule! It won´t suprise me if The haunting gets an Oscar for best sound effects.I recommend this movie for all Jan De Bont-fans, and all other people who likes a good thrill!

Ok, it could have been scarier but there were bits of it that really did freak me out (like hiding-under-your-jacket-with-your-best-friend-clinging-onto-your-arm scared!)True, i have watched scarier films but its still a good film and worth renting if you missed it at the cinema.Had anyone else never heard of Lilli Taylor before this film came out or is it just me who's been living in a hole or something?

Review title: Like Comic Book Guy would say, Worst Remake EVER!
Review_body: After seeing a trailer to the original movie of this. I find this remake is insulting to the original and the great Robert Wise. The story is too Disneyish, that idiot Jan de Bont thinks he can do good but make things crap. The CGI is cartoon, Liam Neleson is really bad in this (and this goes as one of his worst performances next the Clash of the Titans remake), Owen Willson is so annoying that he makes you castrate yourself and this whole power of love thing is getting tired and makes me angry. And to make things bad, the great Steven Spielberg who was influenced by Robert Wise had involvement in it. But lucky after this abomination, he announced that he will never work with Jan de Bont forever and has the same thing as George Lucas has with the Star Wars Holiday Special which is prevented this film to be released on Blu-ray and it's a good thing Spielberg had his named uncredited in this awful movie. Which means that Steven Spielberg is the guy who said that The Lost World and The Kingdom of the Crystal Skull is okay, while this remake is the project is the thing that he is personally ashamed of. Let me repeat that again. The Lost World and The Kingdom of the Crystal Skull: okay. The remake of The Haunting: Personally ashamed of. My advice see the original Haunting it is more better, it has a good ghost story, great Psychology horror, has better character development and has no cartoon CGI, annoying characters, and stupid Disney good vs evil story in which piece of garbage has and should never be on DVD or Blu- ray.

Great comedy I mean Owen Wilson it was a grate movie not scary but when I talk to other people they say its so scary but I love the childs play movies in the same way FUNNY scream is ok I love holoween and Im a fan of vamps, witches, Werewolves and beasts both real and fictional I dont like Jason, Holloween or Fredy Kruger

Some people confuse the story of Hill House with the badly made movie "The Haunting of Hell House". The plots are very similar but the Shirley Jackson story is far superior. Jan de Bont could have made a delightfully terrifying movie but instead made a movie in which the special effects are comical. Stained glass that becomes eyes, ceilings that twist and swell. The set designer for this movie missed an opportunity to use available technology to scare the daylights out of us. Instead of a truly frightening house, we got a mishmash of tacky decor and comically used sculptures. The only element of Gothic scariness was the painting of Hugh Crain at the top of the stairs. The house looked as though it had been a project on HGTV's Designer Finals and the designers lost. The story, itself, could have been retold by de Bont, in a way that would put it right up there with the 1963 version but he chose instead to try and frighten us with cartoon-like special effects and a lackluster and disjointed script. Too much about the Hugh Crain story is left as a puzzle. But, the biggest puzzle of all was why de Bont wasted all that talent and money to give us such a disappointing movie.

This adaptation bears little resemblance to the original. This one is one "special effects" presentation after another. Some of it is actually pretty embarrassingly bad; the carved children's faces, for example.It's overacted and plays almost like a parody. Give it a shot if you're bored on a cold Autumn night. But it will probably disappoint you.

I enjoyed watching the actors and the music was good. The scenery was also quite fantastic. And I do enjoy watching my DVD version now and then. However, I also watch my other DVD of the original with Julie Harris, Richard Johnson, Clare Bloom and Russ Tamblin which was much more mysterious. I don't mean scary slimy bloody stuff they throw at the audience now to make money...I mean it was actually a good old fashion MYSTERY!!!! The house in this version was large enough to get lost in but they all seemed to have no trouble at all running around from room to room. Eleanor being a relative came out of the blue in a way that you weren't sure whether it was in her mind or not. If it was actual in this version, they should have had her find something to allude to it and surprise her! But I watch this version for the pleasure of enjoying the performances of the actors, especially Liam Neeson!

Review title: It would put an insomniac to sleep
Review_body: This movie came out when I was 11 and even at that age I thought this movie was horribly done. The acting is juvenile and lacks any depth or sincerity, the script is just pathetic, and the poor actors had to somehow make it a film that people wouldn't burn at the stake. It also contained hokey effects (the CGI was tasteless and you could see wires in various scenes) and many mistakes in continuity. The lead actress is as awkward with her performance as the actor who played Charlie Bucket in the original Willy Wonka. Half the time you just sit there wondering how on Earth they even got into a movie because the acting was so awful. I feel so sorry for the actors who took a career hit by being in this movie!
I love this movie. It is just a great mix of the bizarre and the truth.

It's pretty weird saying this knowing that the actors are now huge names in hollywood but the acting was just terrible...especially Lili Taylor. The actions and emotions just weren't believable at all. The story line was also all over the place, and left too many unanswered questions that typically needed to be answered to make sense.

Review title: Haunted house heavyweight KOed by dreadful screenplay
Review_body: If movies about haunted houses were judged solely on the merits of the houses themselves and their ability to awe and terrorize the viewer with a presence and personality all their own, The Haunting would easily be considered the best of the genre. Unfortunately, other ingredients like screenplay, plot, pacing and acting are not nearly as tightly constructed as the magnificent sets and production design that are Hill House.Catherine Zeta-Jones' character Theo describes Hill House as "Citizen Kane meets The Munsters" and I can't help making a comparison to the hotel in The Shining. Both are isolated grandiose dwellings with opulent interiors where within every shadow evil lurks. But while the hotel in The Shining achieves a foreboding presence Hill House goes much further, it becomes a character in the film; the star.The Haunting's Hill House is a vast brooding evil looking gothic structure (Harlaxton Manor in England) introduced to us in wide sweeping panoramic aerial shots and closer by liberal and skilled use of cranes and other visual devices that are breathtaking.  The interiors are equally immense complete with huge chandeliers, massive staircases, endless corridors and walk-in fireplaces. The set designs are rich, detailed and voluptuous, bordering on decadent; the ornamentation and artwork classical gargoylesque.Production designer Eugenio Zanetti put together a masterpiece of a haunted house and filled it with dread. The rumored price tag for the interior sets alone is eight million of the total ninety million budget.  Add a creepy sound track by Jerry Goldsmith and some fine sound editing effects reverberating throughout the grand rooms and corridors of Hill House and it comes alive.Not as much can be said for the screenplay, it contains the type of dialog you only hear in the movies. You'd think with a budget as large as this one they wouldn't have entrusted writing duties to new comer David Self who is unable to provide much dimension or motivation for his characters. The story itself departs just enough from the novel on which its based to create some major plot holes.A talented cast including Liam Neeson, Catherine Zeta-Jones, and Lili Taylor go through the motions largely because there isn't much to sink their teeth into. Liam Neeson, a professor who is conducting an experiment in the psychology of fear lead three insomniac volunteers to the isolated Hill House under the guise of studying sleep disorders. When things begin to go bump in the night and its clearly not the professor's doing the real fun begins.Zeta-Jones, one of the two women subjects, has little to do other than look sexy as the glamorous and confident artist Theo opposite Taylor's introverted soft-spoken Nell. We learn early on that Theo is bisexual but no sexual tension develops between the two women or Luke (Owen Wilson), the other subject who is basically cast to fill some space.It soon becomes apparent Nell is the central character and Lili Taylor's performance is more than credible given the material. She's in almost every scene and is able to convey her until then untapped strength of character as Hill House reveals its secrets to her in some truly scary scenes.As the climax approaches The Haunting bogs down under the weight of nonstop special effects that are clever and even original at times but if you recognize a special effect as clever and original the fx boys haven't done their jobs have they?Although the shortcomings are plentiful The Haunting is a very watchable horror movie. There is no question who the real star is and Hill House delivers where it counts.

Review title: I'm glad I ignored the critics and went.
Review_body: This film has gotten some terrible reviews from the critics. Ignore them. This version of The Haunting isn't the best scary movie that I've ever seen, but there are enough genuinely hair-raising moments in the film to make it worth watching. The acting was believable, with good chemistry between all characters, the sets were to be experienced, not described, and the musical score did a wonderful job of supporting and augmenting the action on the screen. Some critics go on about audiences laughing at the action on the screen. Well, some parts are intended to be funny. It was like being on a haunted house ride at the county fair, and should be enjoyed as such. Despite occasional popcorn munching and general clatter, the spooky moments popped up out of nowhere and definitely got our attention. When the spectre of Hugh Crain, the film's biggest baddie ghost, comes booming out of his 20' portrait at the top of the staircase, some of us almost came out of our seats! The effects in the final scenes are worth the price of admission alone. Don't let a lot of bad press and jaded critics keep you from enjoying this film. It's not classic cinema, but it's still an enjoyable ride nonetheless.

I think it's for the best that this movie is no longer in theatres, because it was absolutely the worst movie I had ever seen.  The acting was terrible, the storyline was bad and the special effects made the movie even less scary than it intended to be.  It truly is a waste of money.  There is no suspense in the movie; everything is all in your face.  If you'd like to see a scary movie, try any others but this one.

Somewhere halfway in the movie it just goes straight downhill.  The special effects were one of the redeeming parts of the movie, along with the acting of Lili Taylor.  The buildup of the story was done nicely but it became absurd as we begin to find out how Nel is connected to Hill House.  The ending was completely predictable.  There was also no real development of any other character asides from Nel.  The little subplot of sexual tension between her and Theo appears and disappears as quickly without much relevance.  By the end of the movie I was hoping that it would be over already.  If you don't mind paying $9.50 for a mediocre film w/special effects as its main feature then this is for you.

Review title: OK, but the special effects lessened the fright.
Review_body: A fairly good remake of the original film, but where the first film relied on camera angles and editing to frighten you, this one hits you in the face with special effects and leaves you thinking, wow, that was interesting. Effects, in themselves, are not frightening - they just make you decide if yes, it was pretty realistic or no, it was pretty fake. I found the first film creepy due to its lack of explanation. The remake was tiresome because it tried to explain everything and make the horror a physical entity. I'd give it a C+. It follows the first film fairly faithfully for the first half, but begins to misfire as the special effects take over in the second half.

Review title: It started out well, but ended poorly...
Review_body: This movie had a pretty good beginning and got you interested in it early. The special effects were good, and there were some tense moments that caught the audience by surprise.  The characters were likeable at first, and the movie had a lot of promise in the first half.  The house was very beautiful, and was the only part that remained good throughout.  During the second half of the movie, everything seemed rushed, it didn't flow well, the story seemed contrived, and you felt like parts of the movie were sitting on the cutting room floor.  The ending was plain hokey.  I was so disappointed, and gave it a rating of 4.  Good for ideas and imagery, but overall this movie is a let-down.

I don't even know where to begin on this one.  "It's all about the family." That has to be the worst line of dialogue ever heard in a "horror" movie, although this couldn't be a horror movie even if it tried!!!  Ugh!!! And I know that Owen Wilson is a better actor.  He needs to stop playing the token guy who dies in every action movie (Anaconda, Armageddon).  After all, the man did co-write "Bottle Rocket" and "Rushmore."  He does have some talent. Also, Lily Taylor should stick to indie films. She has no place here. Finally, Catherine Zeta-Jones should become a porn star.  There's no room in legitimate acting for her.  I'm serious.  One of the worst movies I've ever seen, EVER.

Review title: Good effects and interesting story, but horrible ending
Review_body: I'm not going to give anything away, but the ending to this movie was really weak.  It could have used a few more scenes that make you hide your eyes behind your hands too, but it had very good acting, great effects and a story that wasn't entirely stupid like in most horror movies (i.e. a rat bites someone and turns a town into zombies).  Worth seeing once.

My goodness! What a piece of sh*t! This film had everything that you think of when you think BAD movie. The acting was horrible, the script was terrible, and the CGI was WAY too overused! Cheesy lines littered the entire film from start to end and the audience found itself laughing through most if not all of the 'scary' scenes.Avoid this one like the plague (AHHHH! Cheesy lines spreading!)

90% of the way through this, I thought to myself that it's much better than I expected.  But then they had to ruin it with an attempt to put together some plot.  OK... the whole "we're family" thing was simply lame.  Great special effects ruined by cheesy plot and dialogue toward the end.

From the moment this movie started, I got the feeling it was going to be bad. And it was. The sad thing was, this movie got laughs, but not when they intended to get laughs.  Like when the phantom house makes a harp string hit a woman in the eye, the audience was howling, and a painting of the man who lived in the mansion looks like a cross between Jack Nicholson and a werewolf, which also got laughs.  The movie is actually quite good, until Lili Taylors character starts to begin to think she's 'been chosen to protect the children'.  Then everyone in the audience got restless, and you could hear alot of 'Aw, come on..'.  Another ill-thought out part is when Taylor asks Neeson about when he called her, and he says he didnt call. What, does this house know how to dial a phone and impersonate Liam Neeson now? Give me a break. If you dont have to see this, don't.

Instead of a creepy haunted house movie with no special effects, like the original, we are instead given a special effects extravaganza that is lacking in plot.  It's not scary, but is more unintentionally funny. It's pure eye candy, and very little substance.

Review title: Very scary, but not as strong as it could have been.
Review_body: While I admire the use of special effects to show us just /what/ was chasing the poor heroine around, and the suggestive use of dropped bits and pieces to let us know just /what/ had happened in the house, the biggest beef I had with this movie is that there were loose ends and muddied waters. That said: This is one scary movie. The audience spent a great deal of time clinging to their seats and gasping out loud. Several times they outright screamed. Me included.

Review title: Don't ruin the original by seeing this drivel
Review_body: I registered on IMD simply so I could rate this film.  I was looking forward to it from word-of-mouth, but was worried do to the director's past films (Twister, Speed 1 & 2).  Well, let me simply say it was horrible.  Not much spook factor at all.  The original one left such a horrifying memory with me.  It never showed any gore or ghosts and was all psychological.  Great film.  This one was horrid.  CGI everywhere.  Until they get that "glossy" look of CGI eliminated, nothing looks real.  Just the whole mood, acting, storyline, and "oh, geese" factor of this film ruined it. Ugh.

I saw this movie with a group of my friends. All the males hated it and all the females loved it. I'm not sure why that is exactly. The plot was thin, near nonexistent. It had a lot of scenes and shots that were "borrowed" from other flicks I've seen, but this movie does have a couple good points. I think the reason it had any appeal at all is because of the director's eye. There are some beautiful shots in this movie, and the imagery is superb. For instance, each subsequent shot appears to be darker than its predecessor. The appeal in this movie lies solely in its cinematic beauty. I personally recommend it as a rental, but not as a trip to the theater.

Review title: One for the alltime "Misbegotten Sequels" list
Review_body: Seldom has Hollywood produced as utterly wrongheaded a remake as this. Probably only the 70s KING KONG comes close--and at least that had a sense of humor. Shirley Jackson's original novel is one of the pinnacles of horror fiction and as for the 1963 Robert Wise film--it resides comfortable at the top of my list of the best horror films of all time. Unlike the '63 original, this year's model feels compelled to make all of its scares MIND-NUMBINGLY LITERAL. House haunted by the ghosts of murdered children? HEY...LOOK...THOSE 35 BUSTS OF CHERUBIC LITTLE KIDS ARE COVERING THEIR FACES IN CGI TERROR! Neurotic Eleanor can't sleep because her invalid Mom used to POUND ON THE WALL WITH HER CANE! Which her annoying little nephew GETS TO DEMONSTRATE FOR US!  Just like THE BANGING ON THE BEDROOM DOOR IN THE NIGHT THAT WAS REALLY SCARY IN THE ORIGINAL, BUT IS NOW JUST THE BEGINNING OF A LONG SLIDE DOWN INTO UTTER TEDIUM. If ever a movie was doomed to failure by the hiring of a director, this is it. Jan De Bont has displayed no understanding whatsoever of psychology or nuance or...hell, let's call a spade a spade...of acting in his directorial career to date. The whole project is an overblown and patronizing mess, only slightly redeemed by some beautiful sets.

I was looking forward to seeing the Haunting, being a fan of Catherine Zeta-Jones and of the typical ghost story.  I was hoping to be scared, but instead I exercised my eyes as I was continously rolling them.The first half of the movie isn't bad at all, the characters are introduced and the legend of the house are all laid forth. Then the last half of the movie took all of that potential and wasted it away with bad dialogue and cartoonish special effects.By the end of the movie I ended up disliking the only character that I liked from the beginning, Nell.  I'm not complaining, it was worth the 4 bucks I paid to see it...despite all of it's flaws it IS entertaining.

Tales of old haunted houses have always been a big kick for me and while this one might not be a classic it is a lot of fun to watch. The effects help tell the story rather than dominate it and the acting and characterisation draw you in nicely. The pacing could have been better but it's still adequate enough to hold the interest. It's not one to go see in a cynical or analytical frame of mind, just put the brain in a jar and watch - much better that way.

Review title: A sad, sad shadow of its predecessor.
Review_body: This movie has absolutely nothing to recommend it. The first half hour or so is mildly entertaining and because it sticks fairly close to Shirley Jackson's original story, it has a few chilling moments. Unfortunately, the entire second half is an exercise in trite special effects and writing that can only be described as sophomoric. None of it holds together and the ending doesn't make any sense at all. All in all if you want a good scare rent the 1963 film or read Shirley Jackson's fine novel.

Review title: What a waste of good sleep time!!!
Review_body: I can't believe I wasted $3.59 to rent this movie! I can have it for 5 days, but why let it collect dust in my house. It's going back today and I can't return it quick enough! I stayed up until 1:00 a.m. to watch this sleeper. I continued watching it thinking it would pick up the pace or actually do something to merit me spending $3.59 but to no avail. I am a big fan of haunting movies. I loved the original and rented this with high hopes due to the stars that were cast. If someone could tell me where to buy a copy of the 1969 movie "Whatever happened to Aunt Alice" I'd be thrilled...While not a haunting movie this was far better acted and much more scary!!!!

The design of the house is wonderful, too bad that is all that I can say for the movie.  The one thing that was creepy was the housekeeper, who reminded me of Mrs. Danvers from REBECCA, but her lines were so corny.  The characters were unbelievable.  Was she really scared, was she really wanting to help, was it all in her mind, and did it really happen? I tell you what this movie should not have happened.

I think the thing that people didn't like about the movies is that it was not scary enough.I have to agree with that.  It was not too scary for the most part.  The most intense scenes of horror only appear in the final quarter of the movie.For the most part of the movie "The Haunting" is a mystery.  The ghosts of the children keep on trying to tell Nell something and it is only when she starts to figure out that Hugh Crane takes control and the terror level goes up big time.I believe that people will like this movie better if they think of it as a mystery instead of a 100% horror movie.If you want a haunted house movie that is 100% horror go see "House on Haunted Hill"

Review title: Professor of the paranormal takes group of psychics to a haunted house.
Review_body: I use the original version of this film in school sometimes to show how scary effects can be created. This version is laughable. My wife and I recorded it from TV and then regretted the time we had wasted watching it. The effects are too much and downright silly, and in places downright ridiculous. Whatever Liam Nielson was doing in this film I'll never know. Some how, this film tells the audience too much and delves into the original house owner's life. By the end of the film, the suspense caused by mystery and ignorance is completely lost, almost banished. The set itself is quite good and realistic, but I found the relationship between the characters was thin in comparison with the 1963 original.

This movie is awful compared to the version from 1963. I don't have any other words for it.I saw the original movie on TV. The remake was some months later broad casted.In the original movie you do not see any ghost, no blood, no injuries, ... Nothing. The creepy feeling it gives you is physiological: is it really there or is it just imagination? The film is shot in such a way it overwhelms you. In many scenes (eg where Eleanore is running in the house) you always have the feeling that something scary is going to happen or pop up but nothing happens (except the scene where with the stair where Grace Markway opens a door - it scared me btw). Globally, there is not much physical "horror". But it is made so well it gives you the creeps. I went to bed afterwards and I could hardly sleep from all the noises I heard. (The noises are most probably always there at night, but you don't spend attention to it). It took me days before I could put the movie out of my head. What actually happens in that house. It does not give you an answer. To me, the movie has an open ending. The only negative is the slow start and the voice-overs (there are too many). I rate this version 9/10.This remake is the opposite. It is not much physiological, but all physical: you actually see the ghost, the things that happen do effectively happen. It does not give you the constant feeling something scary is going to happen. The scene with the stair is miserable. None of the horror-things in the movie (eg the bed that locks up Eleanore) gave me a creepy feeling. The film has no open ending (the ghost is chased off) except what's going to happen with the soul of Eleanore. This film must have it from the special effects. It does not scare you much during the movie nor afterwards.If you want to rent/buy "The haunting" please be sure you have the version from 1963 and not the waster from 1999.

I saw this film years ago and just watched it again as approaching Halloween I thought I would give it another go as barely remembered it.... I actually enjoyed it, not the most scariest film but easy watching if your in the mood for a spooky easy watching film!

What made the original so haunting and unsettling is its atmosphere, and its psychological effect on the main protagonist. This film, however, takes the whole psychological and atmospheric concept and replaces it with crappy CGI and a horribly written story. Since this was during the time when CGI was being exploited, I see what they were trying to do with this. However, its tacky that they should rely on new technological features on a remake of a film that was purely affective for its subtly. In terms of writing quality, if your expecting a film that dives into questioning the parallels between the paranormal and the human psyche like the original, be prepared to be disappointed. There is no mystery behind anything- this purely a light vs. dark movie. It's not smartly written what-so-ever. This being said, I surprisingly do have a couple of pros. (1) the mansion is unbelievably and gothically beautiful, and even more than the one from the first movie. The house they used is called Harlaxton Manor, which is owned by the University of Evansille for students studying abroad. It is the PERFECT setting for a Gothic horror movie. (2) casting is actually decent (minus Owen Wilson. Sorry bud, not your movie). Lily Taylor is actually a pretty good replacement, bringing a gentleness and gravity to the role. These two pros are what really makes me sad. With such an incredible setting and actors who can actually act (once again excluding Owen Wilson), and if they had just lost the CGi and stuck to the psychological story- this could have been a decent movie. Really disappointed!

Review title: Lousy remake, lousy film in general
Review_body: If you're looking for something really scary, go watch the original 1963 version of The Haunting. NOT this lousy excuse of a horror film.The only reason why I gave it two stars instead of 1 is because of the main cast. Liam Neeson and Catherine Zeta-Jones are great actors, and they deserve to be in much better movies than this. We've even seen Owen Wilson do better!Other than that, it just didn't do anything for me. The story, the CGI effects, and the attempts to build suspense just fall flat. There have been many cases where the remake is nowhere near as good as the original, and this is one of the best examples of that.

The problem with this movie is it doesn't know what it wants to be. It starts out like The Others, really slow, almost creepy (but not quite). Then throws that idea out and becomes a slow-paced and impotent thriller. Then away with that one; now it's a sap-fest.Whatever, this movie is lame. The effects are kinda goofy, totally ruin what little movie there would have been. Sadly, an episode of Charmed will stimulate your brain more than this load did.I gotta say tho, Catherine Zeta Jones is sure fun to look at. She's more convincing hawking cellular phones than she is in the movie. And is it me or is Lili Taylor really attractive in a jump-out-and-say-boo kind of way. I mean, I keep thinking she's not that attractive, but then I keep staring at her. I think I've convinced myself she's kinda ugly, then realize she turns me on. Wtf. Avoid this movie, it's a snore fest.

I saw this movie on TV, and I thought it sucked. I've never saw the haunting that was made in 1963, but it has to be better than this. I did not like the actors in the movie at all. I'm glad I did not waste my money buying this movie, its not even worth renting. I would rent the shining(1980)instead, scary, worth your money, and a lot cheaper. If you really want to see it rent it but if I were you I would just want till it comes on TV again. I have to say the mansion looks amazing, thats the only good thing about this movie. And I did not find this movie scary, so if your'll looking for a good scary do not watch this, like I said I would watch the shining. I give the haunting 1 out of 10. Do not watch it, it sucks.

Review title: Good, but could have been MUCH better
Review_body: I rented the movie in DVD and I don't regret for not having watched it to the cinema. It is a pure DVD-made horror(?)movie with some very good points and plenty of others which were either bad or improvable. The setting of Hill House was MAGNIFICENT: all the large rooms with all these carvings, statues and cherubims-work of art set an ideal surrounding for a creepy story to take place. I also have to praise Lili Taylor for her (although debut)very good and sensitive performance on the role of an ordinary woman with financial problems who realizes that her familial past has something to do with this house. I believe that she carries on her shoulders the whole acting level, although i also liked Catherine Zeta Jones and Liam Neeson. The picture was beautiful, the score adequate. That's it for the good part. Let's move on to the bad points. Although the plot and the past of the house is really interesting, the interest at the beginning expires after the first half, when the pure ghost atmosphere is replaced by VERY cheap, and goofy, and funny, and stupid, and uninspired special effects, clear product of the American comprised film-making.Some scenes are really funny, but I won't mention them:whoever has watched it knows. Owen Wilson breaks on my nerves as he is too cool and "I don't care about anything, I live in my own world" character, and I really liked it when the flue eats up his head!I also have to say that the ending was OH MY GOD!Just awful! Generally I expected much more. I will also watch the original movie and I hope this one doesn't "die" when I compare them.5.5/10

Review title: Had high hopes, started good, went downhill from there.
Review_body: I had high hopes for this movie.  Good stars, special effects, apparently a decent plot.It started good and good acting.  Slow to faster with special effects, which was wise.About 1/3 into the movie it just got silly.  I laughed way too much at this and I don't think that was the intention.  And as for the plot and ending --  I've seen better "Scooby Doo" storylines and endings.  Try "Sixth Sense - much better!

Review title: Not half as bad as people seem to think
Review_body: The early reviews for this movie were really lousy, but after seeing it, I don't know what all the fuss was about. If you want Oscar-worthy performances, and a storyline with no plot holes, well, then go elsewhere. It's a popcorn flick. But is it really, really bad? Not at all - for what it is, it's actually quite good and a lot of fun!'The Haunting' has a lot of eye candy, and the set design is just incredible. Many of the rooms in the house are incredibly imaginative and/or beautiful, and all of them fit in very well. And the special effects are just amazing... the house actually does seem alive! Most of the "ghost" shots are nicely done as well. Overall, this movie just has loads of atmosphere, as well it should. It's a ghost story, after all!As for scare value... no, it's not as scary as some movies I've seen, and it is NOT a horror movie! (Although I'm not sure what category it *does* fall into...) If you sit through it with a cynical attitude (as many critics seem to have done), or it takes a really twisted movie to scare you, then you'll walk out yawning. But if you just go with the flow, certain scenes will have you jumping. This is especially true since a lot of the fright value comes not from what actually happens, but the buildup it takes to get there.In terms of storyline and acting, it wasn't as bad as I thought it would be. Catherine Zeta-Jones has yet to prove that she can act (and I'm still betting she will one of these days)... though there were certain aspects of her character that, although good for a cheap laugh, could and should have been left out. Lili Taylor was completely likeable as Eleanor, although her character's actions and reactions didn't always make sense given the circumstances. Liam Neeson wasn't bad, although his role didn't give him much of a chance to distinguish himself. Owen Wilson played his character exactly the same way he did in Armageddon... and for the most part, just as badly. No one really stood out, but the cast did just fine in establishing the necessary feel... not trustful of each other, and overall, scared out of their wits. Most of the time, that is... at other points, they didn't seem to be scared at all when they probably should have been cowering on the floor.Overall, a very fun movie! You won't be making repeat theater trips for this one, but it makes a great one-timer. Naturally, the reviewers hate it... it's not "pure" horror, it botches a few of its jokes, and the plot has holes here and there. But if you like ghost stories and can overlook the potholes, give it a try. You probably won't be disappointed at all! I give it a 7 out of 10.

This movie has some great effects and a couple of startling scenes.  The storyline, of course, is far-fetched, but that is expected.  Liam Neeson continues to show his versatility, and Catherine Zeta-Jones is simply beautiful.  For comparison purposes, The Haunting scared me at least five times more than the heavily-touted Blair Witch Project.  I recommend The Haunting to any movie fan looking for a fright.

Review title: Despite what the critics say, I liked it.
Review_body: True, the movie may not be as scary and spooky as the previews made it out to be, but the plot was interesting, and the house was beautiful.  The exterior shots were amazing, and I've never seen anything like the interior before.  The house, alone, was worth seeing the movie for.  When you add the special effects and the "bumps" in the night, the movie is definitely worth seeing.

This movie was not Jan De Bont's best finest hour -- in fact since Speed, he has not had a great film.  It was not at all scary, it was implausible (with grown ups -- maybe if the cast had been a bunch of babies it would have made more sense!), and the cheesy lines definitely caused some audience rumblings... I would say save your money, but that you can make more of again -- so instead save your time, because that you can never get back!

The only thing haunting me is what else I might have been able to do with the $7 I spent on this movie.  The house is great, the scenery inside the house is great.  But why did they insist on simply re-creating all of the special effects from The Mummy? I'm sorry Spielberg and Liam Neeson are attached to this movie.  I'm sure they're sorry too.

Review title: Entertaining and, at some points, very scary film
Review_body:
I have not read the novel or seen the film from 1963, so it is safe to say that I, in that way, went in to see this film with an open mind. I had no expectations, just hope of seeing a scary film.
The opening of the film was not that positive. The dialogues were bad and not remotely interesting, plus the acting of the housekeeper was simply laughable. The other characters were not that convincing either. Thankfully the creepy atmosphere of the house takes over, and both dialogue and acting gradually improves (the actors never truly impress, though). The peak of the film is definitely half way through, and especially the psychological thrills I found very scary. You also get a couple of shocks, but, in my opinion, a thousand shocks cannot replace a well made psychological thrill. Unfortunately the psychological thrills are much too few in this film. Towards the last part of the film, the visual effects completely take over, which is very nice to look at, but not scary at all. So once again, as it happens in several horror/thriller movies, the ending lacks tension and thrills.
Hill House is without a doubt one of the most atmospheric settings I have seen in a long time. Only Bates' motel and house in Psycho and the Overlook Hotel in The Shining come to mind when thinking of more frightening settings. The fact that the house is truly magnificent as the setting just makes it all the more disappointing that it all ends up in a special effects orgy. Impressive as they may be, the effects did not scare me.
All in all an entertaining film that could have been even scarier, if they had put some more weight on the psychological thrills. Don't get me wrong, there are several scary scenes in the film, but also several soft spots. So, what is my conclusion? Well, an above average horror flick with the usual cliches, a decent plot, average acting, a couple of good scares and thrills, and, unfortunately, a sh*tload of visual effects. Definitely worth watching, though.
I rate it 7/10.

I'll be absolutley honest, I don't understand those that cannot stand this film. The cinematography was beyond what I expected, the special effects were seamless. This was the kind of film that makes me proud to be an aspiring filmmaker.So the characters weren't so deep you couldn't follow a line of dialogue, but were you expecting Shakespeare? So the plot was pretty much predicatable, but was Titanic really a surprise in any way?I was amazed at how much I enjoyed this film. Because I managed to let go of preconceived notions and let myself be scared, I let my imagination run wild rather than expecting the movie to do it for me. I slept with the lights on because I kept seeing faces and movements in the shadows. I used the film as a vehicle for enjoyment, and that's what it was. Stop expecting your movies to be James Joyce and let them be Jan De Bont. It's a movie, not a masterpeice. Enjoy yourself. If you're the type that goes to the theater to have a little fun and let go, you'll surely enjoy The Haunting.

The Haunting is a decent summer comedy.Wait!  Wasn't it supposed to be a horror movie?As a horror movie it was so horribly bad that the audience was laughing at scenes that were supposed to be frightening.  This movie breaks down into good special effects, terrible acting, and nonexistent story line.  I could go on forever but you or I need not spend any more time in this horse@%#& movie.

The Haunting isn't particularly frightening unless you consider the screenplay and the casting which waste the talents of the actors in order show off rather average special effects.  A Hollywood film from start to finish.  About the only good thing about it is that Adam Sandler is nowhere to be seen. Rent the original B & W film.

The Good: Good acting.  Good special effects.  It didn't rely on the unnecessary, disturbing gore usually accompanied by most horror flicks.The Bad: Too many of the scary special effects were shown in the previews, lessening their affect in the movie. The reason why the house was haunted and the climax of the movie didn't make sense.  Then again, a plot based on a haunted house is difficult to make much sense anyway.

Review title: If you hear "boo," it's probably the audience
Review_body: I wanted to like The Haunting, I really did. It's been a long time since I've seen a good spooky movie about ghosts and haunted houses. Most of the horror fare that's been released in the last several years seems to revolve around alien monsters that have a penchant for disemboweling or beheading hapless humans. The last good scary movie I saw of this sort was Aliens. So I was really looking forward to The Haunting. The cast looked pretty good. I'm not Liam Neeson's biggest fan, but I can think of worse actors to cast in role like this. This film showed a lot of potential. The story is intriguing, and the lead character, Eleanor Lance, played by Lili Taylor is very likable. I found myself more interested in seeing the story revolving around Eleanor (or Nell, as she prefers to be called) unfold than the plot that brings the characters to Hill House in the first place. The story goes something like this: Psychologist Dr. Jeffrey Marrow (Neeson) decides to gather a group of folks suffering from insomnia at Hill House under the pretense of curing their sleep disorders. In reality, he's bringing his subjects in to study the phenomenon of group fear. Thus, he's using this creepy old house to scare the folks. This brings us to the first problem with the film: Marrow's group consists of a mere three subjects. Two folks accompanying the group exit very early after a freak accident injures Marrow's assistant, who, unfortunately, of all the people present, seemed to be the most genuinely afraid. I still wonder whether or not the accident was real or whether it was part of Marrow's plan to spook his subjects. He seemed rather unfazed by the incident. There are several events like this that occur in the film, and it's often difficult, if not impossible, to discern whether or not they're a part of the Marrow's experiment. Director Jan de Bont could've used this ambiguity to his advantage to create scary situations, but he doesn't. When Eleanor and fellow insomniac Theo, played by Catherine Zeta-Jones arrive at the mansion, Mrs. Dudley (Marian Seldes), one of the caretakers of Hill House, states that she and her husband, played by Bruce Dern, don't stay overnight. They leave  before it gets dark. They never stay  after it gets dark. The whole thing is overplayed, and Eleanor even mocks Mrs. Dudley's spiel as she's delivering it to Theo. I was sure that this melodrama was part of the instructions given to the Dudleys by Dr. Marrow, but, honestly, I can't be sure. The characters don't take it seriously, and since the whole purpose of it would have been to set them on edge, it fails miserably. Thus, it fails miserably on two levels: It fails to spook the characters, and it fails to do anything more than amuse the audience. Owen Wilson, who plays insomniac Luke Sannerson, provides the comic relief in the film. He has quite a few truly funny lines. I found his character to be one of the truly enjoyable aspects of the film. His character reminded me a great deal of Hudson in Aliens. Maybe they should've cast Bill Paxton in this film somewhere. The best scary scene in the movie comes when Nell hears strange noises and jumps out of bed to investigate. Nell's problem you see is that she had so much of her life caring for her recently deceased mother that she's still awakened in the middle of the night by the sound of her mother rapping on the wall with her cane. So when she hears the cane knocking on the wall in Hill House, she reflexively jumps out of bed and says, `Coming, Mother.' This was the one spooky moment in the whole film, because we all know it's not her mother. The question is, is it Marrow's doing or ghosts? I suppose it doesn't really matter, but this is a part of the story that's completely ignored. Nell's story is the focus, and rightly so, unfortunately, it falls on its face after showing some early promise. Which brings us to the real problem with the movie-plot elements are far too often revealed in flourishes. I won't divulge any secrets, lest you decide to subject yourselves to the film, but instead of feeding the audience key bits of information a piece at a time, some elements are pulled abruptly from behind a curtain. I'm reminded of the scene from Independence Day in which the President states, after having had psychic contact with the aliens, `I could sense its thoughts. I know what they're planning to do.' I could probably have forgiven the overblown effects if the story had been handled better. If you want to see digital wizardry used more effectively to create scary situations and images, look at The Frighteners, a film that was not outstanding, but was certainly better than The Haunting. The special effects, like many other elements designed to scare us, were a horribly overdone. The house itself is overdone. The architecture, the elaborate mantle carvings, the columns, the huge doors, all of it is hyperbole. The most effective horror films are much more subtle than The Haunting. And the end of the film is the worst offender. De Bont decided to rely on big-budget, overblown special effects in attempt to bring this film to a shattering climax. What he actually accomplished was send the audience a clear signal in the form of a digital crescendo that their suffering was nearly over. All subtlety in films is gone. I think one of Eleanor's lines offers the best summation for this film. As she walks toward a door behind which she hopes to find the answers to the mystery of Hill House, she covers her nose and states, `What's that smell?' Alas, it's this film.

My first reaction to "The Haunting" was impressive: I was stunned by the brilliant camera work, acting, and, of course, the story and screenplay.When the main character reached the mansion, the creepy atmosphere surrounded me. I thought this film was going to be a masterpiece.On the other hand, the second half of the film is sometimes silly (but never boring) most of it because of the digital special effects excess.Finally, I must say that I enjoyed the movie but it would be more powerful if the spirits were suggested instead of being shown to the audience. I give it a 7.

I looked forward to this movie, because the previews had genuinely made this movie look like it could provoke a good scare out of me. I figured if Darkman chose to perform in this movie, it must have had substance. Unfortunately it didn't deliver on either accounts. Sure, the effects were cool, but the movie had nothing else going for it. It was 5 underdeveloped characters thrown into a premise that didn't make much sense, and the sense that it did make made the audience say to themselves "ugh". Nothing interesting comes out of this movie, unfortunately. For a movie with very similar special affects and a much more entertaining plot, go see the Mummy. You'll be glad you did.

Review title: The Best Of It's Kind In Years
Review_body: This movie takes you back to the classic horror movies of the past with a 90's technical twist.  This is definitely a A+++++ experience.  It keeps you riveted to your seat (When you're not jumping out of it)  Worth every dollar!  Go See It !

Review title: Very fun film, definitely a good time
Review_body: The acting was mostly pretty good, especially for Katherine Zeta-Jones and Liam Neeson.  Lili Taylor was a little too goody-goody for me, but since it was kinda required of the role, I'll let it pass.  The special effects were downright spooky.  The movie makes you jump a few times, but isn't so scary that your kids couldn't see it (also, no nudity or sexual situations, and no foul language.)  There's enough humor thrown in to counterbalance the spookiness.  All in all, not the best movie I've ever seen, but it's alot of fun and worth the price of your ticket.  I recommend it.

Review title: I thought at first it was a spoof on the horror genre, until I realized it was supposed to be scary.
Review_body: This movie was so bad I thought I was in an episode of Mystery Science Theater... but the little robots didn't show up! The audience (Boston, MA) could not stop laughing at it.  The only reason people did not walk out is because the tickets were $8.

My summary says it all.  The set was sumptious and detailed.  The house was made out to be the most interesting of the characters.  This is because everyone else had horrible lines, and were not given direction to aid them in acting.  It also hurt the movie that the story was poorly written.  It used every horror cliche' in the book.

My sister-in-law warned me when I said that my hubby and I were going to see this that horror flicks were not my cup of tea.  Well, this did not turn out to be a 'horror' flick.  Except for one scene (which appears in most 'scary' movies)of the skeleton popping up, I don't think I jumped at all.  The draw, for me to this movie, was Liam Neeson.  At the end of the movie, I felt very sorry for him.  Did he need the money?

What was this?! This wasn't scary, this was just souped-up CGI nonsense. The computer imagery ruined any subtlety the film used to have, and as for Liam "Wooden Horse" Neeson....We didn't need Catherine Zeta Jones to declare "HIYA! I swing both ways y'know!" and as for the ending.....Here's a hint - see the original.

What can you say? The film had many special effects and the head characters did it well, but it  was not that exciting as I thought it would be, although I was curious about what would come next. And it was hard to take the eyes of Cathrine Zeeta Jones.

Ignore every criticism you've read about this movie! This movie has great special effects and nice actors. I am a big fan of Catherine Zeta-Jones, so it was great watching her in The Haunting. The best role in this movie is for Lily Taylor. Her character is fun and interesting. I gave this movie a 8/10.

Review title: Special effects couldn't save a disappointing remake.
Review_body: The first "Haunting" is a genuinely scary movie. Special effects can be impressive, but a good story is needed to make the images cohesive. The new "Haunting" is artificially scary, all visual, offering nothing to crawl creepily under one's skin while watching alone on a dark night. It has none of the magic of the original Julie Harris / Claire Bloom movie. This technically wasn't even a remake, as the essence of the story was changed too much and overly complicated - when a straightforward ghostly mystery would have been much more disturbing.
Atmosphere is very haunting. Enjoyed until the last few minutes of cgi.

Review title: Not a Scary Movie, It's a Well Done Movie.
Review_body: Though I have never been scared at the movies I still enjoy the suspense and mystery of a well done "Scary Movie".The Haunting fits that bill very well.The acting is good, though I would say that Lili Taylor's acting makes the movie. Maybe her best acting yet. But all the actors did a good job and I'm pleased to see such main stream leading actors playing equal roles.The set is very well conceived and rich in detail which always helps the depth of a movie.Having not seen the original movie, I see this movie as a stand alone story worth every minute spent watching it.

Review title: Read the book, don't watch the film.
Review_body:
The book scared me, it's pretty terrific and I usually love watching movie versions after to see the book come alive on screen, however, they didn't do this here.
It's utter bobbins.

Review title: The Pieces Are Here Save For One
Review_body: 'The Haunting' is a theatrical adaptation of the Shirley Jackson novel "The Haunting of Hill House". Therefore, despite what some seem to think, it is not really a remake of the 1963 film. I myself have not read the novel, so I cannot tell you how closely this follows it. I have seen the original film, but a while back. I seem to recall enjoying the movie, but not the ending. I was always a "Happy Ending" kind of guy.But this review isn't about those stories; it's about this one. So here goes:First we are introduced to Miss Eleanor "Nell" Vance; a mousy, yet good-hearted caregiver. She receives a call from a Doctor David Marrow(Or is it?), who invites her out to Hill House, the estate of the late Hugh Crane, to assist in a study on what he claims to be Insomnia Research. He pays 900 dollars a week, plus room and board. She accepts (I would too) and journeys to the manor itself. Quite a home. The exterior of the mansion was Harlaxton Manor. The interior was most likely sound stages, for it was a bit too creepy to be real. What with spikes hanging over the bed and all.Nell meets the caretakers, Mr. and Mrs. Dudley, played by Bruce Dern (The 'burbs), and Marian Seldes (Tom and Huck, Home Alone 3). Mrs. Dudley gives Nell a lengthy explanation about just exactly how alone her and her fellow research subjects will be. "I don't stay after dinner. Not after it begins to get dark. We live in town, nine miles, so there won't be anyone around if you need help, we couldn't even hear you. No one could. No one lives any nearer than town; no one will come any nearer than that. In the night. In the dark." She ignores this not-so-subtle B-movie hint, of course. If she didn't, there would be no movie.Next she meets Theodora "Theo". (I don't remember her last name. She might not even have one.) Theo is a gaudy, brazen, bisexual cosmo girl, who is apparently attracted to Nell. (In spite of what some think, there was no deleted "love scene", just a slightly sensual scene leaving Theo's attraction to Nell undeniable. Read the script for further info.) Next comes Luke Sanderson, the boyish cynic with the dry wit. And finally, Dr. Marrow. After dinner, some drinks, and a bedtime story involving the house's haunted past, Marrow explains his goal: OK, so why are we here? Probably to answer the most basic question: "What is wrong with you people?" After a pretty much unnecessary scene where Marrow's assistant gets slashed with a piano wire, and taken to a hospital, never to be heard from, or of, again, we descend into the pit of Hell, I mean Hill, House, and watch as the main characters get chased by ghosts, spooked by specters, and haunted by haunts. Think 'The Haunted Mansion'. But, we mainly get barraged by some of ILM's special effects. Which are quite good, I think. Scenes that stand out for me include a ghostly scene involving a ghost traveling through and under a bed sheet and curtains (you really have to see it), and scenes with hands reaching out of walls. (Those are always cool) And, of course, a breathing ceiling.When I started watching, I thought to myself "Jerry Goldsmith would be perfect for this movie. To my pleasant, he did compose the music. What more can I say. It's awesome. The sound effects are also very good; a 5.1 speaker viewing is recommended.The movie's errors lie in the screenplay itself, which is plagued with plot holes and corny lines. It's as if there were no rewrites. The screenplay is obviously the most important factor in a movie, so I am forced to give this film 6 stars out of 10 stars. Extremely fun to watch, and listen to, but that's about it.

While I suggest that everyone go out and read the Shirley Jackson novel form which this movie originated (The Haunting of Hill House), the movie is not quite up to par. Don't get me wrong, it's not bad...I'd rather watch it than not. But let's just say that the book was much better done...not to mention that I was dissapointed that the film was not entirely accurate, although the casting was great! The actors and actresses were exactly who I would have picked out of a photo line up. All in all, an okay movie.

I saw this movie a while ago and thought it was really scary. I'm watching it again and I know I will see things I didn't before. Bruce Dern is a real quirky character even tho he is only in the movie for a hot minute."I don't stay after dinner.....not after it begins to get dark....I leave before dark comes....we live in town....9 miles so there won't be anyone around if you need help....we couldn't even hear you at night...no one could....no one lives any nearer than town....now one will come any nearer than that...in the NIGHT, in the DARK."Adore this movie!!!

Cant tell the details cause this is a must see movie... Lets just say its a must see scary move... Best actors... Best suspense... Best filming... Catherine Zeta-Jones is at the top of her game in this one... She shows her tremendous diversity again and shines... Owen Wilson shows the beginnings of his great career... We are treated to a roller coaster of fear and flight in the traditions of the greats with this one... Just when you have it pegged hold on you will never know the real story... Cuddle up with your sweetheart hold each other tight and prepare to scream... Keep your feet off the floor, and be brave... Don't miss it...

Review title: Who cares about some stupid old black and white movie, anyway?
Review_body: With all the really crappy movies out there like Suspira, Last House on the Left, the Last Man on Earth, and the Blair Witch Project, I just don't understand why everyone tore this movie apart so bad.I do understand that it was a remake of a widely admired classic, but to tell you the truth, I don't think I knew a single person who had even seen the original to this until this was released. Now, everyone I know has seen the original. So even the haters in the world should understand the power of this remake. There are horrible movies out there. Why dog this one? It was fun. It was scary in places. It had a good, tense feeling all the way through, and I completely enjoyed it. And yes. I saw the original, but I still like this one better. It was scary AND fun. Who cares about some stupid old black and white movie, anyway? The original is a 4/10. The remake (this movie) is a 9/10.

Review title: A lesson in stripping down the original.
Review_body: The television of Saturday evening. Am I glad this was not something I paid for! "The Haunting" must be one of the worst 'reading' of an old masterpiece.As viewing the original before the remake, I pretty much knew the story and the intense scenes to watch out for. A fun cast is the positive thing to begin with, the acting was mediocre but I really developed a 'relationship' with all characters in the film. The movie, had its moments. The ghost chasing Nell through the building being the thrilling scene. Just that this thrilling scene did not come over as horror/thriller at all. It truly gave me the feeling I was watching a fantasy film, for instance "Lord of the Rings" even. Luke's death must have been the biggest injustice against the original and was the biggest anticlimax in a movie ever, him being the funnest character. The whole confrontation of 'Nell' and the Ghost only gave a bigger feel of fantasy film. 'Nell' dying the death she did die, is the absolute no-no.The original was so much better than this weak remake. It was not bad, and it had its moments, but it lost the complete mood of the original. The whole ending was different, and it did not do the film good at all. Watching this makes the remake of 'The Birds' even more disappointing than it already is. Let's all remember the great originals and forget the remakes, as soon as you possibly could.

Review title: Too much well lighted detail, not enough suspense.
Review_body: A misguided researcher tricks a group of insomniacs into taking part in an live-in experiment to be conducted in a haunted castle built by a nineteenth century tycoon.If there is a fatal error that a director with a strong background in cinematography can make when doing a gothic horror flick, it's to use elaborate scenes and light them so that the screen is always full of ornate detail.  Highlighting just the spooky visual elements  would have created a better sense of creepiness.  The Pit and The Pendulum or some original black and white Frankenstein films are works in which one can find what isn't in this movie: a good dose of visual Poeism.The old castle is intriguing but too orderly and well kept to evoke the sense of impending doom that this movie desperately needs.  A few well placed cobwebs and some appropriate moldiness might help but It doesn't happen in this film, nor do the elements of tension and suspense develop.Instead Jan de Bont puts all his money on effects and a weak script with a formulatic and flawed plot (in the beginning of the action characters are introduced only to unexplainedly disappear from the rest of the story.)The only thing new in this movie might be some special effects techniques, but the days of relying on effects to satisfy an audience are numbered. Producers had better get back to thinking about stories and scripts.

this is by far the worst movie i've seen this year.  It had huge potential but just completely sucked.  the set was really great and the special effects were good.  other than that it was awful.
