Owen Wilson's was the only likeable character.  the over-acting was very silly.  the idea may be from the book, but not all books are meant to be made into movies.  little is explained about the house's builder, other than he wanted kids and ended up taking some from his factories.  they they mention he won't let them go even in death, and we're supposed to be scared by that. how can you call someone a villain when all you know about them is that they played hide and seek with the kids they won't let go.  they should have used those special effects to computer-generate a decent story.  on a scale of 1 to 10, i give it a 2.

Review title: This film had me wishing that I had something sharp to poke my eyes out.
Review_body: This movie has the most inane plot idea, wasted performers and effects we've all seen at least twice before. The money was all in the sets.........but the house was a caricature just like the actors.I don't think there was one redeeming feature that three of us could find. Could the empty theatre at a 7 pm show be a hint of how awful this celluloid dreck was?

This movie disappoints in almost every area. The plot line has serious holes, the writing and direction show no imagination. The movie seemed to me much like an extended "Potergeist" television episode. I can't even recommend seeing this movie when it is released on video.

Hoping for a nice warm-up for Blair Witch, some friends and  got together for a late-night showing of the Haunting. Unfortunately, the only thing scary about this movie was the script. Certain characters knew too much and some knew too little, but they all had one thing in common: bad lines. This movie is chock full of bad jokes and poor attempts at horror. I've never seen an audience react to a movie as they did to The Haunting. I must admit that I got more pleasure from the jeers and laughter than the movie itself. Please do yourself a favor and see this during the matinee. I'm giving it a "2" for visual effects, its one saving grace. Man, this movie stinks.

Review title: this movie gets one big boo!
Review_body: some houses are born bad, and some movies are bad, like this one.  the special effects can't make up for a stupid plot and lame acting. the jedi council must be frowning on Liam Neeson. go rent the shining instead and get a real scare. come play with us danny, forever and ever!!

This movie is a terrible remake of a wonderfully frightening classic. They took a film that used the audiences own fear and used them as the tools of fear.  In this film they replaced fear with an overuse of computer generated ghosts.  The only thing I found truly scary in this film was the writing.  I especially enjoyed the line where Eleanor proclaims "I'm home grandpa!" If you want to be scared this summer see Blair Witch or see the original.  This movie goes down as the biggest waste of my time this summer. An F- all the way to the credits.

Review title: Thrills and chills without blood spills
Review_body: Well, as promised they did pull it off.  The Haunting really isn't one of the biggest shockers to hit the big screen, the great part, is there's finally a modern horror movie that can pull off at least a bit of a scare without a fountain of blood. With bloodbaths like Carrie, The Excorsist, and more, I think its gratifying that Jan De Bont made a horror film that almost everyone can see.Bad points include that the movie has an incessant banging throughout the entire film, and, some of the scares are really destroyed by shots of fat statues of children with terrified looks on there faces.A real SFX explosion, recommended.
At a time when horror films seem to be making a comeback, this film is slightly above average. No too much gratuitus gore, a few surprising scenes, and a good sense of eerieness.

Talk about an ending that doesn't follow the written one. The screenwriter took more liberties with Shirley Jackson's novel than I care to count. Instead of hinting at the steady decline of Eleanor's sanity, the movie throws it smack in your face, adding and killing off characters, creating new plotlines that at times make sense and at times are as unbelievable as the finale. A horror film it may be, but it lacks all of the subtlety of the original work.

The Haunting had alot of good things going in its favour. For instance, the perfect setting of an old house, a shady history of a strange previous owner and a group of hapless people who have no idea what's about to happen. But sadly, none of these aspects are used to its fullest potential. It seems that through-out the movie there is a sence that it was made for the younger generation rather than the almost unshakable older crowd. And this is a problem. Because its aimed at younger people (and to acheive its PG type rating) the scares are extreamly subtle and the suspence and gore are practically non-existant. You can't help but think what type of movie it could have been if differant producers and a differant director were involved.The horror (if you can call it that) is mostly made of sound effects and CG soaked imagery. The CGI is another problem. It's so in-your-face and glossy that it looks out of place. Hollywood, it seems, needs to take a leaf out of the Blair Witch Project book. Much more could have been done here if simple suggestion was used instead of a barrage of technology.On the plus side of things, the preformances are fairly good. Liam Neeson gives his usual above average and Catherine Zeta Jones seems extreamly comfortable with her caracter. Lili Taylor, however, fell foul of the script writer. Her's is the deepest caracter here. There was enough scope to write a brilliant piece of script, but alas she is only 2 dimentional. Her climactic scenes are almost laughable.To sum up, The Haunting is a poor effort of a story that had so much potential. The kids will love it, but the older generation will be dissapointed. One only hopes that the director, Jan De Bont, is given back the freedom of film-making he had when he directed Speed.

Review title: Worth seeing in theatres, but only barely.
Review_body: This movie has all the makings of a so-so interpretation of a really good book.  I haven't yet read the book myself, but there are certain tell-tale signs in the movie pointing towards a plot that the movie itself doesn't get into.Basically, the special effects and the cinematography were what saved this movie.  The house where it takes place is breathtaking, and the visual effects were tastefully done until the end, where they made the mood way too cheesy to stomach.  The plot, as I've already mentioned, is interesting but far too unfledged to be reason enough to watch this movie.  The characters are well played and absolutely see-through, indicative of poor screenwriting mixed with good acting.So to sum up, I thought that the eye-candy was worth the money, but if you want the more intellectual side to this story--read the book.

Review title: Great cast, sets, and effects add up to Summer popcorn fun
Review_body: Lavish sets, playful effects, another great Jerry Goldsmith score, and a delightful main cast made this Fun-House Thrill-Ride my favorite "Summer Movie" in many years.  While it doesn't achieve the "Great Movie" status for richness of story and characters, like say Good Will Hunting or As Good As It Gets, it's not supposed to!  This is Summer, time to chuck reality and have some fun at the theater!  This is a theater-experience movie, with sound that rumbles your seat, and eye candy to fill every inch of the big screen.  It's what makes you want to go over and over again because it won't be the same when it comes to video.  I've heard so many poor reviews of this movie and some people say it's not scary, but they are all missing the point: it may not be scary, but it's thrilling and fun; good old fashioned popcorn fun.  I also like the liberties they took with the original story, which gives it a life of it's own.  It's a good balance of having enough the same and enough different to keep it fresh and exciting.  So, in my book, it gets top honors for a Summer Thrill Ride. [9 out of 10] [****] [A]

If you enjoy the absolute WORST movies that have been featured on Mystery Science Theatre 3000, then you may want to consider seeing "The Haunting"... that is, if you can find a way to see it without spending money. From start to finish, "The Haunting" was one of the worst movies I have seen, including those on MST3K. There was no suspense at all, as the movie repeatedly told you everything that was going on. Nothing was scary, since when something potentially scary occured, you could see it coming from a mile away.  And when someone was killed, it was generally very funny, not scary. Furthermore, the director had some bizarre obsession with constantly showing closeups of Owen Wilson. That, combined with the laughable acting and extremely obnoxious character Mr. Wilson played, had me screaming for his character's death the instant he appeared in the movie. This was a very poorly written and a very poorly directed movie. I admit the CG effects were neat to look at, but that doesn't make a movie.  Neither does casting Qui-Gon.  Indeed, I think that is the only reason Liam Neeson appeared in the movie... in attempt to milk success from Star Wars.  Had the movie pursued what appeared to be a potential relationship between Catherine Zeta-Jones and Lili Taylor, it may have been watchable. But alas, the focus was on a convoluted, nonsensical... something... that may remind one of a plot. I give this piece of dung 1/10th star (and the CG was what give it that).

Come on people,are we getting so critical that we don't know how to enjoy a movie without nit-picking every detail? This movie did the job and was a scary movie if you let it be,the person I was with said "It's only a movie so how can it scare you if you know it's all fake?"Well if that's the attitude we are going to take we might as well stop going,Come on relax and start enjoying things again,I did.

The 1999 remake of The Haunting is one of the finest films i've ever seen. Critics have been slamming this film left and right,and it's taught me what I suspected all along. Critics ' words should be taken with a grain of salt. The critics seem to not understand this movie isnt supposed to be scare you out of your seat ,it's all psychological terror. I think the movie also gets unfair treatment because it's a remake of an older film. Before listening to what the papers say about this movie,just remember that Star Wars was called an unoriginal,horribly bad movie.

Review title: Another triumph for Dreamworks special effects
Review_body: The people at Dreamworks have once again created a film that incorporates spectacular special effects.  Just the house itself is a marvel to behold, let alone the amazing events that occur before your eyes.  The Haunting is yet another example of where motion pictures are headed to in the 21st century.  Combining a suspenseful storyline with unnerving visual effects makes for a memorable experience.  Although the overall plot suffers from some serious deficiences, including a rather abrupt ending, the stunning visual effects manage to suspend this picture from an otherwise average review.

This was a TRULY amazing movie.  I highly recommend it!  Its got great acting (especially from Lili Taylor), awesome effects and stunning production design.  But all the kudos should go to director Jan De Bont for combining all these elements and more into a thrill ride that doesn't stop. It has funny moments without being corny, it is scary with about being gory and it is dramatic without being boring!!  All horror films should aim for this high level of filmmaking craftsmanship.  The pacing is perfect - the FX don't overwhelm you, they slowly increase to build your suspense and amazement.  I literally jumped out of my seat and had my mouth hanging open several times.  In the horror genre, this movie is head & shoulders above all the other recent films like SCREAM, etc.  I always thought horror movies were mostly dumb, but this movie can be summed up in one word: SMART.  It harks back to classics like THE SHINING where psychological horror was better than pure gore.  And that, I think, is the ultimate compliment!!

Review title: Save your money and go see Blair Witch Project...
Review_body: My friends and I went out with high hopes of seeing the Blair Witch Project but after finding it sold out had to settle for this film.  Many patrons were simply walking out when they found the Blair Witch sold out and I wish we'd done the same.The plot of this film has nothing holding it together.  From the second scene the film has no flow.  I don't know how anyone could have read this script and not seen how bad this film was.  The main focus of the story is completely uninteresting and predictable.  The story of the house and it's history is the only interesting element of the film but unfortunately we don't hear enough of that story to make it even remotely interesting.  There are a few scenes with special effects which are somewhat interesting but they don't save the film.  Thirty minutes before the film was to end I was ready to walk out.  The plot had just completely disintegrated and the film had lost what little coherence it had.The next day we did get in to see the Blair Witch Project and it with it's tiny budget and zero special effects blow this movie away.  Out of 10 I give this film a 3.

Review title: More of a comedy then horror film
Review_body: This is one of those movies that will always live on friday nights on the USA network. It's definitely filled with over done special effects.  This film is more of a spoof of the old haunting then a remake.  Although i was entertained with comedy and special effects this movie lacks any power. Stay away until video.

This remake of the original 1963 film, The Haunting, is a disappoint to fans of the original.  It was a mediocre film, with Hollywood flare of "scary" special effects.  You expect to be scared, but end up laughing.  It was a big let down.

Review title: Effects heavy but none of the psychological fright of the 1st
Review_body: It's still amazing to me that, with all the technology Mr. DuBont had at his disposal, the scariest part of the movie was a skeleton that jumps out.... If you are looking for a great interpretation of Ms. Jacksons book... Get the original.  Looking for an example of what you can do with some good computers now days, see this one.

despite the critics, i really liked the movie...plus it had liam neeson in it, can't go wrong there....the acting was decent, the effects were cool (got a little sick of the 'eleanor help us'), the end was a little weak but i'd see it again!!!!!  don't let the critics fool you, judge for yourself, and know that mr. showbiz is full of it!!!!

This is horrible.  All of the actors seem out of touch, the scares rely way too much on CG, the ending is terribly lame, and it's too long for it's own good.  I've seen some pillows creepier than this.  Don't waste your $8.

Although the makers of the Haunting claim that it is based on the classic, "The Haunting of Hill House", the only thing the two have in common is the names of the characters.  I could live even with this if the movie hadn't had such a cheesy ending.  Why do Hollywood folks seem to think that movies must have some sort of happy ending?  The original story was a tragedy, and it's been turned into some god-awful redemption and salvation story.  I'll give it this much, the interiors were creepy.  That was ruined, though, by all the CGI crap.  I think CGI is great, but I'm afraid that CGI is taking the place of story and camera work.  "The Blair Witch Project" had no effects, no fancy equipment, and it still scared the crap out of me.  As a plea to filmmakers, please don't assume we won't like the movie unless we can see everything!  Sometimes what isn't seen is the most effective.

Review title: See the old movie or read the book.
Review_body: The movie started out great, the key phrase being "started out".  The scene of Zeta-Jones and Taylor's exploration of the house was as eerie as the author had originally intended it to be.  But when the special effects kick in, the film maker's misunderstanding of the term "less is more" is obvious. It also seems quite possible that they haven't read the book or seen the old movie either, judging by most of the plot line.  If you're looking for a good scare, don't see this movie.  Instead, spend $3.75 to rent the old one. Or event better yet, get the book from the library.  I guarantee the hair on the back of you neck will be standing on end from start to finish.

Critics are over rated in themselves.  I have no idea why anyone could not like this movie.  The acting was good, effects were great, and in a certified Dolby Digital DTS (the newest sound like used in SW Episode 1) the sound kicks some major ass!  Go see it in a good cinema while you still can!

Review title: Low on horror but great summer fun
Review_body:
I saw The Haunting the night it opened and I loved it. Let me say that I'm a horror fan in general, and I prefer a good ghost story to a hack and slash movie anyday. Still the Haunting had very few scary scenes.  It is not in league with "The Shining" or even "Burnt Offerings".  That aside The Haunting had an interesting story, great music/sound, good FX, and the coolest mansion even filmed.  Indeed the house is the star of the film (as it should be). For haunted house fans it's worth the price of admission alone.
The movie has some faults, but most are minor.  A lot of reviewers note the cheesy dialog, but the truth is that there are only about 2 or 3 bad lines in the whole picture ("home is where the heart is" & "it's about family" being the worst).  Not enough to ruin it by any means.  The acting is top rate.  Lili Taylor (as Eleanor) is fantastic, but Catherine Zeta Jones seems to steal every scene she's in (doesn't she always).  Liam Neeson is somewhat wasted as the doctor conducting a study on the other three.
A major complaint I hear a lot is that only Lili Taylor's character is really developed.  True, but so what.  Do you really need to know everything about a character in a movie.  The Haunting is about the house and it's relationship to Eleanor. The other characters only serve to define her.  For example:  Catherine Zeta Jone's  overtly sexual Theo serves to contrast with Lili Taylor's Eleanor to show us a woman lacking self esteem and confidence. It is Eleanor who the story revolves around, and Lili Taylor does an excellent job of bringing her to life.It's also nice to see a horror movie that uses style and mood over gore & blood (of which there is very little). Those expecting to be scared out of their skin with the Haunting will be disappointed.  Those wanting a good summer movie with a big budget, big stars, and lots of special Fx set in a very cool haunted house, will find The Haunting very satisfing. 9 stars (out of 10).

For movie fans who have never heard of the book (Shirley Jackson's "The Haunting of Hill House") and have never seen the 1963 Robert Wise production with Julie Harris, this remake will seem pretty darn bad.For those of us who have, it is just plain awful.Bad acting (what was Neeson thinking?), goofy computer enhancements, and a further move away from Jackson's story doom this remake.Do yourself a favor and rent the original movie. It still effectively scares without hokey special effects. The acting is professional and believable.For readers of the book, the  from 1963 follows the it much closer.

Review title: Well, at least the effects are "special"
Review_body: There's nothing quite like a good scare in a film.  And that is exactly what you get from The Haunting, for about a split second.  In fact, the only thing impressive about this film is the house itself.  Somebody must have spent a good long time making it move like that, and for that I am grateful, because nothing else in the "movie" moved at all.  I'll make this short and sweet:  If you are a fan of special effects, or just really cool looking houses, this is a movie for you.  Otherwise, you're wasting your time and money.

I was a little apprehensive in viewing the Haunting as I'd heard several critics and friends slam it to hell and back, but upon seeing it for the first time recently I was pleasantly surprised and found that I liked it a lot. The performances are suitably great from it's leads but Lili Taylor just steals the show as innocent and vulnerable Eleanor "Nell". The screenplay plays great with her emotions and you really feel for her character as the movie progresses. Rather than remake the original as in "Psycho" 98..Director Jan De Bont has told his vision of Shirley Jacksons wonderfully creepy novel and what he delivers is really breath-taking...from the house's gaping interiors to smothering carvings, he really uses these as characters unto themselves and as the story unfolds and night falls the films atmosphere stirs up a suitably wicked air of menace. I can't recommend this movie enough...don't compare it to the original, go in from a fresh perspective and I guarantee you'll be enthralled.

Review title: Very good - scary, great effects...I liked it!
Review_body: I thought that The Haunting was one of the best films I've seen in a long while.  I know all the other reviews around say it isn't scary and there's no characters or plot, but I personally found that the characters had substance, there is a pretty deep plot (though they could have made more of the sub-plot between Nell and Theo), and it DID scare me.  I have the childrens' voices in my head still.  I went to see it at a late night showing (midnight), which I guess probably helped somewhat in making it really scary. Amazing special effects too.  I liked the idea of using the curtains as a way to see the childrens' ghosts.  And Lili Taylor was brilliant in it. I did think that it shouldn't be a 12 though.  Okay, so there's no swearing or gory violence, but all the scary things - rooms changing shape, statues and pictures coming to life - are things that will really scare younger children.

Review title: I am ashamed to have contributed to this film's box office.
Review_body: This film epitomises the worst of what Hollywood is capable of: sloppy screenwriting (dire plotting, poor structure, zero interesting characterization) combined with big-budget effect excess. OK, effect movies can work (Jan de Bont's 'Twister' did), and it is possible to make non-humans protagonists... but wasn't this film supposed to be at least a little bit scary? Interesting? Fun? Something? What were all these high-profile actors doing when they signed up to this bomb? Well, they certainly weren't looking to do any acting.I'm afraid it's an all round disaster. None of the roles' potential was remotely fulfilled (Zeta Jones' part was, to all intents and purposes, non-existent). And any interesting story developments were soon abandoned to some rather mundane effects, which rather than create anything nearing a frisson of cinematic pleasure, merely turned the whole debacle into a farce. And was it scary? No, it was just funny. The only shots or scenes which went any of the way to creating any feeling of tension or fear were made without a single computer effect. Which must be saying something.

One of the worst films I've ever seen; its awfulness was compounded by the fact that I had seen the original (a classic) only two weeks previously, so was expecting good things.  My expectations were also raised by the reasonable cast including the wonderful Lili Taylor. (Dreadful script, meaningless encounters, reliance on special effects rather than acting and plot... Need I say more?

Review title: Special effects no substitute for good acting and plot
Review_body: A classic example of how modern day special effects, no matter how well crafted (which they are in The Haunting)  can ruin an otherwise good, if well used,  storyline.  If film makers limited the use of special effects to support the actors and plot, rather than as a substitute, then I think we would all benefit.The film begins with a steady, albeit predictable build up and the first scenes in the house really make you want to believe it is has a mysterious and sinister past.  However, about half way through the film the actors become secondary to the overdone special effects and seem to confine themselves to wandering around aimlessly.At no stage during the film did I ever feel scared nor did I receive any sudden frights (compared, for example, to the "choke on your popcorn" frights delivered in Sixth Sense).   If this was the aim of the film, then I'm afraid it failed miserably.   In the scariness stakes, repeated loud noises and wobbly walls are no match for the brief glimpse of an unexplained shadow or a rapidly moving household object narrowly missing you.I felt the ending to The Haunting was very abrupt and did not satisfactorily explain all that had happened in the closing scenes.  While I usually don't mind films to end in such a way that make the audience work out the ending, I found in this case I didn't care.By no means the worst film I have seen this year - there are a few good creepy scenes and the house is truly magnificent.  The Haunting was sufficiently "average" to avoid me feeling cheated of my admission money, but it is not a film I intend to see again.

I know viewers have already been adequately warned against this cinematic trainwreck, but I just can't withold from kicking the pathetic adaptation while it's down. The Haunting is the worst film I've seen to date. The 1963 B&W version is a psychologically terrifying adaptation of Shirly Jackson's nightmarish novel The Haunting of Hill House. The 1999 movie rapes the original plot, casts a terrible cast and sticks entirely un-spooky ghosts and gore right in the audiences yawning faces. Do not waste precious hours of your mortal life on this atrocity!

Review title: The best movie of the year
Review_body: This movie keeps you on your seat all the way through, if you think that you are going to be kept board and relaxed, you ARE WRONG!!!!!!! the actors and actresses are some of the best, they all may not be well known but boy ARE THEY GOOD!!!!!! I saw this movie 10 times while in the theaters and people said "how could you do that, know one can go and see the same movies again and again" I agree with this but with this movie, I could see it again and again and again and again and again and again (but that is why people buy them on videos, so that they can watch it as many times as you like.In my personal opinion I liked the character of Luke Sannerson , who was played by Owen Wilson. I also love the way the house was made, You would be umming and arring over the such beautiful features of the house. (eg:the cherubs, and defentd carving.

Before I watched the haunting I thought it would be the usual type of ghost story with bumps in the night.  Well to a certain extent I was right, but this film seemed to have a weird and quite weird line.  Some of the scenes are just downright stupid and the intention to scare does not hit you in the face in the first place.  Although after thinking more about the story line afterwards it is a little bit freaky!

Review title: The only scary bit is the Horrendous Plot and Script
Review_body:
Poorly conceived, totally un-engaging piece of c***.  Too American, Too Obvious, Too reliant on Computer Generated Effects.Weak & Dull.  
Worst Career Move For All Involved in this project.

what a waste of celluloid! I went into this with some hopes of seeing something great with such a brilliant cast including the stunning catherine zeta, liam, owen, and under the visually epileptic direction of Jan (Speed) DeBont and produced by spielberg himself. What the hell did we spend our ten pounds on? This film was overwrought with cliché after clich and was utterly disappointed. Comparing this snooze-fest with the more than modestly budgeted 'House on Haunted Hill' that lurked right around the corner of this year, I was even hesitant to see that after this piece of crap. Let me tell you that 'House on Haunted Hill' was an incredible picture compared to this mess of film. Catherine Zeta can come haunt me whenever she chooses thought!

Review title: Not Haunted by the new The Haunting... (may be spoilers)
Review_body:
How viewers react to this new "adaption" of Shirley Jackson's book, which was promoted as NOT being a remake of the original 1963 movie (true enough), will be based, I suspect, on the following: those who were big fans of either the book or original movie are not going to think much of this one...and those who have never been exposed to either, and who are big fans of Hollywood's current trend towards "special effects" being the first and last word in how "good" a film is, are going to love it.
Things I did not like about this adaption:1.  It was NOT a true adaption of the book.  From the articles I had read, this movie was supposed to cover other aspects in the book that the first one never got around to.  And, that seemed reasonable, no film can cover a book word for word unless it is the length of THE STAND! (And not even then) But, there were things in this movie that were never by any means ever mentioned or even hinted at, in the movie.  Reminded me of the way they decided to kill off the black man in the original movie version of THE SHINING.  I didn't like that, either.  What the movie's press release SHOULD have said is..."We got the basic, very basic, idea from Shirley Jackson's book, we kept the same names of the house and several (though not all) of the leading character's names, but then we decided to write our own story, and, what the heck, we watched THE CHANGELING and THE SHINING and GHOST first, and decided to throw in a bit of them, too."2.  They completely lost the theme of a parapyschologist inviting carefully picked guest who had all had brushes with the paranormal in their pasts, to investigate a house that truly seemed to have been "born bad".  No, instead, this "doctor" got everyone to the house under the false pretense of studying their "insomnia" (he really invited them there to scare them to death and then see how they reacted to their fear...like lab rats, who he mentioned never got told they are part of an experiment...nice guy).  This doctor, who did not have the same name, by the way, was as different from the dedicated professional of the original movie as night from day.3.  In direct contrast to the statement that was used to promote both movies "some houses are just born bad", this house was not born bad but rather became bad because of what happened there...and, this time around, Nel gets to unravel the mystery (shades of THE CHANGELING).  The only problem was, the so-called mystery was so incoherently told that I'm sure it remained a mystery to most of the audience...but, then there was no mystery in the first place (not in the book), because the house was bad TO BEGIN WITH. It's first "victim" died before ever setting eyes on it.4.  The way the character of Luke was portrayed was absolutely ridiculous. He was supposed to be a debonair playboy who was someday to inherit the house (and was a true skeptic of it's "history")...and in this one he was just a winey-voiced, bumbling nerd who couldn't sleep(insomnia remember) and was a compulsive liar.5.  I was also annoyed with the way the movie jumped from almost trying to recreate original scenes word for word (the scene with Nel's sister's family, and Mrs. Dudley's little opening speech...) to going off into flights of fancy that made me think more of these other movies than THE HAUNTING.  It's like it couldn't make up its mind what it wanted to do.6.  I missed Nel's narrative through the whole movie.  The original was so like a gothic novel in the way that the story was mostly told in the first person, through Nel's eyes, and we always were privy to her thoughts. That totally unique touch was completely lost in the new version.  They also tried to make Nel much more of a heroine.  The original Nel was not a bad person, but she was a bitter person (could she be otherwise after sacrificing 11 years of her life to a selfish old woman and a spiteful sister?) and she liked to moan, and she lost her temper...  This one was almost too good to be true.  This was never more apparent than in the climax of the movie where the writer's had obviously been watching GHOST one too many times.7.  They changed the history of the house and it's occupents too much. There was no Abigail Crain (the daughter of Hugh whose legend loomed large in the original versions), there was no "companion", and there was no nursery.  There was also no "Grace" (wife of the original doctor) and Hugh Crain's wives died in totally different ways.  These changes, changed the story WAY too much.  I don't know whether the producers of this movie should be glad Shirley Jackson no longer walks this earth or whether they should...BE SORRY (if ya get my drift!!! The hauntings she could envision are not something to be trifled with!!!).In conclusion, let me just leave you with some words from the original Luke (appropriate substitution of the word "house" for "movie"!):  "This 'movie' should be burnt to the ground, and the ground sprinkled with salt!"  My favorite movie of all time remains so.  No competition from this one.

Review title: Put Casper In While You're At It (Sigh)...
Review_body: I really wanted to like this movie about the haunted house (hoping it would be like others, much older, that I've seen), especially after seeing the special about it on the TV, made prior to its release.However, this movie did not work at all for me for the following reasons:1. Hard to believe at first, but it had too much of a "Casper" feel. I think this is because the children's "ghosts" are so amazingly unconvincing and fake-looking, that it is hard to believe they would even release it like this. The children are all generic-looking and doll-like, as if the people who made this never saw a real child. (Could they not get any child actors?) It also reminds me so much of the CGI trickery in the Casper movie, but unlike Casper, this is supposed to be realistic looking, yes?2. I did not at all like the character of Dr. David Marrow, especially in thinking anyone who acts a certain way is having some sort of "episode" and is in a state of delusion as if he "knows" everything. Why do some "professional" people assume they have any more understanding than anyone else (relative to actual experience, not just going to school)? This does happen in real life, but far more in movies, it would seem, I guess to purposely make you hate the character?3. I may be wrong in this, but how many absolutely identical paintings (one in the kitchen?), one on the wall in the stairwell, and at least one more? - were there of Crain? This is not in the lists of "goofs" as far as I can tell, but seems very obvious, more than other listed goofs. Why would you have copies of the same very large painting in different areas? This was very annoying for me and damaged any potential realism. Dorian Gray, he is not.4. I know the house is always "changing", but how can it be so different on the outside than the inside?5. Finally, Mrs. Dudley's "in the dark" speeches made me laugh, which I do not think was intended, and the "I can see my breath" scene was also a bit silly.I will say that the carved cherubic faces of the children "coming to life" and also making outlines in curtains and sheets was very creepy (perhaps the most interesting facet of the whole movie, in concept - having the feel of an old DC comic), but the more obvious CGI ghost children, as well as their unchildlike voices (with regard of what their spirits must have went through, especially), completely ruined these connecting elements.I also feel this movie would have been more entertaining if they had not shown Crain at all in his "human" form. And the ending made no sense to me at all. I didn't at all understand the supposed explanation of Eleanor's history, nor why she had to die when I thought the ghosts were "protecting" her. This, as well, was extremely annoying.I will give this movie a 4/10. Not so bad as to deserve a 1.

Good movie . Well shot ,well acted and good special effects.Alot of fuddy duddys have slammed this movie and consider the '63 version a masterpiece.. pffft! .. This is waayy more fun ! Compared to a lot of garbage out now this is a very well made movie. Entertaining and well worth a look !

When I watched this movie first, I was in for a scaring and thrilling film since it was declared a "Horrorfilm". However after 30 minutes I wondered what that was supposed to be. I would rather describe it as a horror-comedy or even parody. But even if that should have been the intention, it went wrong. The film is full of cliches of average horrorfilms. Additionally the story is completely predictable. There are strange statues in the house, blowing winds, whistling sounds and of course an ancient ghost. Even the special effects, which are in fact high-quality don't prevent the movie from being boring. These effects create an artificial impression: The winding of the ceiling or the braking window might have worked for a sci-fi movie, but not for a horrorfilm which is supposed to scare. The actors can't save the movie either: Liam Neeson is top, but the two girls (especially Lily Taylor gets on your nerves after a while)are just average.The set of Hill House is nice, and the rooms in there are pretty impressive but without convincing story-who cares? The only thing I can say is: Try again-it can only get better

ah, where to begin? i saw this with my best friend and it was SO horrible we loved it. it was not only cheesy, with embarrassing special effects, it was stupid and too twisted anyway. still, its horridness provided us with several things to laugh over. so if you and your friends love inside jokes, enjoy, because this is chock-full of things to ridicule. also, i kinda feel bad for catherine zeta-jones. she is a fantastic actress whose skills are quite... crushed in this movie. same goes for owen Wilson. watch this movie with popcorn to throw at the screen, just in case.yep. that is all. OH! one more thing.... not scary at ALL. however look for odd twists. yeah.
All copies of this horrible remake movie should be taken outside, burned and the earth sown with salt.

This is one of the best and beautiful horror films that I've seen and I'm sure others have one way or another retained the images that are so eerie yet majestic in a sense because of one, we have this marvelous setting, the elaborately mystical house to begin with ...and because of careful direction along with characters that are goodness, not stoned as prevalent in today's standards, there is a genuine and yes, scary feeling you could walk away from when watching the film. The elements of the house and the characters are in perfect symbiosis...you keep your eyes open because the perspective of every character that enters in each floor and room are in a way, extensions of each other...what a classic way of enjoying films that don't rely on convoluted plots and/or reading the psyche of the enemy as if its mind is stretched to a 100 ft. deep. Nothing is far too complicated here and it makes for a pleasurable experience. It's an awe to watch the scenes unfold in this film...the images are hidden dialogues for themselves and this saves the audience from over-analyzing things. If you want to get spooked anytime of the day on the pleasure of your simple couch and TV, I think The Haunting works....and the wonderful thing is that after, you can go about doing your normal things. The 'haunting' starts and stops when the movie's finished. Simple!

This movie had beautiful sets, great acting, a wonderful cast, and Catherine Zeta- Jones was especially phenomenal.The movie starts with some subtle scares, but the tension rises as the movie goes on. Compared to the original I thought the plot had a greater meaning, and was more carefully plotted, since in the original, the main character Eleanore might of just been crazy all along, and that seems like an excuse to not think of a good ending.I would give it a 10 out of 10, especially considering the CGI was pretty good for a film made in 1999.

Review title: i see what this film could have been. its just the case of a bad commercial director
Review_body: this COULD have been a fantasy tale like Tim Burton's Edward scissor-hands mixed with the surreal complexion of David lynch's Mullholland drive. this COULD have been suspenseful and mentally captivating. NEEDS; a director that isn't as fluent and fast in his storytelling, people like choppiness in scenes, slight mellow drama and some aspects to be left to the mind, they just wanted to throw the ghost into the story as fast as possible. ; a music department that more has a grasp on suspenseful backing music. (i still insist that insidious's backing track is the best) ; a different cgi. the ghosts were lacking. the one in the bed? in that big Gothic house, they could have done much better i see what this film could have been. Though it is a okay movie to watch, there is always something lacking.i like all of the actors in this apart from Owen Wilson. there is always an actor i do not like. so i think that is why i stuck to it watch Mullholland drive and Edward scissor hands and see if you agree with me. think of Eleanor's (nells) character as being in a Betty(Mullholland drive) type story with the Gothic charm of Tim Burton.

Review title: I wish I could give this movie less than a 1.
Review_body: Quite possibly the worst movie I have ever seen. I saw this in the theatre and still lament the two hours of my life that I cannot get back. The only reason that I am even bothering to write a "review" of this, for lack of a better term, movie is that I just want to warn people to stay away.If ever you feel the urge to put this unholy tangle of bile on your television, just put on the original. The original 1963 version of "The Haunting" isn't just a good haunted house movie, it's an absolute genre masterpiece.This "thing" that Jan de Bont hobbled together is dreck of the lowest order. Sure, there are some good actors in it: Bruce Dern, Liam Neeson, but they are wasted.Don't waste your time. Seriously. You'll never get it back.

Review title: The Haunting could have been so much better, it is just a shame Lili Taylor is boring and that there are not enough scares to keep us interested.
Review_body: *MINOR SPOILER* I was definitely intrigued by a cast which seemed a bit mixed - Liam Neeson (serious), Owen Wilson (comedy), Catherine Zeta-Jones (Welsh) and the other one who I had never seen before (Lili Taylor), or again for that matter. So didn't know quite what to expect... And so onto the film, it concentrates (unfortunately) on Eleanor (Lili Taylor) following the death of her mother.  She responds to an ad looking for insomniacs to take part in a study undertaken by Dr David Marrow (Liam Neeson) who is actually going to try and scare them and see what happens. Fair enough, so they meet up at the haunted house along with Theo (Catherine Zeta Jones), and Luke (Owen Wilson) and we wait for scary things to happen. Unfortunately it takes far too long for the scariness to begin (what little of it there is).  Yes, the house is weird, lots of odd rooms ready for scary set-pieces, but they are not exploited as they could have been.  Eleanor is just so dull that I just ended up not caring about her in the end.  The special effects were also a little boring.  It is much scarier not to now what the cause is, rather than seeing some face in a curtain. Our one quality piece of entertainment was the flume-decapitation of Owen Wilson, a classic.  Sorry to spoil it, but we knew at least one of them had to die. The story grinds on to its boring, pointless conclusion that we just don`t care about in the end.  It could have been so much better.

Review title: A group of people are invited to participate in a scientific study in an abandoned mansion.
Review_body: The beginning of the movie was a little sketchy. The plot could have used some elaboration, especially as far as 'who's who' in the film, etc. The special effects were phenomenal, excuse the pun. It was slow at the beginning, but eventually sped up rather admirably with unique visual effects and dialog. Most of the actors/actresses gave strong performances, but definitely not all. Liam Neeson was excellent, as was Zeta-Jones (although I'm not a big fan of hers). Luke Wilson should stick to comedy. His performance was a bit unbelievable at times (as when he was supposed to be terrified). The actress who played 'Elenor' was sufficient, although her dialog was a bit weak in the beginning and at the end.

Review title: Not a touch on the Robert Wise classic!
Review_body: Considering the original film version of 'The Haunting" is in my top ten films of all time' I approached this adaption with trepidation. I was right to be cautious as this film is a poorly written and badly executed load of old tosh, all those involved should be ashamed. the original was terrifying to me as a child for one reason! you see nothing. Robert Wise used innovative camera-work and superb lighting to generate fear and this is why it work's. The shame of the new version is that it relies on clever special effects and pyrotechnics to get from A to B, sadder still is that the ingredients were there (actors such as Liam Neeson, Catherine Zeta Jones) to do something different. This film should only watched as an example of studio butchery!

Review title: Some Movies Are Born Bad: A Cinematic Abomination
Review_body: I hate to say it, folks, but I've got to be honest with you...it's been six years, and I have yet to see a movie worse than this one.For the (fortunately) uninitiated, "The Haunting" is a pitiful remake of the classic 1963 horror flick. While it naturally fails to measure up to the original, the fact that it attempts to pass itself off as somehow "original" in itself lowers an otherwise typical remake to the level of utterly abysmal garbage. I had the pleasure of watching this stinker back when I was still in high school, and it has left me with a tarnished image of the horror genre ever since.I won't waste my time or yours outlining the details of the plot, but suffice to say, it's your typical haunted house story, only enhanced by a melee of "ethereal" 90's special effects. The actors, with a few notable exceptions, all deliver campy if not completely unbelievable performances, highly unmemorable whether viewed collectively or individually. The one major attempt at a "plot twist" of any kind (though "contrivance" would be more suitable) appears toward the very end, and it is laughably conveyed- presumably unintentionally- in what must surely be the cheesiest way possible.Obviously, I would advise against watching this movie under most circumstances (no, it's not even worth a rental) but if you're curious or even remotely masochistic, try to catch it on public television. It's a favorite of many broadcasters during the Halloween season, so this October, keep your eyes peeled...just make sure you don't gouge them out of their sockets in retribution.That might actually be scary.

Review title: Don't always listen to other reviews!
Review_body: I, like many other people, am greatly surprised by the amount of hate and loathing for this movie. I think the main root of the problem, stems from the original. The original being a good movie with plenty of thrills and chills that got peoples hearts thumping and blood pumping. Due to the enjoyable nature of the original, people seem to instantly blacklist this newer version. However I extremely recommend that virgin viewers of this film, take heed in ignoring peoples opinion on it. This 1999 version is completely different to the original, so much so that perhaps it shouldn't of been coined as a remake to the 1963 one.The first time I watched this film, I hadn't seen the original, so I guess I had nothing to pin my hopes on. I personally loved this movie. So did all my friends that I showed it to. Forget that it's a 'remake' and just watch it without any outside or prior knowledge, but this is one entertaining flick.I'm no sucker for CGI and special effects; I've always been against them. However this movie has some very good effects, that are used well and for the right reasons. The creators don't overuse them or simply add them in for cheap tricks and thrills. They are placed in nicely and make the film feel a lot more exciting.The acting I found was very well executed. The actors, who were well cast I believe, are very interesting and their characters offer traits that are often found at the ends of the human psych scale. There are no average or normal people in this film and that keeps it entertaining and likable. They're 3 dimensional and you easily find yourself really giving a damn about them.The storyline I'll admit is slightly diluted. They seem to not give much suspense to the actual story behind why they are all in the house. However with that said, the script is well written and actually quite intellectual at points. I personally didn't find it much of a problem about the story line, because I found many other things that helped the film.The music and general sound of the film are wonderful. I have a sub-woofer and I honestly recommend you watch this with surround because it is just, epic! The bass in this film is so powerful, even during bright daylight I felt like I was in the actual movie itself just from the bass alone. Not exactly a big deal to many, but to those who have the right equipment, it's heaven! Overall I thoroughly enjoyed this movie and watch it at least two or three times a year. You really should not judge this movie, as you shouldn't any others, by the reviews of other people. Mainly because I think as I said previously the hate is down to the love of the original. Definitely give it a go, you have nothing to lose but could end up finding your new favourite. Just like me.

Review title: Much Better Than I Thought It Would Be
Review_body:
To start with it has a very good cast of actors, the film starts off a little slow but starts getting interesting around 25 minutes in.
Some very creepy parts in the film, and parts that make you jump out your skin.We watched the film at 11pm with the lights out and just two candles for light for added fright.All in all a good film and well worth a watch.

Review title: One of the funniest movies ever made
Review_body: You know a horror movie is in trouble when everyone in the theater is laughing instead of screaming; and at my local movie theater, that was what the audience was doing while they were watching the supposed high-tech version of the horror classic The Haunting. The 1999 version is too loud, too ridiculous, and just too overdone.

The movie had very good, professional CGI work but there was no humanity to it.  The script was very predictable; before each of the scary bits I could give at least 5 to 10 seconds advance notice, "Here it comes!"  De Bont was never able to make me really care about the characters; I ended up rooting for the effects to win out.  Interesting cameo from Bruce Dern that I didn't know about.

Review title: Good movie up until the ending
Review_body: The Haunting is pretty good as far as remakes go, however that is mainly because of the special effects. They were incredible.  The story was decent and I also feel it was a scary movie, right up to the ending.  The movie builds up this sense of horror inside this evil house, and then ends with a silly sequence that supposedly ties everything together.  Liam is his normal Schindler-Qui-Gon self and Catherine just spends a lot of time looking hot. I'd give the movie a B- and Catherine Zeta-Jones an A+.

Review title: really good movie, made me jump
Review_body: after seeing the movie and reading all the "reviews" of it and comments on how the audience hooted and laughed at the film i see no reason why they did. there were some scenes in the movie that made me laugh a little, at the situation, not at how bad they tried to scare you. it did make me jump a few times and it will keep you on the edge of your seat. i can't see how this movie made so many people laugh, in the theater i work at and saw it in, the whole auditorium was filled and when something happened i saw a lot of people jump up...no one was laughing.. makes me kind of wonder what kind of audience was at the preview?

One of the best ghost stories in years. Not since "Ghost Story" have I seen such chilling work. The best Jan De Bont film since "Twister". The special effects and the whispering of the spirits literally sent chills down my spine. Two HOORAYS for a great horror movie. Hope to see more horror movies like this with real ghostly scares and less blood and gore. A-

Review title: Once again shows that a horror movie is really made HORROR-ble by computer effects
Review_body: I wanted to walk out of this movie.  I stayed in, hoping that the ending would redeem the rest of it.  It did the exact opposite.  The chaotic, loud ending was basically the effects people having fun playing with their computers.  The only scary thing about this is the thought of all horror movies turning into 'THE MATRIX with a monster.'  The movie had one (maybe two) creepy parts and a jump or two, but it almost doesn't even fit in the horror genre.  The story was confusing and not worth caring about.  The acting was up to par, but the actual characters weren't worth getting into the movie for.  Owen Wilson's character was hilarious and well-played too. His performance was probably the best part of the movie - not a good sign.
NOT WORTH IT. save your money.4 out of 10embarrassingdon't go

This movie should go fast to the 250 bottom ones. The plot is very poor. Only illogic scenes. Not even a single good dialoge. The characters are disjointed, The teaser is far better than the movie itself. I could not find anything good on it. Hummm, maybe Zeta-Jones...

Review title: This Film is Horrific...in a bad way
Review_body: THE HAUNTING-a movie that tries to hard to be both a special effects film, and a horror film at once. Unfortunatetly in only barley succeeds one of them. The film forgets one key ingredient in making a horror film, is that you must focus more attention on making the characters then making the effects for there emotions travel through them into the crowd. The Haunting is about as enjoyable as a trip to the doctor. The film takes so long to get started by the time it does you want to 1. Boo the screen or 2.Leave the theater (believe me I would have if I wasn't stuck in the middle of the row. Bottom line This film is Horrific.....in a bad way. De Bont's new worst 1/2

Although not nearly as scary as the 1963 version, this 'Haunting' is sure to please younger, special effects hungry, moviegoers.  The acting was pretty good, although I didn't really get the sense that the actors were too scared of what was happening to them.  The house was incredible!  I'd love to spend a weekend there myself.De Bont took too long to get to the 'scary' part of the film, which could have been a whole lot scarier without all the special effects - c'mon filmmakers, leave us something to do with our imagination!

Review title: Could've been a far better horror movie
Review_body: The characters are good and so is the acting. The scenografy is really nice and appropriate. Special FX are interesting and are used in a proper way. What dosen't work is the plot, too linear and not much developed. Also the general atmosphere should (and could) have been far creepier and obsessive. I think the production wanted to make a movie for the general audience, kids included, but that definitely ruined the movie. Horror movies should be scary, and, if it is necessary, graphic and disturbing; that's what they are supposed to be. I think that the best american movies are those whose production have the courage to make a movie that is not necessarily "for all the family" and don't have to be something even Disney would produce. In my opinion movies that are afraid of achieving their full effect are really disappointing. Fortunately ther's still someone who can produce a good horror movie (with capital H): The sixth sense is a great example.

This is the cheesiest "horror" movie I've ever seen. To be fair, I'll admit _most_ horror movies are pretty cheesy, but this one outdoes them all, especially with the various little monologues... The scientist's monologue on "I'm doing this to further science!" cut short by a slap, Eleanor's "It's not about fear! It's about family! It's about the children!"... Those are the award winning cheesy moments, but, if you're a cheese lover, this is the velveeta of movies, so there are plenty of varieties of cheese here... The acting is cheesy, the dialogue is cheesy, and the monologues were cheesy... If that's what you like, this is the movie for you...

I think the movie was excellent!! Awesome special effects!!  I love the actors! I wish I lived in that house or could at least see it. The effects were done very well! Kudos to the director, cast, and crew!! I will for sure read the book!! I'm telling everyone I know about it!!

Review title: Quite possibly the biggest mockery of the filming industry.
Review_body: Whoever is reading this, take heed of my warning.  This movie is terrible. Beyond terrible.  The script is so bad, I think that two pieces of bread could have better dialogue.  Don't even get me started on how lame the whole story was, including what is supposed to be the big climax, which is more like watching a remake of the Exorcist by a bunch of 5 year olds on a camcorder that think they should do everything in slow motion just to make the scene more dramatic.  I don't understand.  Jan De Bont started off so well with Speed (OK, not an Oscar Caliber movie, but at least it was enjoyable), then Twister, then that piece of crap Speed 2 and now this. Geez, the more I think about this movie the more frustrated I am getting.  I have to talk to the executives at Dreamworks and ask them how the hell I am ever gonna get back those 2 hours of my life that I completely wasted watching this trash.  DO NOT watch this movie, it will completely suck away your will to live.

Review title: A hilarious mix of horror and Liam Neeson
Review_body: After seeing the film I must say that I was entertained, so it is not at all a bad movie. However, special effects alone are not enough to carry a movie with plot/unity gaps big enough to drive a small Buick through. In terms of the horror genre, I did jump at some of the "Boo!" parts, but I also think that some of the scenes that were supposed to be frightening, came across as humorous instead. Overall: **1/2   C+/B-Perhaps it was the fact that this film was released in the US not long after Star Wars: Episode 1, but I kept expecting (wanting) Liam Neeson to pull out his lightsaber and use the force.

This film manages to scare and shock much more than could be expected from the 12 certificate. The house itself was unbelievable and very atmospheric (I especially liked the book stepping stones and the various statues). The special effects were mind-blowing and well worth the money spent. I'm not a big horror fan but I genuinely found this film scary.

Review title: Great sets, cast; good acting; mediocre plot (slight spoilers if any)
Review_body: First, the good points of the film.  It was visually gorgeous, incredible in fact.  Some of the best sets ever.  The actors were well chosen and did a good job of things.  Catherine Zeta Jones especially was marvellous in her role, playing it with obvious relish.The special effects were middling; slightly unconvincing, plus, as is all too often these days, YOU'VE SEEN THEM ALL (almost) IN THE TRAILER.The script, however, sucks.  All the time is spent in setup, and the payoff is pathetic and over WAY too quickly.  Kudos to the writer/director/studio for not slavishly following the who lives/who dies formula for horror movies so perfectly captured by 'Scream' -- but that's all the credit they're going to get from me.  The ending is all too pat and too easy, and doesn't make enough sense.  There are some good lines, but the overall structure is bad, and one leaves with a sense of dissatisfaction with the entire thing.  I really hope that the flaws are due to overzealous cutting or meddling -- if the original script was that bad, I'm amazed they ever started to make the movie, and spend that much on it.

Review title: Totally creepy!!in a very fun way!
Review_body: We'll I've been waitin to see this movie, it seems like forever, and now that I have I gotta say I'm very satisfied. I loved the atmosphere. It starts out extremely beautiful, you almost want to see this house for yourself. but I'll tell you, your glad you'll never set foot in it by the end! I loved how everything focused on one main character, this poor girl and everyones reactions towards the house's repeated attempts to get her. As much as I loved this movie, I do wish they had done certain aspects of it better. The movie seemed to start at a very unhurried pace, Pulling us into it. We get to enjoy the character's reactions to the house. I think one of my favorite parts to this movie are the ones that involve everyones reactions to Nell when they think she has snapped. Though, I do believe the ending to this movie is quite hurried and left a lot to be desired. The ending felt extremely rushed through, almost like they didn't know exactly how to resolve it so they spent most of the movies time in the "getting to the end" parts that were wonderful, because they knew the ending wouldn't live up to the rest of the movie. It needed to be longer and they needed to touch onto more aspects of the plot than they did, instead of slamming it to a halt. Nell's speech to the " bad guy" at the end is even a little bit silly! But the ending didn't stink, it was even pretty cool, it just could have been better. The movie as a whole was great, and there were no parts in it that detracted from the enjoyment of it. I totally recommend this movie to anyone!

Review title: A sleepy remake of the 1963 classic
Review_body: Haunted house fans will be entertained with this creepy ghost story. However, the director's attempt to bring resolution to the ending of the film was a major disappointment.  If you want to see it done correctly, rent the original (1963) black and white classic from Blockbuster Video.  It may not have all the special effects of the 1999 version, but it will leave you terrified right to the spooky ending.

In my opinion it's pretty hard to make a truly scary movie with a lot of CGI special effects; maybe its because I'm so busy being amazed by them that I dont have time to be spooked.  The Haunting is one of these movies. There's not much suspense but there are parts that will make you jump and the story is somewhat interesting.  Rising star, Owen Wilson plays his character great and is the best part of the movie, besides the house itself.  All in all this movie isn't that haunting but its still a decent movie with great acting all around including Owen Wilson as Luke.

Review title: started well, but descended into a Speed2-like flop
Review_body: They hyped the movie with "from the director of Speed," what they didn't tell you was that De Bont also directed the sea-going waste-of-celluloid known as Speed 2! Like the marketing tagline, this movie was "born bad." Sure the effects were pure ILM, but they couldn't save the proverbial sinking ship. The characters were awful (Liam--why?!?), all stereotypes, the direction and camera angles tried oh-so-hard to inspire fear but didn't, and the acting was awful. And this chubby lady sitting behind me kept gaffawing every two seconds. Was that a horror flick or a comedy? No, it was so cheesy it was funny. All in all, I'm glad I know the manager of the local cineplex and didn't have to pay for the ticket.

Review title: Very good, but didn't scare me like the 1963 original
Review_body: I LOVED the castle they used for the filming. It had many similar effects that terrified me as a child when I saw the original. What I didn't like about it was that there was little left to the imagination. A good scary movie leaves you something to go home and haunt you, something to wake you up in a cold sweat. Nothing was left to ponder here.I also usually like Liam Neeson in anything but his character was without much character here. I don't think it was his acting, just the writing.

Review title: OK, but could be much better.
Review_body: This movie was OK until the last 15 minutes when the director turned the movie over to the special effects guys who have obviously never heard of plot or acting or even suspense.

This film is not a scare fest! The films directer relies on special effects rather than good screenplay,and directing.The best part of the film is the house itself.The original Haunting relies on human emotion.This is just another special effects movie.Not a horror film.

Since the latest version of the "Haunting" was released, all I have heard or read about is its comparison to the original Robert Wise 1963 film, and how much better the original was. I was so impressed with the current Jan De Bont remake, that I thought I would do myself a favor and rent the original.What a mistake that was! There is no comparison of the recent release of the "Haunting" to the original. While I may agree the   current version could be "scarier", I have never sat through a more boring and uneventful movie than the 1963 Wise original.  The interior sets looked as if they belonged in a 1950's sitcom rather than "Hill House", and the only thing frightening was that I actually wasted the money and time to watch this old and poorly made movie.The one good thing about Robert Wise's "Haunting", is that it proves that just because something is the "original" or old, doesn't mean that it's the best, and that remakes of old movies can be better than the original.

A mess of special effects and set design that works to a point in a very sloppy way but ultimately backfires with a terrible ending.  Wasted cast, no script, no story.  Typical summer crap.  After this, Twister, and Speed 2 Jan De Bont needs to be sent away.  He is quite possibly the worst director working today on the Hollywood A-list.

Review title: All smoke in mirrors and no substance, "The Haunting" is a terribly disappointing -- and expensive -- attempt at veneering a classic.
Review_body: I wanted to like this film. I REALLY did. But I hated this film. I REALLY did. From the launch of truly captivating trailers, through interviews I'd seen of reputable talents like Catherine Zeta-Jones and Liam Neesom, this film -- along with the "Blair Witch Project" -- promised to mark the summer of '99 as the season in which intelligence made its long-awaited return to the horror genre. What was offered by Dreamworks was (another) CGI-riddled, thinly acted waste of time, money, talent and celluloid. An abuse of special effects may spook your 5-year-old and dazzle your 11-year-old, but the most frightening thing about "The Haunting" to any movie-going adult likely will be its $75 million price tag.

Review title: Three-dimensional effects don't make up for one-dimensional acting...
Review_body: I just saw the sneak preview for this movie, and I'd like to tell you to wait for the video, but since most of The Haunting's virtues (if any) are in it's special effects, it's probably best to see it on the big screen, if at all.  This movie was NOT SCARY...in fact, people were laughing throughout it.  The acting was bland, and the characters flat.  The dialogue was utter cheese, and the story full of holes.  The only plus to this movie was the set design of the house itself, which was magnificent.  In short, go see this movie expecting to laugh at the corniness of it all.

Review title: Great Effects, lacking at the end
Review_body: This movie scared the (you know what)  out of me at times.  I liked it for that fact.  On the other hand the story left you wondering at the end. How, why and what for. (thats all I can say without giving plot away) Lily Taylor did a terrific job, and the special effects were spectacular. I was just left wanting to know why.

Review title: Good movie but lack of horror.
Review_body: I felt the movie overall was real good.  The actors were real good and the house is spectacular. The only thing I didn't really see was the horror. It had some good parts of sudden shock that will probably make you jump slightly.  I'd recommend this movie to anyone, just don't expect it to be real scary.

I thought it was scary, but the plot and dialogue left much to be desired. However, if you're looking for visual effects, go ASAP, because they are amazing.  It seems like they were trying to make an old-style haunted house movie with new technology, and it *could* have worked--but didn't.

Review title: A waste of time, money and Liam Neesan
Review_body: There are no redeeming qualities for this bomb! All the performances were shallow and camp. The makers abused special effects in an effort to carry the film and none of the  creepiness of the original movie was captured.

Review title: Average acting, story not necessary, cool house, hilarious
Review_body: Though the movie was by far the worst scripted movie and the most falsely advertised movie i've ever seen, it was one of the top comedies.  I found myself laughing even during the most boring scenes of the movie!  It was missing almost everything, but I do have to admit the acting and the house weren't too bad and there were a couple parts that I actually thought were good about the movie, but on a scale between 1 and 10 it would never get higher than a 1, even if it was extremely entertaining.

This film should go down in history as the worst movie of 1999.  It is a prime example of the Hollywood big-budgeted, badly scripted and acted, special effects film.  For anyone wanting a real scare should watch the original.

A movie well worth the ticket!  It's about time someone got back to the basics of a good mystery/fear flick without the gross use of axe murderers or stupid dolls that come alive and slice everyone up with knives... The effects in the movie were amazing!  Yet they were not overdone -- traditional forms of film making were also implemented as needed - and with large success. Great movie.

Review title: An over the top turkey, a worthless waste.
Review_body: Shirley Jackson's story, "The Haunting of Hill House" is one which has twice scared the willies out of me.  Unfortunately neither time was when I went to see Jan de Bont's film, "The Haunting," which opened this week amid hype and hoopla. Compared to Jackson's original novel and Robert Wise's 1963 film version, de Bont's remake seems cheap, obvious and phony. It neither scares nor convinces.Watching this movie is like having a talkative guy sitting next to you in the theater poking you in the ribs and yelling, "Hey, this is scary, eh?"  For instance, I'm sure that the sound department didn't intend to make a confusing muddle out of the the story.  But that's what happens.  The major scares in Jackson's story come from the sounds of the house.  De Bont fills the sound track with groans, creaks and heavy breathing, so many that the viewer doesn't know whether the sounds are there because they are in the story or are just window dressing for the movie viewer.  This outright spoils several of the scenes and waters down the effect on those where the sounds are meant to be heard by the characters.  In the earlier Robert Wise direction, the sounds truly mean something to the characters and present a wonderfully frightful experience for the film viewer. In this turkey some of the groans are coming from the audience.Character development is likewise in-your-face.  For instance, where Wise lets Theo's lesbianism be subtle and under the covers (so to speak), de Bont has Catherine Zeta-Jones do her usual over-acting in tight leather in her very first scenes.  Although Lili Taylor could probably do a very credible job as Eleanor, the script doesn't help her develop Eleanor's fragile persona.  Regardless, what little good she does in the role is completely ruined by the idiotic and special effects filled ending which requires her character to somehow cast off the fragility and metamorphose into a pontificating Superwoman. The rest of the script is equally ridiculous and unbelievable. Liam  Neeson's ample talents are wasted.If you are tempted to go see "The Haunting" in the next few weeks, my advice is to either go to the library and check out Shirley Jackson's wonderful novel, "The Haunting of Hill House". Or, if you insist on seeing a movie, make it Robert Wise's truly chilling 1963 black and white version, also entitled "The Haunting."  And, sweet dreams.

For a movie that is so hyped, that grabs people's attention with it's ads and looked to be a really good ghost story...well it just plain sucks.  the film tries to scare and not be a stereotypical ghost story, but it doesn't scare and its even worse than a stereotypical ghost story.  at least the original film didn't show any ghosts and left the viewer wondering if there were any there at all, this version completly ruins that style of filmmaking. the special effects run the story, and the special effects arent that up to par either.  if you want to see a good movie, rent the original or go to blair witch.

In some cases, less is more.  In this case, it certainly would have been better.  Being a fan of the original "Haunting" from 1963 (and of the book), I was hoping for a little more subtlety, but unfortunately EVERYTHING is on display here.  But it might not have been so bad if the CGI ghosts were not so...dumb-looking.  And the ending was a little too Disney-esque for me. Although this is just my opinion, a haunted house movie, particularly in a house that was "born bad" does not necessarily need a "happy" ending (especially one that seemed so contrived). But it certainly wasn't all bad.  The house is incredible, and I thought the sounds and music were first-rate.  There were a few good effects too.  I'd just like to use my imagination a little more and not have everything spelled out for me.  Maybe a slightly more literal interpretation of the original storyline (from the book that is) would have worked better.

Review title: Worst movie I've seen this year.
Review_body: Bad script, bad acting, good special effects.  Unfortunately for this film, it takes more than special effects to make a movie scary in 1999.  Don't waste your time on this one.

Review title: The Haunting is a great piece of movie making
Review_body: I think The Haunting was very well done. The special effects were amazing in this movie. It had a great cast who worked very well together. The movie had a very good plot line. There weren't that many jolts though. I only jumped once but it was still a wonderful piece of movie making. There were also a few moments where Lili Taylor's character was forced by the script writer to say some pretty stupid things but her wonderful acting got her by in this movie. I really enjoyed The Haunting. My rating is **** out of 5 stars.

Review title: Quite Possibly the Worst Movie Ever Made
Review_body: After seeing this movie, I remain in a state of shock.  I am shocked that a movie could be this terrible.  I simply cannot believe that so many contrived plot devices and sappy lines of dialogue can fit into a mere two hours.  The special effects, although innovative, are at best distracting, and most of the time just plain silly.  If I had one wish, aside from that of world peace, it would be that no one would ever have to endure the pain and anguish of sitting through this pathetic movie.

Review title: I laughed more than I got scared
Review_body: This movie was a very sad attempt for a horror movie.  I can't believe it was actually even made.  Everything was either predictable, pointless, silly, or goofy-looking.  Believe me.  I'm still telling my friends to go watch it, but just to see how bad it is.  When you leave the theater, you'll probably be booing the movie, and if you're not, its because you're laughing too hard.

This had to have been one of the most horrible movies I've ever seen.  It's really sad, too, considering the movie had the stars to make it an excellent film.  The movie trods through special fx scene followed by special fx scene.. held together only by a loose plot that's revealed when the eye candy runs dry.  This movie had a lot of potential.. but Hollywood's obsession with outdoing its competition's digital effects turned this beautiful looking film into a box office bomb.

Review title: Wonderfully animated, poor adaptation of a truly intense book.
Review_body: Having read Shirley Jackson's novel shortly before seeing this film, I really hoped the plot would stay true to the original story.  Certain events did, but for the most part, it was a completely different storyline.However, I did enjoy the film as it had the ability to make me jump (and scream outloud once, I'm ashamed to say) and the computer animation was extremely well done. The cast itself did a really decent job of portraying the characters from the book accurately, although I left wanting a little bit more.  While Shirley Jackson focused more on the mental aspect concerning her characters reactions to the various manifestations taking place, the was more or less pure Hollywood in that what the characters saw rather then what they felt took precedence. All in all, it was definitely scary and the plot, while changed dramatically, was still interesting.  My only recommendation is that you read the book after seeing the film, or you may be disappointed.

Review title: A magnificent film. Don't let the critics turn you away.
Review_body: This film was great. I saw it the day after it opened and I loved it. The movie has a very interesting plot, a great cast, outstanding special effects and everything else a good movie should have. If you are a fan of thrillers and suspenseful movies then I will give you my guarentee that you will like it if not love it. Don't let the critics fool you with their bad reviews, the critics raved about Titanic and personally I think the Haunting is better.

Review title: A group of people stay the week in HillHouse... Only to unravel it's history, and release the Horror that has been locked inside.
Review_body: This movie is the greatest Thriller, Suspence, Horror movie I have ever seen.. It just blows "Scream", and "I Know What You Did Last Summer" out of the water, no contest.  It's full of GREAT Special FX, and the acting is awesome.  I would definately go see this movie again.  It's worth the 6 bucks.

Review title: If you liked the book, DO NOT see this movie!
Review_body:
This movie has lost all of the elements that made the novel great.  Nell's growing insanity is replaced with obvious ghouls and ghostly apparitions calling in the night.  The web of suspense and uncertainty woven by the author is replaced with a climactic fight scene between Nell the Strong and Crane the Evil Ghost.  Be sure, this is not the mousey Nell of the novel but a new, heroic Nell the Conqueror.If you have not read the novel, avoid this movie.
