The characters exist for no reason other than to be exposed to the crumbling house and mobile statues in the climactic scene. The dialogue serves no purpose but to fill time between computer generated effects.  This is not a horror movie.  It is an hour and 45 minute wait for 15 minutes of special effects.
Rent the first movie or read the book.

This movie successfully did one thing.  It managed to make time pass more slowly.  The sets were the only high point for this movie.  The movie always left you with the something is going to happen feeling, unfortunately, nothing ever really did.  A waste of a decent cast and sets.

The special effects were very enjoyable.  Otherwise, the acting was terrible (and I expected more from Lili Taylor), the plot was thin, the dialogue was very badly written.  There were many holes in the plot.  At the end of the movie I felt cheated out of two hours of my life.

Review title: One of the worst movies ever made!
Review_body: I can't believe Liam Neeson whored himself to this piece of crap! I thought Wild Wild West stunk, but this movie was just rancid. This movie cheapens the original Hunting, which was great. Dreamworks should have spent less money on the sets and more on a decent script that doesn't assume that it's demographic is a bunch of half-wits. This movie makes Ishtar and Godzilla look like Citizen Kane in comparison.

Review title: A house, a ghost, cheesy dialogue...great flick
Review_body: The Haunting was definitely not what I was looking for when I sat in the theatre seat last night, but I got plenty of what I didn't expect but loved anyway.  Visually the movie was really awesome.  Eerie eye-candy was everywhere and it made me at times take a step back and say "Whoa".  The monologues by lily Taylor seemed to be a bit unrealistic at times and tended to be a little melodramatic but overall I really like what they did with this remake. I definitely would recommend it to anyone wanting a visually pleasing, although not quite terrifying movie.

I consider the original 1963 version of "The Haunting" to be one of the scariest, if not THE scariest movie ever made.  I first saw it when it was released (I was 12) and to this day if I watch it I get chills (and I've seen it many, many times.) The terror came from the fact that you never saw what, or who, was haunting Hill House.  You only saw a door bend in and out, or you heard weird sounds, etc.  Everything was pretty much left to your imagination--and that's where this remake goes terribly, terribly wrong.  Aside from the fact that parts of the original Shirley Jackson story were changed for no apparently valid reason, in this version, you see far too much, virtually nothing is left to the imagination, and the end tries to wrap up everything in a "we've got rid of the ghost" scenario, (also a departure from the original story.)  The sets are about the only good thing in this disaster.  Do yourself a favor and rent the original version, and watch it alone. At night. In the dark.

Although I have to admit the special effects were very good, the movie just seemed to lack intensity.  Sure there were a few "scary" moments but bad acting and a lame plot kinda spoiled what could have been a good movie.  Go see it for the special effects but don't expect to leave trembling. Don't forget to rent Vincent Price's 1960's version. 4/10

I grew up watching (the classic) Scooby Doo cartoons, and I love the campy dialogue, creepy yet benign villains, and the goofy gang, with their cliche personalities. I find that kind of thing entertaining, and I enjoyed this movie for those same qualities. I kept expecting the Globe Trotters to show up with the Mystery Machine and rescue everyone. If you're expecting to be scared, you may be disappointed, but if you'd like some light summer entertainment and/or a Liam Neeson/Catherine-Zeta Jones/Lili Taylor fix, you'll probably enjoy this flick.

script is muddy at best, plot points are stated but never supported. character is established by simple declarations, but no action. the actors are wasted, except lili taylor, who salvages her character until the second act eats her alive. the film seems to have been hacked to bits in the editing suite...it begins as a  passable gothic horror/suspense, but mutates into a psychic thriller about midway, and then deteriorates fo a brief moment into a gore flick (character is obligatorily beheaded) before making a final plunge into being a sorry stab at an effects mega-picture (the producers obviously love their effects, as we are forced to look at them far too long in every effects shot).  cinematography deteriorates badly as movie progresses, as does sound quality. avoid this film at all costs.

Everyone is right....the setting of this movie is quite breathtaking. However, this does not make up for the extreme lack of character and plot development.  The most disappointing thing about this movie is that it could have been good.  Had the  script writers/editors picked one plot line to develop, movie-goers may have cared what happened to the different characters.  As it currently stands, this movie is more laughable than frightening.  You also leave the theater wondering many things about why certain things happened -- the biggest thing you wonder is WHY this film was even released!

A very well done piece of cinema, however, not well written. The story seemed to have slight gaps and there were some obvious cut scenes as observed by some of the dialog. Liam Neeson and Catherine Zeta-Jones are not at their best here. Lily Taylor was quite refreshing as the center of the group. My personal favorite is Owen Wilson. He has a very sharp wit that stands out from the rest and he lives up to the role of female eye candy and then some. Go see this movie in the theater. The FX will be much better that way. However, check the brain at the door.

I for one hate scary movies. This is a weird situation for me since my friends are movie nuts, and my Mother loves Stephen King. They've forced me to watch movies such as Seven, Beetle Juice, Doloris Claborne, and many others! All of which I've had a tough nights' sleep afterward. So it was strange when I really wanted to see this movie... My reasons being I love Liam Nelison, and Catherine Zeta-Jones. Also the speical effect totally blew me away during the trailers. So I went to go see it on opening night in my very small home town. And I have to tell you I LOVED IT! It is very creepy and scary, but not in the blood and gore way like all the rest I've seen. The story is original, each character is in depth, and the effects are even better. Thanks to Stan Winston, our friend who created the effects in my all time favorite movie Jurassic Park! Over all I have to say it is a must see.-Sleep Tight- Din

The movie in of itself was not too interesting. The people at Dreamworks did a beautiful job but you aren't supposed to see what you're afraid of. In any case, the movie's one incredibly strong point was the mansion that it was filmed in. It contains some of the most ungodly amazing architecture I have ever seen. I spent the majority of the movie watching the backgrounds and am inclined to see it for just that reason. I would recommend it to anyone who has even a tiny interest in architecture, sculpture, or art.

This movie should not be associated with the original The Haunting. It has very little in common and is just using/abusing the name. It has nothing but overdone special effects. There are no character developments. It could have been so good.

Review title: You can see The Haunting for free.
Review_body:
After seeing the Movie on DVD I realized that one of the trailers on the DVD disc contained almost the entire movie (about 90% of it).
What The Haunting is, is really the trailer I mentioned above (which is a few minutes long) extended to almost 2 hours of repetitive acting. The movie itself is very slow moving and what little that happens can easily be guessed long in advance. (Facts are I could guess 100% of what little story twists existed in the movie and I had not even seen a single trailer before seeing the movie. Nothing like any of the twists in The Usual Suspects)For the hype about the special effects.. well to start with, they were few and the quality of them was nothing spectacular.. about the same as all other movies with digital post production effects released -99.My tip to you: See the trailers and skip the movie, since the movie itself was among the worst I've seen in years. (not counting B movies). If you're still stubborn about seeing the movie, another tip: Bring 5 cups of coffee and bring a jar of Caffein pills. You'll need it!

Review title: Perhaps the worst film I have ever seen
Review_body: *MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS*Having read a number of reviews on this website, I think that my summary of this movie will ring false to many people.  I thought for some time about what to say about this film, and realized that very little else would express my views.  This movie does have good special effects, and it is only due to that that it gets the one star out of ten that I would give it.  I can deal with movies that are supposed to be fun lacking brilliant cinematography or fantastic acting.  All that I ask is that the film live up to what it is meant to be.  In the case of "The Haunting," that is a horror movie.  I swear to you that I am not exagerating when I say that the closest I came to having a frightened response to this film was one slight flexing of my right calf muscle in one scene of the movie.  It really wasn't a frightening scene - just startling.  My biggest beef with the movie is that it has all of the sterotypes and stupid audience grabbing devices that tend to piss me off.  An example:  Catherine Zeta-Jones has several incredibly heavy-handed lines that hint at her bisexuality.  Message, "hey adolescent boys, this character might hook up with another woman.  Watch and get turned on."  It is a lame device used in the abscence of real plot to draw people into the film.  The same thing is done with the special effects.  Basically, I hated this film.  If I hadn't been with a group of friends on whom I was dependent for a ride home, I would have walked out.  It was not fun to watch in any way.  As a fellow audience member said on the way out to people waiting in line to see this film, "Just stick a fork in your eyes.  It will be cheaper and more fun."

Review title: It'll make you jump out of your seat
Review_body: I thought this movie was awesome.  It had some parts that would really scare the pants off of you.  The actors and actresses did a fine job. This was one of the best haunted house movies I have seen.  The house in the movie was just beautiful.

The haunting was a good film with a good storyline and some good acting however it was just not creepy enough. The film was very jumpy at parts but i prefer horror films that are scary all the way through and not shocking in parts. However the interesting storyline makes up for the lack in creepyness and it might make you jump out of your skin in parts.

Review title: well I, for one, enjoyed it
Review_body: What is everyone's problem with the movie? Why can't you just sit back and enjoy it rather than look for all the bad mistakes the director made or how the actors should have been someone else. I thought it was a great movie and saw it thrice.

Oh, dear, oh, dear. This was bad. Very, very bad. I went to see this with my niece (15 yrs) to be a good uncle and to give her, at least, a reasonable scare. But alas, Neeson, Zeta-Jones et al, couldn't scare a 15 year old girl from Northern Norway, let alone her uncle. I hoped it would be an ordinary but scary movie. But apart from the spectacular special effects, it was a huge disappointment, even for my expectations. The plot is wafer thin, the characters cardboard-like, and the ghosts are as scary as those in Ghostbusters. Two things crossed my mind when I was suffering in the theatre: What the hell was Neeson thinking, when he said "Yess!" to this movie? AND,It's a shame to use such splendid surroundings as the Hill house to shoot The Haunting... (And don't tell me the castle is data-animated?)

When you hear the word "haunting", it makes you think automatically of some spooky old house with ghosts that chase you around.  Well, basically, as you have seen in the previews, this is what this film is about.  3 complete strangers stay in an old house and get freaked out by some"thing".The thing is, this film is unlike any other scary movie i have seen before. It is a scary movie, but not in the usual sense of scariness.  There is no guy in a black hooded costume chasing innocent young girls with a butcher knife, but instead a house come to life by things unknown.  The special effects are used in this movie like no other.  Instead if using goriness to freak others out, they imply violence, rather than showing it to you face to face.  The CGIs are astounding.  They bring the house to life for the viewer without making you feel that you are inside some elaborate computer game. Overall, this movie is the best horror movie to come out since "Screa-": well let's not give that gore-fest too much credit...

One of the worst films ever made. Without Liam Neeson, this would be a complete failure. The special effects cannot redeem this pitiful adaptation of Shirley Jackson's original -- the attempt to spin this tail of psychological suspense into a modern day horror flick fails miserably and is at times almost comical in doing so.

OH MY GOD!!!!!!!!!!!!! What a awful film. I will not give away any of the plot as it really has none. Go and see the great 1963 movie and only watch this mess if you want good laugh. The 1963 movie is one of my all time favourite films. Its a movie that if you watch alone at night try just try to sleep with out the lights off! The sounds of banging on the door is chilling. This movie version does have a great house as did the 1963 film. I don't know where the new one was filmed. The house in the 1963 version was filmed at Ettington Park Hotel in England and its house that truly has a life of its own. And this house in the new one has that same feeling. So there was all the ingredients for a good film. But they missed by miles.

Review title: What a Steaming Pile of Crap
Review_body: I actually saw this turd in the theater--worse, at an uncomfortable theater. I don't know what this miserable attempt was trying to be, but it sure as hell wasn't scary, or creepy, or even cool.  I don't know who thought that just because Speed made money, that deBont was a good choice to direct this junk.  Since we can do almost anything with computers these days, many filmmakers seem to have forgotten that it's not necessarily what we see in horror movies...it's what we almost see, or don't see at all.  I never would have imagined that looking at Catherine Zeta Jones could get boring, but oh, my God!  This movie SUCKS!

Well, I watched this movie for over 2 times. I thought it was all right, though I haven't read the book or watched the older version of this.I read other people's comments, and most of them rated for this movie for only two or even one star. I think this movie was well performed, and it really gave me chills every second. The children's statue and the special effects were pretty unique. We can also observe how every character shown their different personalities, and they try to fight against the evil spirit or get defeated by it. Maybe I should read the book and compare it carefully once again? I rate this movie 7 out of 10.

The original movie ( dated 19??)did not show any "monster" , it just SUGGESTED scary "things" , .This version however shows every aspect of a "sick minded ghost" , including unnecessary special effects . The "mystery " ,as presented in the original movie , was the most scary part : one simply did not know what was causing the weird things that happened. By showing the face of the "old man" , this Mister has completely disappeared. Even worse : the special effects ( crying wooden children faces) is ridiculous. This is a stupid remake , too obviously spectacular to even be close as scary as the original

If more people did their research, instead of just going on what they "hear" or may believe they know about a movie. This was not a remake of an original 1960's movie of similar theme, they were forbidden from filming any likeness. It bears more of a resemblence to Stephen Kings Rose Red, because he wrote the first draft before it fell through. Really an awesome movie with a compelling, believable ghost story.

Horrible CGI, laughable plot with no connective tissue until the last twenty minutes, weirdly famous actors that somehow all did the worst job ever, dumb ending....must i go on...do yourself a favor and watch the netflix series adaption. Two stars because we laughed the whole time over how stupid it is
Hello everyone I'm telling you now do not watch this film thanks.

The Haunting (1999) version is no where near as scary as the 1960's version. I think the movie was all hype and failed to produce the intensity the older version did. The house was amazing, but even with all the special affects, I recommend you go back and watch the original.
Shirley Jackson would crawl out of her grave to kill whatever this is.

Well, I...I don't know what to say. Sweet merciful Christ.I would rather see a Super8 dragged through the mud by a young Finnish boy, blathering about in his native tongue, than view this awful piece of filth once more. I feel sorry for the relatively capable cast for this inclusion on their resumes.Holy...LORD. A simple case of some buffoon, or presumably a group of them, trying to repackage a classic for the bumbling idiocy of the modern movie audience. I mean, people sat around an expensive wooden table, discussed this heap at length, and eventually, they were all nodding in agreement. Someone WATCHED this AFTER it was filmed and mumbled "Sure." A very sad moment.Let this go down as one of the WORST remakes in the history of cinema.Stay away.

I have seen the 1963 version as a child and as an adult, and I have read the actual Shirley Jackson novel. What the heck does this movie have to do with any of it??? SO much of the plot is NOT in the book or the earlier version. They took a title and made up their own movie around it, and the result was horrible. Whose idea was this anyway??? In the original, Hugh Crain was NOT some industrialist who exploited children. Eleanor was NOT his granddaughter. The original movie and book made the idea of "haunting" a very individual experience, and most of what happened happened inside the heads of the individual characters. This movie, though made in 1999, was obviously made for small minds that lack imagination and cannot deal with suggestion. These folks need the computer-generated nonsense, the gore, and the whole thing laid right out there so that no imagination needs to be utilized. Sad, sad, sad.

One of the most atmospheric and frightening films ever made was 'The Haunting', the black and white original film made in 1963. I am not easily scared by a film, and seldom twice by the same film, but the fear this one engenders is primal and eternal. I still wont watch it alone even now. It touches something deep and terrifying inside you. What a film.Then a crime was committed; it was re-made in 1999 and turned into a Hollywood joke of a film with Catherine Zita Jones and a ton of special effects. The result doesn't deserve to ever air. Its a dull self indulgent bore of a film that desecrates all that was brilliant, and everything that was scary, in the original. It's a familiar story. The Director doesn't have the skill to create narrative tension, but boy do they have a special effects budget so lets throw millions of dollars at it it and yawn. Of course the problem with special effects is that they're not that special anymore, and the idea that you can prop up a badly made film with CGI surely doesn't apply to audiences over 18 years of age? Then there's the cast. Oh dear. This story assumes powerful and complex characterisations to develop and advance the narrative. Paper thin acting doesn't hack it no matter how glamorous or over-paid the performers may be. For my money there has to be a certain arrogance in thinking you can remake a brilliant film, so if you're going to, you'd better deliver. This is a catastrophe of ego and hubris unredeemed by vision, talent, or tension.The only frightening aspect of the film is wondering how many millions of dollars were squandered on this folly - putting the cash in a big pile in the street and setting fire to it so tramps could get warm on cold nights would have been a better use of the money. See the 1963 original, it's a fabulous and genuinely terrifying film.

This movie could have been a lot better.It seems they decided to ignore the idea that made the original movie great, that being to leave the ghosts to your imagination, and did the exact opposite.Not only that but the ghosts look terrible. The children ghosts look like Casper the ghosts friends or something and Hugh Crane looks like Paul Bunyan.CG might be good in some epic movie like Lord of the Rings but it ruins horror movies.Everything else was actually pretty good though. If you can get past the CG ghosts you might find this movie entertaining but I much prefer the original.

Review title: Not a bad re-make, not the same film as the original
Review_body: The original movie was pure mood. It didn't show any gore, not even any blood, yet it had you checking under the bed, inside the closet, and behind every door before you went to bed that night (& maybe a few nights thereafter if you were sensitive to horror movies). This re-make is a substantially different plot. In the original Eleanor is a highly sensitive weak willed single woman (read "Spinster") who was badly taken advantage of by her family. She has no will to resist the deadly spirit of Hill House. In the re-make, Eleanor is a highly sensitive strong willed single woman (if she's a "Spinster", WOW!) who was badly taken advantage of by her family. Having gone through 11 very hard years with her invalid mother, she has developed the inner strength to stand up to, and defeat the deadly spirit of Hill House. The all-star cast helps the re-make, the house itself (well, the special effects) is a leading character in the re-make & is VERY impressive. The set (I include Katherine Zeta-Jones as a moving prop) is incredible. All in all a good one for horror fans if not a blockbuster for the rest of us.

I wonder if it is England or Brittain Or France or Germany maybe.I would love to see the movie on Halloween night . It's better then "Halloween". It kept me on the edge of my seat. The special effects were great. This movie was loaded with detail, but not enough to make you loose interest. If anyone knows if this place is for real, please leave some information on it. I want to know where it is and if there is a web site with further details.I also need to see the original. I bet it was great for 1963, that was a good year. The Director did a heck of a job on this movie, as did the actors. No need to copy this movie anymore. This 1999 feature was great.

Review title: I know there are worse films but I can't think of any...
Review_body: I love films, but I hate wasting my time. I guess that's the gamble. This film was simply a huge waste of time--for me and the film makers. Aside from not being scary, it has the weakest story line imaginable. There's not much more to say. I've seen better made-for-TV movies.

Review title: Saw when I was 11 and still like it!
Review_body: I saw this when I was 11, and liked it. Granted I didn't sleep with my feet over the bedside for a while. After watching it again tonight, I realize that I still like it. There is symbolism in having a 'no-name' actress play the main character. It goes with the character. The effects were fun, and very much my style of creepy, suspense, and just plain disturbing. And for being made in 1999, The Haunting is very well done. You clearly see the fear in the characters as they try to figure out what was going on, and the change that happens in the main character is very subtle and empathetic to a receptive audience. I don't watch horror/suspense movies because I am very empathetic and remember details, but this is a movie even for 'chicken' audiences. I recommend this movie if you prefer suspense and thriller with dignity over gore, blood, and screaming college students. ^~^

Review title: One of the worst movies of all time.
Review_body: This remake is on my personal list of the five worst movies of all time, and a serious contender for the absolute worst -- right down there with "Night Train to Venice" (1993). It is as if a couple of illiterate junior-high-dropout stoners had been hired, at great expense, to adapt Shirley Jackson's disturbing, even terrifying, novella into a seventh-grade level comic book. The kindest thing I can say for the actors is that they try to work with the dreck they've been given. (They don't succeed.) The director has no idea of how to generate suspense, or fear, or horror. He apparently believed that a battery of increasingly ridiculous CGI special effects would take care of those things. (They don't.) The movie is campy, overproduced, and ludicrously over-the-top. At one point, around midway through the film, I literally fell off my couch laughing at a "dramatic" episode that was meant to be frightening but was instead face-palmingly moronic. After that brief moment, however, sad to say, the film went ever more rapidly downhill -- from mildly amusingly in its stupidity to preachy, saccharine, self-important, embarrassing, incoherent, and just plain boring. I sincerely hope that this film damaged or ended the careers of its chief makers. By the time the credits rolled, I was angry that I'd wasted my time watching this meretricious trash and felt like I'd lost twenty points off my IQ in the process.

Review title: You want to know what's scarier than this film?
Review_body: My balls are scarier than this film. Seriously. I looked down at my balls in the shower today and thought, "Crikey, aren't my balls unsightly". That feeling was more unsettling than anything that this film has to offer. If that mild feeling of displeasure caused by glancing at my own balls were to go for an interview with this film for the position of being engaging on any level, they would be sent home for being vastly over qualified. In an interview, my balls would have shown the interviewer - this film - up for the lame, lazy, celebrity vehicle it is. In fact, MY BALLS SHOULD HAVE WRITTEN AND DIRECTED THIS FILM. My ugly, wrinkly balls. All hail my balls! Hail them! By the standards this film has set, my balls will rule Hollywood. I have Shane Meadows balls. Kubrick balls. They are downy haired Nolan balls. One day, they will put together a film ever so mildly scary and it will make all responsible for The Haunting (1999) cack in their pants. The mildly scary movie my balls will create will blow their obviously very limited minds.

This movie was incredibly appalling. As a fan of the book, I was interested to see if this version could hold up. It couldn't. It's funny with trying to be with horrific dialogue predictable events. I ended up laughing through 90% of the movie and groaning through the other 10%. The special effects are horrible as well-I wondered through most of it if the animators even tried at all. Everything's very cartoonish and cheesy, which took away a lot for me. Even seasoned actors such as Liam Neeson and Lili Taylor couldn't pull this mess up. I expected better from them, but they didn't have much to work with. The only really good part of the movie was the photography, but that was overshadowed by the bad.Read the book or see the original, and skip this one.2 stars out of 10, out of pity.

Review title: The worst movie I've ever seen.
Review_body: I'm not going to say this is the worst movie ever because I haven't seen every movie in existence, but so far, I have never seen such a horrible movie. The acting is awful. Lili Taylor would not pass as a good actress in an elementary school play. I can't even believe somebody would pay her to act. The script is just plain terrible. All of the characters are completely cliché. The special effects are laughably cheesy. The plot is almost as bad as the acting (and no I have not read the book).In summary, do not watch this movie. Don't even think about watching it. It is slow torture.

Because the overall reviews are just so bad i felt compelled to say something. I saw this movie when I was around 15 years old and thought at the time that it was pretty scary, now not so much.I find it to be a Disney horror, if Pixar and Disney were to make a horror movie this is what you would get. you have mystery, action and a feel good ending. I never saw the original and I'm not really someone that likes horror movies so that says enough about the film to know that it really is not that scary. I loved the special effects and build up to the end, although the end is somewhat exaggerated I loved the part when he is defeated and the child ghosts go to heaven.What can I say I love Disney movies.

The Haunting. A remake, of course. The original was a creepy psychological thriller, and one that has improved with time. Compared to this 1999 remake, it's a classic. There is no character development here, only caricatures (the slut, the authoritative brain, the "I'm gonna get us outta here" fellow, the oh so sensitive bookworm). But, seeing as how the were banking on the special effects being the "star", I guess characters that you can empathize with are a secondary concern. Unfortunately, the effects are laughable. Mewing cherubs, stretchy doors, irritating dead children that can't speak plainly ... and an idiotically sappy ending that does it's darnedest to give you a new age enema of butterflies and rainbows. Ill take my Skittles orally, thank you. Bruce Dern, I've liked you since "The Cowboys". Stop it.

I'm stunned. Is it possible to miss the point of the book any more completely? It's supposed to be a psychological thriller. The *whole* point was the ambiguity.The reader (or watcher if you're talking about the old B+W version) is supposed to decide for themselves if the house was really haunted, or if Eleanor was just suggestible and in need of a home, or if Eleanor was doing it herself with her mentioned paranormal abilities, or if it was maybe the house *and* Eleanor both doing things. You never saw the actual ghosts because you weren't supposed to know for sure if there were any! This bears no resemblance at all to Shirley Jacksons lovely, spooky psychological thriller.
So sad Lili Taylor was not first in the recognition of casts on here. She made the show, it was her story. Catherine Zeta Jones was not the star.

So it starts with a beautiful old house in the country. You have a group of people who get asked to come to this house and (not surprisingly) the caretakers always lock the gates at night for no apparent reason. Anywhoo, the people laugh, joke etc. This Dr tells them a spooky story of this woman and some kids. They get scared, they start to feel stuff. Oh no, a girl see's s ghost. Some more talking then this huge ghost comes and etc etc. This girl finds out that this ghost killed little kids and that she must free their souls, yeah yeah, blah blah. She does but, oh no, she dies as she does. And goes to heaven whilst this evil ghost goes to hell. Two people survive and escape the house. The script is terrible because a guy gets his head chopped off and Elanor (the one who dies saving the kids) says "oh no". The acting is wooden, the effects are crap and the set is a couple off rooms used over and over again. Basically if you like laughing at badly made films watch it, but if your looking for a scare then definitely give this film a miss. I was extremely disappointed when I watched this. A very big let down. My sister (who gets sacred very easily) got bored in this film it is appalling.

Review title: No point in watching this film
Review_body: This film has nothing to say, so I won't say much about it. It was meant to make money, it made it, now let's move on.Liam Neeson is wasted here.Catherine Zeta Jones is beautiful, her lines are crap and her personality is a caricature. Owen Wilson plays Owen Wilson, although his name in this film is Luke.Lili Taylor plays some kind of character. Not sure what. She saw a decapitation and just said "on, no." Theo (CZJ) was screaming - she covered her mouth in horror but the sound was coming as if it wasn't muffled, as if it were dubbed.The music has some ridiculous circus themes. I don't know what this film wants to be. Haunted house? Undead children? Scary paintings? Gargoyle statues coming to life?Why not all of the above?How about some comedy. Dr. Marrow says "what do we all need in life, the basics, food, water, shelter." Theo (Zeta Jones) interrupts/adds "sex" with the subtlety of a sledgehammer, to which Luke (Owen Wilson) responds "meow." Yups, Owen Wilson plays himself. If you've seen him say "wow" many times, then meow isn't far off. It's not scary, not funny, not entertaining, not dramatic, not mysterious, not anything.The special effects, some look good, some bad, but I won't give it plus points over good effects nor minus over bad ones. The attacking spider bed effect was interesting, but that's not why anyone would watch a film.Don't watch.

As I have recently watched many rather stupid and low budget horror movies, 'The Haunting' really did it for me. The set was definitely mind blowing, even though most of it was recreated on a sound stage in the US. The enormity of the house depicted has to be seen to be believed, even then it cannot be.I found 'Hill House' incredibly haunting, so any plot staged in that place would be creepy by nature. I don't usually find special effects believable and mostly they are completely over the top. Effects in this movie are excellent with photography to match. As for the very creative and enormity of the sets, they were stunning and very professionally done.I rate this movie as a 9......that's quite high I know, but it really tickled my imagination. The best movie I've seen in quite a while, (most movies along these lines are rubbish) so I'll definitely watch it again.

When I saw this movie in theaters, I couldn't sleep for days. I was 12 and images like Hugh Crane lunging out of the fireplace or his angry face appearing in the window frightened me beyond belief.I watched it last night for the first time in many years a few days after revisiting the 1963 film. And it was just truly awful. I found myself resisting the temptation to quit early because I believe in seeing things true to the end unless I absolutely can't bear it. Annoying acting saved by Liam and Owen. Catherine cannot play terrified and as much as I admire Lili, she's no Julie Harris. I will admit that the face in the window seen still gave me a little bit of a chill but nowhere near what it did when I was 12.One other positive is that it has reaffirmed my enthusiasm for exploring huge houses.

They screwed up this story! In the end Nell is all heroic and taking on for the team to save all their asses from Hill House and a bunch of nonsense like that! They added heads getting chopped, wires cutting peoples faces, and the ceiling turning into a giant hand! What the hell is that about??? I own and love the original movie, I read the book and I love it! The reason why the original movie and the book are so great is because it scares you so much without even showing the ghost. There is no gore. There is no ceiling hand. It is only the ghost ad how ghosts can truly kill a person. They cannot kill us, they cannot throw us about the room or fly a knife into our head. No. They can only drive us mad. Taking away all our senses of security. Nell was a selfish woman. She only wanted good things for herself. Yes, she cared a little for the others, but not too much. David Self and Jan de Bont have taken a crap on this great story! I hate this damn remake!
